column2: ST. PETERSBURGH, Fla., March 4--Yogi Berry is unquestionably the most incorrigible sports follower in the big leagues. As soon as the baseball season ends, he roots violently for the Football Giants. Then he haunts Madison Squara Garden all winter long, watching basketball, boxing, hockey, track and--who knows?--maybe even the dog show.

A revised and simplified set of formulas for his enlarged theory of relativity was completed by Dr. Albert Einstein in December, 1954, a few months before his death, April 18, 1955.

DETROIT, March 5 (AP)--The auto industry is scheduling production of nearly 610,000 passenger cars this month. If its plans do not miscarry that will bring it a first-quarter output of more than 1,775,000 cars.

WASHINGTON, March 5--The latest revision of the Bricker proposal to amend the Constitution, which was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee today, appears to be a pious Legal platitude until three words in it are noted.
The three-man Federal Maritime Board, in a split decision, denied approval yesterday of a dual-rate system proposed by member lines of the Trans-Pacific Freight Conference of Japan.
ALBANY, March 5--The State Bar Association endorsed today a bill that would create twentysix additional places on the State Supreme Court bench.

A record volume of sales and a 45 per cent increase in earnings last year were reported yesterday by the Industrial Rayon Corporation in its thirtieth annual statement to stockholders.

If there's a cheerier note today in the fire command at an antiaircraft battery drill somewhere in Queens, it's probably because the platoon sergeant's wife is going to join him after living apart for two years.

WASHINGTON, March 5-- The long-blocked proposal that a President's treaty-making powers be policed by the Congress was given another chance for a Senate showdown today. This came in the acceptance by the Senate Judiciary Committee of new and conciliatory language that might let it receive Senate approval.

WASHINGTON, March-- Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota, told the Senate today that he was under pressure from party leaders in his state to help the Administration retain flexible farm price supports.

The new Norwegian-flag motor vessel Libreville will enter service for the Fern-Ville Mediterranean Line on March 20 when she sails from here on her maiden voyage for North African, Italian and Near Eastern ports.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday ordered charges filed against Charley Johnston for violation of the board's rules against "undercover" managers.

The City Council threw a temporary roadblock yesterday into the path of legislation making permanent the stock car taxicab. A local law making the small cab permanent was approved by the Council a week ago and sent to Mayor Wagner for public hearing and signature.
THE era when parents were urged to "share everything with the children," including the kind of financial details usually reserved for the tax collector, would appear to be on the wane.

While being blasted as "dictatorial" and "unfair" in its treatment of Wes Santee, the Amateur Athletic Union moved vigorously forward yesterday in its campaign to rule America's fastest miler off the track for violation of the amateur code.

THE uphill battle to win a minimum chance for edu cational television in New York City has reached another turning point. Unless the Legislature acts favorably within the immediate days ahead on a pending bill, the prospects for educational TV could be darker than ever.
CHICAGO, March 6--Educational leaders heard many of their accepted practices challenged today.
SALMON anglers may get some comfort from an optimistic report on prospects this year on the Miramichi, where things were a good deal less than good last year.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 6 --John S. Stamm, Bishop Emeritus of the Evangelical United Brethren Church and president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America in 1948 and 1949, died here yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 77 years old.
MOSCOW, March 6--Denmark has resisted Soviet pressure to obtain a formal pledge that she would bar foreign troops or bases from her territory.

A new type of denim--half rayon and half cotton--has been developed by two prominent textile concerns. They hope it can crack the 400,000,000-yards-ayear market for denim in work and play clothes.

The names of sixty-nine nominees for the theatre's Antoinette Perry Awards were announced yesterday.

The longest winning streak in college sports--Yale's 141 consecutive dual-meet victories in swimming--will be in serious danger Saturday.
Ford stock, after a brief and adventurous sojourn in the overthe-counter market, goes on the New York Stock Exchange today.

HATTIE CARNEGIE did not live to see the spring col lection presented at her salon yesterday, but the stamp of her instinctive taste on every design was unmistakable. It was pure, custom-made Carnegie.

Mrs. Average Consumer has been closely watched as she does her shopping for food. The watchers, working for Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., found that 86 per cent of women in this country do their food buying chiefly in a single store. Of this number 91 per cent (or 78 per cent of the total) shop mainly in a self-service store, while 7 per cent shop mostly in a clerk-service store.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6--It is a truism in baseball that no major league club is stronger than its bench. That means that the entry with the greater number of talented reserves, ready to jump in wherever an emergency might arise, has the best over-all chance to finish on top.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP)--The president of Brink's, Inc., said today that its chairman should quit trying to influence employee and stockholders in favor of an Eastern holding company that is trying to gain control.

JEROME ROBBINS' new ballet, "The Concert," had its premiere by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night. Nat Holman, the basketball coach, yesterday applied for a year's sabbatical leave from City College. His request was approved by the Hygiene Department, but college officials and the Board of Higher Education have to rule on it.

St. Louis borrowed $2,150,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance various public improvements. WASHINGTON, March 7-- President Eisenhower resumed today his Wednesday golfing routine, but rain chased him back to the Burning Tree Club, house in near-by Marylan after only six holes. This was the first Wednesday in Washington on which the President has played golf since his heart attack last Sept. 24.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) --The United States hailed today "the farsighted and generous statesmanship" that led to the French-Moroccan declaration of independence for Morocco.

ALBANY, March 7--The New York Central Railroad won a reprieve today from the Public Service Commission's threat to punish it for running trains late on its main line.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh kept his promise yesterday to impose jail terms on scofflaws arrested on warrants. He sentenced a 22-year-old banana peddler to a thirty-day jail term.

Robert S. Lourie has been appointed national sales manager in charge of gin for the Four Roses Distillers Company, it was announced yesterday by Jay Could, executive vice president.

A two-story business building on plot 85 by 100 feet, at Thirteenth and Vine Streets, in Philadelphia, Pa., occupied under lease by the Universale Pictures Corporation, has been sold by David Green to a New York investor represented by Edward Menden, attorney.

Rainy weather, accompanied by a low ceiling and poor visibility, interfered yesterday with flights to and from La Guardia Airport. The New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, was not affected.

CHICAGO, March 7--Price moves in grain and soybean futures were mixed today on the Board of Trade. Corn demand broadened, and wheat was under some pressure. Soybeans reacted from yesterday's strong close. Rye declined, and oats were inclined to drag.
The Isthmian Steamship Company will continue its worldwide cargo services indefinitely as a separate entity, C.S. Walsh, president of States Marine Corporation, said yesterday.
CARACAS, March 7--Dr. Bernardo Mattarella, Minister of Foreign Trade in the Italian Cabnet, arrived in Caracas today accompanied by his wife and three aides.

PARIS, March 7--Three civil servants and a journalist went on trial here today on charges of having leaked military secrets. Their case, when it broke eighteen months ago, caused a major political uproar and involved in the controversy many of France's most noted political figures.
The Pitston Company yesterday denied reports that it is seeking to acquire control of Briaks, Inc., of Chicago. Pitston recently acquired 44,500 shares of Brink stock at $36.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board restricted today its trans-Pacific air route proceeding to an application by Pan American World Airways.
A Chinese laundryman has been cited for contempt for assertedly giving false and evasive answers to a special Federal grand jury investigating passport frauds by Chinese nationals.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. March 7--An American Boy Scout is being sought to serve as a junior scientific aide in Antarctica during the International Geophysical Year, 1957-58.

CHICAGO, March 7--Union leaders put forward today what gave promise of becoming the most costly set of contract demands ever presented to the steel industry.

Price increases of as much as 10 per cent were announced yesterday in the fall line of Dobbs and Knox hats produced by the Hat Corporation of America. Other producers are expected to announce similar increases.

Training methods of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were employed yesterday by student detectives of the New York police.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, March 8--The International Union of Electrical Workers was reported to have voted last night not to accept in its present form a Government plan to settle the 143-day Westinghouse strike. The company accepted the compromise Tuesday.

President Eisenhower yesterday commended the work done by the overseas relief agencies of the three major religious faiths in a message to the directors of each agency. The message was sent on the eve of the groups' fund campaigns.

Schulz imposed the sentence for the week of April 23. Development of the first effective antidote against wartime use of deadly nerve gas, was announced here yesterday by a team of Columbia University biochemists. The antidote has protected 100 per cent of the animals exposed to doses of nerve gas that would have killed them in less than five minutes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13--The Columbia Broadcasting System and the Screen Actors Guild failed today to make any headway in settling a jurisdictional dispute involving the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

CLEVELAND, March 13 (AP)-- J.P. Seiberling, president of Seiberling Rubber Company, Akron, said today present management would wage an all-out fight against an attempt by Edward Lamb to gain control of the company.

DUBLIN, March 13--Alderman Alfred Byrne, ten times the Lord Mayor of Dublin, died here today at the age of 74. One of the most popular men in Ireland, he was known to thousands of his countrymen as "Alfie."

A drinking establishment exists for every 548 residents of Manhattan. This compares with a city-wide average of one bar for every 941 inhabitants, according to the 1955 annual report issued yesterday by the State Liquor Authority.
John P. McGrath said yesterday that the Waterfront Commission has not gone "political" or "soft" as the result of his appointment as Commisioner representing New York.

Everything that could have been hoped from the two-week visit of President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy to the United States has come to pass. We say good-by to him this morning with mingled regret and satisfaction.

JERSEY CITY, March 13-- The director of this city's recreation department and three of his aides were indicted here today by a grand jury on charges of condoning absences from jobs. They were accused of conspiracy.

The shell of the 8,013-footlong third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel will be completed within sixty days. Extra crews working round-the-clock have regained the time lost by the flooding of Jan. 25 that hampered operations at the land tunnel on the New York side of the Hudson River crossing.
LONDON, March 13--The Government scrapped its old retail price index today and substituted a new one intended to reflect more accurately the current pattern of spending in British households.

For Sandor Iharos, a lanky individual with long pointed features and a shock of brown hair, holds six world's running titles.
THE artichoke, thistle-shaped, nutty-flavored, is most abun dant this month and next. This, then, is the time when the vegetable can come to dinner in delicious ways, many borrowed from the French.

Commodity futures trading was unusually light in most New York markets yesterday. Prices drifted generally lower in featureless trading, Coffee, potatoes, wool, rubber and hides declined; cocoa rose, and price movements for sugar, cottonseed oil and soybean oil were mixed.

LONDON, Mar. 13--A rise in prices here today as a result of the new record high set by the New York Stock Exchange was offset by a decline in British Government issues. Business was slightly higher today, final day of the list bookkeeping account of the Stock Exchange's financial year.

CAIRO, March 13--French Foreign Minister Christian Pineau is coming here tomorrow from India for talks with Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser. He is expected to discuss with the Premier all aspects of France's relations with Egypt.

Northrup Knox, Frank Shields and James Bostwick, all amateurs, reached the quarter-finals of the United States open court tennis championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12-- The Presidential press conference Wednesday morning will mark the forty-third anniversary of this distinctively American institution. This is the fourth dispatch of a series by the British general who was the commander of the Arab Legion of Jordan until he was dismissed recently by King Hussein.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- When an economist talks about "Savings," he quickly loses the layman in a wilderness of definition.

BONN, Germany, March 14--A Bundestag committee rejected today a proposal to give West Berlin direct representation in the lower house of the West German Parliament. The proposal, made by the Social Democratic Opposition, was opposed by the United States, Britain and France.

J.A. Columbus of Anchorage, Alaska, received the Sagamore Hill Medal of the Boone and Crockett Club last night for his record polar bear trophy entered in the club's seventh biennial North American big game competition.
WASHINGTON, March 14--The White House said tonight that President Eisenhower had invited the Prime Minister of India, Jawaharlal Nehru, to visit him in Washington.

St. Patrick's Day this year will be special. Prime Minister John A. Costello arrived in the United States yesterday from Dublin and will be the prize guest at New York's parade on Saturday. The Republic of Ireland could not have sent a citizen more deserving of honor.
The chief organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association will make his oncepostponed recruiting trip through the Midwest "in another week or two," it was learned yesterday.

The circus faces a strike at opening time in Madison Square Garden on April 4. Two unions announced yesterday that they planned to picket the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey show in protest against its refusal to sign contracts covering 900 entertainers, roustabouts and drivers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14--Bob Clampett, producer of "Time for Beany," sued the National Broadcasting Company and Stan Freberg yesterday for $2,000,000 over the use of a puppet character.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 5 points off to 13 points up.
Johnny Podres will do his 1956 pitching--if any--for the United States Army.
TANGIER, Morocco, March 14--Moroccan nationalist leaders said today instructions had been sent to "resistance fighters" in the Riff and northeastern Morocco to suspend hostilities against the French.

A hundred and fifty years ago today the Orphan Asylum Society in the City of New York was founded by Mrs. Isabella Graham, who in 1806 called in ten ladies including Mrs. Alexander Hamilton to deal with the problem created by an overflowing almshouse and the ravages...

SATURDAY, 11:30 A. M.: Four stories will be told at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue at Park Place. At 1:15 P.M. a live animal program will be given, followed by science, cultural history and planetarium demonstrations at 2:30, 3 and 3:30 P. M. Free.

The Maritime Administration yesterday granted approval in principle to plans of two major American oil companies for construction of two to four new tankers and major alterations to three bulk oil carriers.

The Pennsylvania Railroad plans to ask for increases in passenger fares and other services by amounts up to 6 per cent This was disclosed yesterday by James M. Symes, president, in the company's annual report mailed to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Business outlays for plant expansion this year will be the greatest in history with a total of $35,000,000,000, the Government predicted today. The figure is 22 per cent higher than the record level of $28,700,000,000 achieved in 1955.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 14--The smashing endorsement of Vice President Richard M. Nixon by Republicans in yesterday's New Hampshire primary took the spotlight here today. It overshadowed Senator Estes Kefauver's sweep of the Democratic contest.
Air hammers and drills let up their din in replacing worn-out marble at City Hall yesterday long enough to permit a meeting inside to proceed in peace.

Mr. and Mrs. David H. Friedman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Marian Friedman, to Bertram Richard Newman. He is a son of Mrs. Frederick H. Newman, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Newman.

CAIRO March 14--Christian Pineau, French Foreign Minister, said today that Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt had assured him that not a single North African guerrilla had been trained in Egypt during the last several months.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 14-- Officials here welcomed President Eisenhower's statement today that the possibility of arms deliveries to Israel was not foreclosed.

Miami Beach hotels, which do things in a big way, spent more than $6,000,000 for advertising last year, with the largest portion going to metropolitan newspapers. This was reported yesterday by Sam A. Rivkind, executive president of the Miami Beach...

The 9,800-block survey of the Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean has rated about 1,300 blocks as "poor" or "very bad"--in spite of the fact that the coordinated campaign against litter has now been going on for a year.
ALBANY, March 14--Both houses of the Legislature voted today to authorize a new charter giving a stronger and more centralized form of government for Suffolk County.
LONDON, March 14--The British Government's policy in Cyprus and the deportation of Archbishop Makarios were decisively endorsed in the House of Commons tonight.
CHICAGO, March 14--There was an outbreak of booing in a crowd of 12,145 at the Chicago Stadium tonight.
ALBANY, March 14--Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Jacob K. Javits joined the Public Service Commission today in support of a bill to end a dual standard for fixing utility rates.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Eisenhower said today he would be happy to run on any political ticket with Richard M. Nixon.
The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York appealed yesterday for $2,816,000 to carry on its work in the coming year.

A public offering of $10,000,000 of Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc. 3 per cent sinking funds debentures due in 1976, is being made today by an underwriting group headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane. The debentures are priced at par and accrued interest.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates yesterday were selected by competitive bidding to purchase up to $23,000,000 of any collateral trust 4 per cent notes of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company not taken up by first mortgage bondholders of...

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is seeking permission of its stockholders to borrow $46,520,000 more. The company's present long-term debt--including $50,112,000 of equipment trust obligations--stands at $204, 315,400.

AS Ben-Zion himself says of the two cycles of Biblical etchings now on exhibition at the Duveen-Graham Galleries, 1014 Madison Avenue, they are a collection of Biblical themes rather than illustrations. The two groups, each comprising...

NEW DELHI, India, March 14--The tall, thin man who once ruled India in the name of the British crown descended from his plane here today. The man who rules India now stepped forward and put out his hand.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 14 --A British police sergeant was shot dead in the center of Nicosia this morning. Thus Greek Cypriote terrorists carried out the first killing in revenge for the exile of Archbishop Makarios.

Bill Russell, San Francisco ace, and Bill Thieben of Hofstra College, were honored by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association yesterday. The writers also announced their selections for the 1955-56 All-Metropolitan collegiate team.

A warning that builders may possibly be providing an oversupply of new apartments on Manhattan's East Side was sounded yesterday by an executive officer of one of the leading investment building concerns in the field.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14-- The archrivalry between Tenley Albright and Carol Heiss, two of the top figure skaters in the world, dominated the conversation as the four-day United States figure skating championships opened at the Arena today.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., March 14 --Dr. William E.B. DuBois, 88year-old co-founder of the National Association for Advancement of Colored People, has been barred from speaking at an American Labor party rally on desegregation at Levittown Hall Friday night.
The United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation is entering the book publishing and furniture making fields and expanding its interest in atomic energy with the acquisition of three companies.
Motor vehicle tolls provided the bulk of the record revenue of the widely diverse operations of the Port of New York Authority last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14--Atomic scientists from fifteen nations met here today to plan an international survey of the effects of radiation on "man and his environment."
The Sabbath Law was assailed yesterday as a "statutory crazy quilt" that resulted in New York City "more often than not in harassment and injustice."
William Faulkner, the 1949 Nobel Prize novelist, believes that the South "is armed for revolt."

A scared chimpanzee named Mike suffered through ten hours of freedom here yesterday. He sprinted across East Side rooftops for four hours and romped recklessly through one inhospitable tenant's living room.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 14-- The Georgia State Board of Education today asked that the pension of an integrationist be discontinued. He was identified as Dr. Guy H. Wells, former president of the Georgia State College for Women.
A dispute between an independent barbers union and an A.F.L.-C.I.O. barbers' local that led to organizational picketing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was settled Tuesday night.
ALBANY, March 14--The Assembly approved over Democratic opposition today a bill that would cost New York City an estimated $3,000,000 a year in higher pension expenses.
Score another triumph for the fine print.
MELBOURNE, March 14 (UP) --Faith Leech of Victoria won a special 110-yard free-style swimming race among three Australian Olympic candidates today in 1 minute 4.8 seconds.

The creation of a quasi-public financing institution, through which more than a billion dollars of union pension funds might be invested in middle-income rental and cooperative housing, was proposed testerday by State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray.

The Alabama Highway Authority yesterday postponed action on the sale of $15,000,000 of serial bonds secured by gasoline tax revenues.

ATHENS, March 14--Manifestations of United States interest in Cyprus were welcomed here today. However, as the day wore on reports described as having come from Washington tended to dampen enthusiasm.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Eisenhower called today for "moderation" on the issue of school segregation, "but with [a] determination to make progress."
The New York Rangers and The Detroit Red Wings will clash tonight at Madison Square Garden in a game that probably will decide second place in the National Hockey League race.
Commerce of Manhattan and Jefferson and Erasmus Hall of Brooklyn gained the semi-final round of the fifty-second annual Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday.

DARIEN, Conn., March 14-- This community was pondering today its next course of action after the owners of a tract had withdrawn an offer to sell it as a site for a high school.
PHILADELPHIA, March 14-- Dr. John H. Gibbon Sr., Professor Emeritus of Surgery at Jefferson Medical College, died last night in Bryn Mawr Hospital after a short illness. He was 84 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Ross Rizley, denied today that the board had conspired with the regular airlines to block new competition.
ROME, March 14--In a move to weaken Italian adherence to the Atlantic Alliance, Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, suggested today an Italian-Soviet pact of nonaggression.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- Northern Senators continued to hammer today at Southern colleagues for their recent manifesto against the Supreme Court's ruling ending segregation in the public schools.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 14 (AP)--Barbara McIntire of Toledo birdied four of the last seven holes today for a 38, 34--72, two under women's par, to win the qualifying medal in the fiftyfourth North and South amateur golf tournament. The Canadian champion, Marlene Stewart of Fonthill, Ont., was a stroke behind.
The Amalgamated Clothing Workers demanded yesterday higher wages and increased insurance benefits for 150,000 men's clothing workers in all parts of the country.
Six state-aided low-rent housing projects that will provide 3,781 new apartments at a total cost of $70,104,000 were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- President Eisenhower expressed anxiety today over decay "in getting a good farm bill to our farmers."

FLOATING fabrics and easy skirts are prominent in Ann Cox' custom collection, shown Tuesday in her shop on Fiftyseventh Street. Navy blue and flowered silks are top favorites for daytime dresses; chiffon rates high for evening.
Carbon monoxide fumes from a defective sidearm gas water heater killed a Brooklyn family of seven yesterday.

Crude oil and natural gas reserves in the United States at the end of 1955 were well above the indicated reserves on Dec. 31. 1954, according to a joint survey by the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14--Norman Retchin and Alvin Ganzer, the writer-director-producer team who recently made "The Leather Saint" with Paramount financing, are discussing a continuing association with the studio for two pictures a year. They also have their sights set on a Broadway stage production.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 15 --Paul seymour's set shot with one minute left helped the Syracuse Nationals gained the thirdplace play-off berth in the Eastern Division race of the National Basketball Association by beating the New-York Knickerbockers today.

MINEOLA, L.I, March 15-- Nassau County Republicans and Democrats designated candidates today for national and state legislative office. The slates will go before the parties' voters at the June 5 primary election.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 15 --For the second time in three days a trio of Braves' pitchers held the Dodgers to four hits. But today's game, unlike the other, wasn't a shutout.

As the legislative session in Albany nears an end we urge members of both parties to set narrow partisanship aside in the consideration of amendments to make the optional Permanent Personal Registration of voters more readily acceptable to counties and cities.
Following are excerpts of editorial comment from newspapers in various parts of the country on The New York Times survey of racial integration in the South.

New York City's public school teachers are to get a $21,000,000 salary increase. But the teachers are unhappy. They want more.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 15 --Mr. and Mrs. Emil D. Tietje have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Ann Tietje, to Harry Caldwell Briggs, son of Mrs. Charles Dwight Briggs of Worcester, Mass., and the late Mr. Briggs.
A German Parliamentary committee has made a wise and welcome decision in turning down a Socialist proposal to give West Berlin direct voting representation in the Bonn Parliament's lower house.
CHICAGO, March 15--Johnny Saxton, the new world welterweight champion, picked up a check for $42,677,49 today and in a fleeting moment changed from a tired, dour young man to an affable character.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 15-- Casey Stengel and his Yankees today made their first inspection of whatever troubles Bucky Harris may be storing up for them under the banner of the Detroit Tigers.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 15-- George Breen of Cortland State Teachers shattered the American record as he won the 1,500meter free-style title in the individual championships of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League tonight.
ALBANY, March 15--Republican legislative leaders disclosed today the details of the housing and help-for-the-aged programs that they expect the Legislature to approve before it adjourns next week.
TUNIS, Tunisia, March 15-- As Tunisia awaited an announcement from Paris of its independence, the first truly national election campaign got under way here today.

STUART, Fla., March 15-- Stump-knocker bream and bull bass were waiting in the rivers and sloughs west of here and sailfish were still rising in the Gulf Stream today. But it seemed like a good day to try for jack crevalle and blues around the St. Lucie Inlet.
Production and consumption of newsprint in February set new a records for the month, according to trade reports yesterday.

Wes Santee succeeded yesterday in getting a little more mileage out of the marathon effort to block his suspension by the Amateur Athletic Union.
WHITE PLAINS, March 15-- A test of the constitutionality of the state's Vagrancy Law was begun in Supreme Court here today by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

PARIS, March 15--France will reinforce North, Africa with another mechanized division, reducing her forces assigned to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Europe to three skeletonized divisions.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, March 16--Secretary of State Dulles declared here today that Nationalst China's defensive capacity was being "largely increased," especially in terms of air power under the ChineseUnited States mutual defense treaty.

Early American art objects, including needlecraft, paintings, shop signs and weather vanes, will be exhibited from April 11 through May 5 for the benefit of the Fresh Air Association of St. John, Inc.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March, 15--Herbert I. Segal of New York today was elected president of Van Norman Industries, Inc., at a meeting of the board of directors.
Directors of the Ward Industries Corporation elected Richard Weininger yesterday as chairman of the board and chief executive officer.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 --Tenley Emma Albright put a virtually unbreakable grip today on the women's national senior figure-skating championship by defeating six competitors in the compulsory school figures at the Arena.
WASHINTON, March 15-- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- The Senate leadership's new election-reform bill was sharply criticized today.
You mustn't be premature in the skiing business. That's what operators, who have been macking artificial, snow all season at Fahnestock Park near Carmel have learned.
THE stuff that dreams are made of is dispensed by Anna Maximilian Potok. She designs precious furs for the precious few.

CORNED beef comes into its own on St. Patrick's Day, when the Irish wear the green, watch the Fifth Avenue parade and eat again that favorite of the Emerald Isle, corned beef and cabbage. The dish is one for which many others share the Irish enthusiasm.
ON the morrow, Fifth Avenue Glen will echo the tread of St. Patrick's host from noon to March twilight. John Sheahan of Gleann Chorbraighe has inscribed the orders.
In a widening inquiry a special Federal grand jury was impaneled yesterday to investigate violence, extortion and racketeering in the food industry and small businesses.

ALBANY, March 15--A Deputy Corrections Commissioner told a Senate Finance subcommittee today that he had consulted Democratic county chairmen on appointments of prison guards from civil service lists.

According to diplomatic reports, Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party secretary, made a secret address to the recent Twentieth Congress of the Communist party explaining why Stalin was being desanctified.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 15 (AP)--Favorites sloshed unscathed through a rain-soaked, bonechilling first round in the North and South women's amateur golf tournament today, although several had close calls.
A plea for less client meddling in advertising agency affairs was voiced yesterday by Gordon C. Young, executive vice president and advertising manager of the Life Savers Corporation.
DULUTH, Minn., March 15-- Senator Estes Kefauver today saw "ominous signs" that the nation might be "walking up to the brink" of war again.

Plans are being made at frequent meetings for the David Mannes Ninetieth Anniversary Concert, to be held on the night of April 16 in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

MESA, Ariz., March 15--Until today Foster Castleman appeared to be running a slow third in the second-base sweepstakes of the Giants. He had contributed nothing to indicate he might be in contention for the job.
BULLETINS from the road have not been misleading. "My Fair Lady," which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening, is a wonderful show.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross last night served notice that she would not rescind any departmental order, regardless of objections by employe groups.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- By a one-vote margin, the Eisenhower Administration lost another major test of its farm policy in the Senate today.
Commodity Futures were unusually quiet in most markets on the New York exchanges. Trading generally was featureless with prices moving in narrow ranges. Quotations closed mixed.

ALBANY, March 15--New York State wants to know how much its personal income taxpayers are contributing to the support of persons claimed as dependents.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15--George Pal, former Paramount producer, has organized his own company, Galaxy Pictures, Inc. He plans to start work immediately on the first of six films slated for production within two years.

WASHINGTON, March 15-- Work on a United States proposal for a new United Nations effort to bring peace to the Middle East continued in the State Department, the Defense Department and other agencies today.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- The first formal Republican reply in the Senate to the Southern segregation manifesto was made today. It was in a tone of marked moderation.
CHICAGO, March 15--Corn futures prices moved up today on the Board of Trade. The firmer tone reflected recent accumulations.
The price of nylon filament yarn was slashed yesterday by two major producers. It was the first such price cut since 1948.
A $1,000,000 fund has been established by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation for International art competitions to be held every two years.
LONDON, March 15--Stock Exchange prices resumed their advance today in light trading, but Government funds and some industrial shares lost part of their gains near the close.

VIENNA, March 15--Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, soldier-politician who played an active part in turning the elerical Fascist Government of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss into a dictatorship in 1934, died of a heart ailment today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 (AP)--Five-hit pitching and a home run by Willie Jones gave a 2-1 verdict to the Phillies over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

A dilapidated building on Broadway has drawn charges by the Broadway Association that it is a "menace" and presents an "unsightly, unsafe condition." It has also drawn a promise by the Department of Housing and Building of quick remedial action.
The Borden Company, big dairy products concern, last year increased its sales to the best volume in its ninety-nine-year history, but earnings declined 5 per cent below the record attained in 1954.
The Aluminum Company of America now acknowledges that it has shelved plans for a $400,000,000 smelter near Skagway, Alaska.

LONDON, March 15--During the three months preceding my dismissal, the Jordanian Government, for the first time in its thirty-five years of existence, faced serious internal disorders. These disorders were largely instrumental in causing the termination of my services.
A panel of psychiatrists yesterday put the "use with caution" label on drug therapy for the mental disorders of children.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company reported yesterday that world-wide sales of its soaps, synthetic detergents and toilet articles reached a new high of $468,578,000 in 1955. Sales in 1954 amounted to $424,349,000.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- Senator J. William Fulbright served notice today that a bipartisan group of Senators would press a drive to gain tax relief for small business.
The Republican national chairman predicted yesterday that his party would make new gains in Southern Congressional races this year.
The State of New Hampshire borrowed $19,322,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of bonds maturing serially from 1957 to 1983.
Stocks continued to push upward yesterday and The New York Times average made a new historic high for the fifth successive day.

ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, off Wilkes Land, Antarctica, March 15--The Indian Ocean gave this Navy icebreaker a rough welcome today.

Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and its subsidiaries reported gains in 1955 in electric operating revenues and net income. This was accompished despite the loss of income from its former gas properties, according to the annual report released yesterday.

Arthur Murray, dean of dance instructors, offered $5,000 a week yesterday to Nanette Fabray to appear on his forthcoming telecast when she leaves Sid Caesar's show.
Cotton futures closed barely steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices were 1 point (5 cents a bale) lower to 21 points ($1.05 a bale) higher.

A group of suburban retailers yesterday asked manufacturers of women's apparel to keep their products out of the hands of discount operators. The manufacturers said they would try, but they needed cooperation from the retailers to do it.

Jack Johnson of New York and James Dunn of Philadelphia will meet at noon today in the final round of the first open championship sponsored by the newly formed United States Court Tennis Association. Both are professionals.

WASHINGTON, March 25-- The United States Information Agency has begun world-wide distribution of a "Primer on Communism."

Newspaper advertising set new records in February. All-time high linage figures were recorded for February and for the two months of 1956 in every category except financial advertising. Every category, including financial, showed a substantial rise over the comparable 1955 periods.

LOS ANGELES, March 25-- Senator Estes Kefauver's intensive campaign in quest of support for the Democratic Presidential nomination took him today from a Los Angeles Baptist Church to a gay garden party in suburban Beverly Hills.

PITTSBURGH, March 25-- The Hakoah Football Club of Brooklyn was defeated by the Harmarville eleven today in the first of two games to determine the Eastern division winner in the national challenge cup soccer competition. The score was 1--0.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 25--Employers and trade unions after extended negotiations have agreed on new wage levels.
Opposition has developed to the restriction of the forthcoming tour of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" to summer musical tents with their unusually large seating capacity.

Vast expansions of mortgage lending over the last several years are commencing to stir uneasiness among economists. There is a feeling that the Government, perhaps, is using nonfarm mortgage guarantees a little too generously as a hypodermic for the economy.

PARIS, March 25--French authorities are apprehensive of a general increase in the price of European coal anal its effect on industrial production. They feel that this will result from the decision taken at Luxembourg by the executive body of the European Coal and Steel Community to free the price of coal.

John A. Costello, Prime Minister of Ireland, attended Palm Sunday services at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. In the afternoon he was guest at a reception given by the American Irish Historical Society.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- Congress departs this week for a ten-day Easter holiday with nearly three months of indecisive struggle behind it and the great bulk of its work still ahead.
SUMMIT, N.J., March 25-- Robert von Ezdorf of 417 Morris Avenue, a New York architect, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 67.

Negro clergymen who are leading the bus boycott in the South are using a modern application of basic Christian precepts, the Very Rev. James A. Pike said yesterday in a sermon at New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
A new company, the Peruvian Transport Corporation, Ltd., has been incorporated under the laws of Canada.

There were too many Canadians on the ice for the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The Flying Frenchmen from Montreal seemed to be always in the right place at the right time, and consequently were able to defeat the Broadway Blues, 5 to 3.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 25(AP)--Bill Lillard of Chicago moved into the lead in two divisions of the fifty-third annual American Bowling Congress tournament today.
Crime could be reduced substantially by strict enforcement of narcotics laws and adequate hospitalization of addicts, four experts said here Yesterday.
Overbrook Hall, a six-story apartment house for forty-eight families at 180 East Hartsdale Avenue, Hartsdale, in Westchester County, has been sold by the Olin Stores Corporation.
BOGOTA, March 24--Colombia expects to receive in the course of 1956 a total of $62,000,000 in loans from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

BONN, Germany, March 25-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union has introduced a sweeping tax-reduction bill in the hope of retrieving its political leadership before the 1957 general elections.
ZURICH, March 25--Both Swiss securities and American certificate, were in brisk demand all the week in the Zurich market. The turnover was high and price rises were numerous.

Two major bar groups announced yesterday the establishment of a special trained panel of lawyers available to help defend Federal employes and industrial workers in security risk cases.
MIAMI, March 25--The Yankee-Dodger spring exhibition show today was still following the pattern of the 1955 world series.

Leaders in religion and psychiatry have joined to educate one another in the insights of the two fields and to promote mental health. Formation of the National Academy of Religion and Mental Health was formally announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- The Navy has abolishted the ceremonial presentation of Reserve commissions to Merchant Marine Academy graduates.

The steamship charter market continued upward last week, and leaders of the field saw no immediate end to the trend. For the third consecutive week the overall freight rate index topped a previous two-and-a-half-year high.

In the first Asian conference of the International Press Institute, just concluded in Tokyo, there was a high degree of realism. Criticisms of Western handling of Asian news were quickly passed over so that the Asian delegates could really come to grips with some fundamental problems.

LONDON, March 25--Disclosure by the Chancellor of the Exchequer that Great Britain incurred a deficit of 193,000,000 in its balance of payments in 1955 indicated last week a discouraging state of affairs but did not shock the city.
The convicted leader of the Negro boycott of buses in Montgomery, Ala., was given a hero's welcome by an interracial audience of 2,500 in a Brooklyn church yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25 --Rivalries among the Arab states have become so acute recently that the antagonisms seriously weaken these countries in their stand against Israel.
WASHINGTON, March 25--Undecided cases are piling up in the Supreme Court. Some observers feel that the justices may be having difficulty in reaching decisions.
MOSCOW, March 25--Important ideological and diplomatic tests are believed to be pending for Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union and the United States.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 25-- Earl Averill, whose father won many a yesteryear game for the Cleveland Indians, won one for the Tribe today.
McCOMB, Miss., March 25-- The Centenary Methodist Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Ida Fae Emmerich to Dr. Robert Charles Hardy.
IF Ernest J. Christie were not a stoic he would probably be a ruin.
Holy Week was ushered in at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday with the age-old ceremonies of Palm Sunday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25--A resume of the new Screen Actors Guild contract was mailed to more than 10,000 guild members yesterday. It contains a greater range of wage increases and improvements in working conditions than had been disclosed in the formal announcement on March 14.

Miss Gloria Jane Frankel, daughter of Mrs. Silas Kassel of Plattsburgh, N.Y., was married here yesterday to Lee Hanower of New York. He is a son of Leonard R. Hanower, former city judge of Long Beach, L. I., and Mrs. Hanower.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 25--President Iskander Mirza warned India today that while "war between India and Pakistan would be suicidal" this nation, nevertheless, would "maintain our territorial integrity by every means within our power."
NASRALLAH, Tunisia, March 25--Like the other men of this district, Salah ben Mohammed Bazouk tried his hand at voting today.

"Little Glass Clock," a comedy by Hugh Mills concerning amorous goings-on in a French chateau during the reign of Louis XV, will open tonight at the John Golden Theatre. The curtain is scheduled for 8 o'clock.
PHILADELPHIA, March 25-- The chairmen of the two major political parties squared off today in a nationally televised debate over "Who Will Win in 1956."

A choir of bell ringers played three Palm Sunday hymns on the entrance steps of the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday. The bells symbolically welcomed Jesus Christ on His joyous entry into Jersusalem six days before. He was to be crucified.

The next-to-last week of the Metropolitan Opera season will include the final repetition of the new Metropolitan production of "Parsifal." It will be presented on Friday evening, April 6. Martial Singher will sing the part of Amfortas for the first time in this production.

Borough President John Cashmore paid yesterday that Brooklyn industry had continued to grow in the last year despite attempts to lure concerns elsewhere.

It is more than twenty years since the Hull program for reducing tariffs by international agreement went into effect. WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP)--The Defense Department's research chief warned today that Russia was "closing the gap" on the United States in the race to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile and new jet bombers.
Aluminium, Ltd., big Canadian aluminum producer, last year had the highest production, sales and profits in its twenty-eightyear history, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

Charles W. Locke, the venerable crew coach at Middlesex School, was busy shoveling snow off the walks in front of his home in Concord, Mass., one morning last week. There was no school. The boys were on vacation.

The durability of the Christian gospel was emphasized yesterday by many Protestant clergymen in their Palm Sunday sermons.
Domestic cotton market prices last week closed firm after a mixed beginning early in the week. There were substantial net gains.

PENSACOLA, Fla., March 25 (AP)--A group of Negroes, angered by the shooting of a Negro, attacked and beat two white men today. Two men were hospitalized. Two others were arrested.

GENEVA, March 25--The Economic Commission for Europe has made an attempt to prod Western European Governments into frank consideration of their most vexing and politically touchy problem of economic policy: wages.

PITTSBURGH, March 25-- Steel output this month is expected to break all previous monthly records. There is more than an even chance that total production for the first time will come within an eyelash of 11,000,000 tons.

NO matter how much you like it, this is not the year to be lavish with olive oil, Never inexpensive, its price has skyrocketed in recent weeks. A pint of the oil, which sold for 93 cents last December, may be $1.20 or more now.

Directors of Trans World Airlines, Inc., elected several new officials and elevated others. Warren Lee Pierson, chairman, announced yesterday.
Cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 31 points ($1.55 a bale) off today. The far months were the weakest.

Mrs. Annette Wallach Labalme, wife of Dr. George Labalme, a retired surgeon, died yesterday at her home, 944 Fifth Avenue. She was 69 years old.

LONDON, March 26--Bertrand Russell accused the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation today of committing atrocities and of using a technique "made familiar in other police states such as Nazi Germany and Stalin's Russia."

LOS ANGELES, March 26 (AP) --Watson Jones, a former California State heavyweight champion, testified today that he participated in four "fixed" fights, three of them on instructions from Matchmaker Babe McCoy.

DETROIT, March 26 (AP)--The Rev. Dr. Edgar DeWitt Jones, minister emeritus of the Central Woodward Christian Church and a well-known Lincoln scholar, died today after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

LOS ANGELES, March 26-- Senator Estes Kefauver continued his stumping around Los Angeles today as Democratic organization leaders stepped up their fight on his bid to win the party's California Presidential primary.

The senior and junior wardens of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights, explained yesterday why they had changed from ardent supporters of the Rev. William Howard Melish in 1949 to bitter opponents in 1956.
Members of the Connecticut College Club of New York have selected the April 4 performance of "Time Limit!" at the Booth Theatre for their tenth annual theatre party.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 26 --There were 4,475 fans packed into arid around Holman Stadium today to root for the world champions, and the Dodgers didn't let them down.

American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., last year increased its net earnings from operations 74 per cent to $8.218,017 from $4,721,787 earned in 1954, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reported in the annual statement to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Senate prepared tonight to start its voting tests tomorrow on proposals to change the way of choosing Presidents and Vice Presidents. On the eve of the scheduled voting it appeared that the reformers had a rough row to hoe.

Jun Tsuchiya, Japanese Consul General here, and Mme. Tsuchiya of 49 East Seventy-second Street, honorary chairmen for the American premiere on April 23 of "Madame Butterfly," will be hosts at a meeting at their home on Thursday to formulate plans for the success of the event.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP)--The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal antiracketeering law applied to union featherbedding demands supported by threats and violence.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Some powerful organization Democrats believe their party is in a state of disarray requiring a re-examination of assumptions about the identity of the Presidential nominee.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 26--While the Giants were routing the Baltimore Orioles, 14--1, today, the apparent dearth of good fielding pitchers in the major leagues was brought home forcefully.
Nashua, the world's costliest horse, arrived by train from Florida yesterday. Last night he was bedded down in his old stall at the Aqueduct track.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26--Maury Paul, recording secretary of Local 47, American Federation of Musicians, was voted out of office today. It was the latest show of defiance by Hollywood musicians against the leaderships of James C. Petrillo, president of the federation.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the Smith Act convictions of two Communist leaders. It will hear the appeals of Junius Irving Scales, chairman of the Communist party of North Carolina, and Claude Mack Lightfoot, a party functionary in Chicago.
AN honest-to-goodness democrat, 64-year-old John A. Costello, Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, dislikes unnecessary ceremony and formalities.

The assembling of plots has been completed on the east and west sides of Nostrand Avenue, between Avenues R and S, in Brooklyn for improvement with apartment buildings. The propeity was assembled for the Nostrand Building Corporation, a subsidiary of Meyer Berfond, ...

Norman Thomas, veteran antiCommunist and six-time Socialist party candidate for President, has been raising funds to defend two Communists. His efforts so far, he said yesterday, have "sowed seed on very barren ground."
Everybody talks about the weather, but nobody as much as retailers do.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26--Motion-picture producers are showing renewed interest in the writings of Herman Melville.

APRIL showers have a habit, of course, of confining the young indoors. For eleven days, to be exact, if weather conditions over the last eighty-five years can be relied upon to repeat themselves during the month starting Sunday.
HONOLULU, March 26--The International Brotherhood of Teamsters quietly buried tonight its controversial plan to lend $400,000 to the International Longshoremen's Association.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 26--A President of Mexico met a Prime Minister of Canada officially tonight for the first in history. President Eisenhawer was "the good neighbor" who brought them together.
Three blood centers of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will be open today.

Mayor Wagner's flat rejection of any increase over $10,500,000 in new commitment for the salaries of the city's teachers in the next fiscal year turns future bargaining sessions between the Board of Education and the teachers into a futile pursuit.

An elusive midtown hotel fire killed a man early yesterday morning and caused nine firemen to suffer smoke poisoning. The dead man was Oscar Steigman, a 78-year-old resident of the hotel, the Tivoli, at 300 West Forty-second Street at Eighth Avenue.

The coming Grace Kelly-Prince Rainier wedding will be responsible, directly or indirectly, for considerable advertising although the Kelly family has served official warning against commercial exploitation of the event.
The United Nations has been dealing with the Palestine question almost continuously since April 2, 1947.

SARASOTA, Fla., March. 26 (AP)--A specialist today diagnosed Gene Conley's pitching arm trouble as "chronic tendonitis," but would not estimate how long the Milwaukee Braves righthander would be side-lined pending another examination Thursday.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Supreme Court agreed today to reopen the long-disputed question of how far Louisiana's boundary extends into the oilrich submerged lands of the Gulf of Mexico.

BOWIE, Md., March 26 (AP)-- C.V. Whitney's Head Man, idle since October, romped to a fourlength victory over seven other 3-year-olds today to show he must be regarded a serious contender for the Kentucky Derby.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Government has canceled the citizenship of Lauchlin B. Currie, former administrative assistant to President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The jet fighter is supplementing the Russian peasant as a major factor in Soviet military strength.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 26--Malaya's Chief Minister, Tengku Abdul Rahman, flew here today for a three-day state visit. He is expected to review the Thai-Malayan anti-Communist border agreement with Thai officials.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 26-- The Gulf Oil Corporation tonight signed a forty-year contract with the Bolivian Government for the exploration, development and transport of oil. The contract calls for an eventual investment of $40,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Spokesmen for airlines operating in Alaska told a Senate Commerce subcommittee today that Civil Aeronautics Board regulations had hampered their growth and the development of Alaska. They urged the subcommittee to approve legislation to give them permanent operating certificates for the routes they serve.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., March 26 (UP)--A twin-engine Navy plane patrol bomber exploded and crashed today during an attempted emergency landing on the Monongahela River, thirtyfive miles southeast of Pittsburgh. The three men reported aboard were believed killed.

Prime Minister John A. Costello of Ireland paid warm compliments to this country yesterday at a luncheon in his honor given by the City of New York. The gray-haired politician and lawyer from Dublin received many in kind.
The Citizens' Committee for Expanded Foreign Aid said yesterday that President, Eisenhower's recommendations on foreign aid were "far too limited in scope."
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --The Supreme Court today upheld a Securities and Exchange Commission order designed to safeguard investors in the reorganization of the General Stores Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- The right of the Secretary of Labor to prescribe a single uniform and nation-wide minimum wage for workers on Government contracts in the textile industry was upheld today by the Supreme Court.
CHICAGO, March 26--Adlai E. Stevenson will plunge into the Florida and California primaries with a revised set of tactics.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 26--A highly placed Government official said today that Pakistan would "shun any Soviet offer" of aid. The official, who insisted on anonymity, added, "Nobody wants aid from them and that is our policy."

Two young men in College Point, Queens, are sharpening their ice skates for the United States indoor championships to be held in the Flushing Meadow rink on Saturday and Sunday, April 7 and 8. One is a definite prospect for the 1960 Olympic Games. The other hopes to make those classic tests no later that 1968.
MANCHESTER, England, March 26--The British Govrernment was accused of "fatuous and ill-conceived" diplomacy here tonight at the country's first ...

A friend and former law associate of Municipal Court Justice Carson DeWitt Baker--the scofflaw jurist--had his driver's license revoked yesterday in Manhattan Traffic Court. In addition, he was committed to jail ...
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26--A sportsman is missing something in his Florida trip if he passes up a fishing or hunting spin with Woody Upthegrove and his airboats.

PARIS, March 26--France's negotiations with North Africa so far have been political. But experts here consider that the problems then a are basically economic and may soon exceed France's capacity to meet them.

The Coast Guard spoiled a good mystery story yesterday. It came up with a simple explanation of why a Russian freighter towing a trawler and a floating drydock called at Honolulu on St. Patrick's Day.
KIBBUTZ NAAN, Israel, March 26--A proposal was made here today to reconstruct the ancient fortress of Massada where the Roman legions in A. D. 73 broke the last Jewish resistance in Palestine.
"THE LONG WAY HOME," a factual story drama tized last night on "Robert Montgomery Presents" over Channel 4, was a memorable television achievement.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26--A fairly gloomy summation of prospects for Latin America was presented today by the United Nations Economic Commission for that area.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 --The press of Cairo and Da mascus have created a certain amount of mystery with reports that the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan has signed a new military agreement with Syria that amounts to joining the "neutralist" bloc dominated by Egypt.

TRENTON, March 27--The New Jersey Legislature voted early this morning to increase from 3 to 5 cents a pack the state tax on cigarettes. The money would be used to finance a program of state aid for school construction.
TRENTON, March 26--Legislation that would permit New Jersey life insurance companies to issue variable annuities on an individual and group basis was introduced today in the State Assembly.

WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Soviet Union proposed today to settle its naval lend-lease account with the United States by buying thirty-one ships and sinking seventy-nine said to be unseaworthy.

The Mercy, a former Navy hospital ship, is scheduled to enter a local shipyard this morning to be readied for duty as a training vessel for merchant marine cadets.
WASHINGTON March 26 (AP) --The Senate Internal Security subcommittee published today a volume of the private papers of the late Harry Dexter White.
Twenty-two fleet-footed dice players galloped right out of Flatbush Court yesterday and evaded detectives on hand to serve subpoenas.
NEW YORK is seen through the eyes of an interna tional artist in the exhibition of paintings by Meme von Winterhalder at the Chase Gallery, 21 East Sixty-third Street.

Mayor Wagner said no yesterday to teachers' requests for salary increases beyond those announced March 15. At that time he said the teachers would get $21,000,000 in rises, starting July 1.
The local law making permanent the use of stock car taxicabs on New York's streets was adopted by the City Council yesterday.

"TEN DAYS IN AUGUST," by Bernard Frizell, is a historical novel about the wild and astonishing liberation of Paris. The narrative unfolds in terms of a thriller that should move the sardonically sentimental heart of Alfred Hitchcock. No other single event in World War II inflamed the imagination of the West as much as the new birth of freedom in the City of Light.

Softening European copper prices and a forecast of a balance of supply and demand in this country drove copper stocks down in yesterday's market and brought a moderately lower close for the list as a whole.
CANNES, France, March 26 (AP)--Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif., and Budge Patty of Los Angeles set up an all-America men's final in the Cannes international tennis tournament today.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Senate Commerce Committee gave a sympathetic hearing today to a slashing attack on two keystones of network television operation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26--The Screen Actors Guild does not intend to give any ground to other unions with the introduction of electronic methods, including tape recording, for making motion pictures.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of the Immunity Act of 1954.
A study of long-term rapid transit needs based on the city's growth and changes that have occurred in the last several years was ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP)-- Dr. Jonas E. Salk, developer of a successful polio vaccine, headed a list of thirteen persons who received recognition awards last night from the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation.
WHITE PLAINS, March 26-- Improvements in railroad commutation service in Westchester will be sought by a County Transit Committee set up today.

ALBANY, March 27--Republicans are planning an intensive campaign this fall to win twothirds majorities in the Senate and Assembly. They are seeking the power to override any of Governor Harriman's vetoes.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., March 27--The Glen Cove Neighborhood House, which recently bought the indoor tennis courts and six acres of land from the George duPont Pratt estate ...

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's gross revenues rose 9.7 per cent last month to $12,457,604. But operating expenses rose even more sharply, and the company sustained a net loss of $1,236,253.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W, Va., March 27--Canada and Mexico accepted today a United States suggestion that they take the lead in helping newly freed countries develop democratic processes.

NEW ORLEANS, March 27 (AP)--The Louisiana Department of the American Legion leveled charges of Communist leanings at a Columbia University law professor today and objected to his speaking at Louisiana State University.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 27--President Anastasio Somoza, his son Luis, J. Addington Wagner, national commander of the American Legion, and Mrs. Wagner narrowly escaped drowning yesterday during a fishing trip.
"Little Glass Clock" will stop ticking after its eighth and final performance on Saturday night at the John Golden Theatre. None of its three predecessors has fared well this season.

CHICAGO, March 27--Gen. Robert E. Wood (retired) told a meeting of Sears, Roebuck Co. employes tonight that he will retire next month as chairman of the bord of trustees of their savings and profit sharing pension fund.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 27--The Bulgarians are tough, hard-working, frugal peasant folk with a sense of color and natural talent for music. But they are unlucky. Except for tiny Albania, their country was the last Balkan region liberated from the Ottoman Turks.

MONTREAL, March 27--The Canadiens of Montreal refused to "open the gates of mercy" even the merest trifle in their play-off game with the New York Rangers tonight. The Flying Frenchmen took after the Broadway Blues from the start, maintained a steady pressure on them, and battered them into submission by the score of 7 to 0.
MOSCOW, March 27--The recent Communist party Congress inaugurated a revolution in Soviet art and science no less farreaching than the political changes it has already brought.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27--The Western powers plan no major change in a resolution before the Security Council for a peace mission to the Middle East by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.
The city's schoolteachers criticized Mayor Wagner yesterday for "inadequate" salary increases. In addition, they warned that they would extend their boycott of extra-curricular activities.
Hermann H. Field, one of the four Fields who became involved in the Communist intrigue that brought death to top Communist politicians in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland, returned home yesterday.

In the new economic competition with Soviet Russia, the United States must combine increased aid and trade if it is to be victorious, George W. Wolf, president of the United States Steel Export Company, declared last night.
Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings for the preview of an exhibition of drawings by artists from all sections of the country, known as "Collectors' First Choice."

The East-West College AllStar squads began practice yesterday for the annual Fresh Air Fund basketball game to be played Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. The ten-man squads drilled at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- Conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives voted 8 to 2 today to restore rigid price supports at 90 per cent of parity.

MOSCOW, March 27--The Soviet press professes to see the American Presidential election with Marxist clarity. The alignment of political forces and the role of different leaders in the United States is being presented today to the Soviet citizen in the simplified terms to which he is accustomed.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 27 (AP)--Jonkheer Dr. F. Beelaerts van Blokland, one of the Netherlands' leading elder statesmen, died here early today of a heart attack. His age was 84.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 27--Big Don Newcombe stepped into his role as the Dodgers' No. 1 pitcher today and worked the first six innings against the Phils.

Pre-war German bonds payable in United States dollars were refused validation for the first time here yesterday by the intergovernmental agency that has been screening much securities since September, 1953.
The nation's surface transportation industry was invited yesterday by Senator Warren G. Magnuson to participate in Congressional efforts to restore full competition in national transportation.

The conference committee that has been seeking to reconcile the Senate and House versions of a farm bill voted yesterday to adopt two provisions (one from each of the two bills) that, if endorsed by the two houses, would seem to add up to a gratuitous invitation to a veto from the White House.

WHEN a teacher of cookery cooks the dinner for his own birthday party, what does he cook? Anyone interested in the table art would like to know, we think, and that is why, as one of ten guests at Paul Mayer's the other evening, we took copious notes.

CHICAGO, March 27--Grain futures reacted today to heavy profit-taking by longs following the recent sharp advances. Early in the day, new high prices for the season were established in all wheat futures and in May and July soybeans. Selling increased later.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) --The Department of Commerce said today the first two months of this year showed a tendency in most major industries for sales and production to level off.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 27--A blueprint for enforcing on an unparalleled scale the racial separation theories of South Africa's governing party was submitted today to Parliament in Capetown.
TRENTON, March 27--Gov. Robert B. Meyner made it clear today that he was not pleased with the approval by the Legislature of a 2-cent-a-pack increase in the tax on cigarettes.
MIAMI BEACH, March 27 (AP)--William H. Cane, 81-yearold head of the Yonkers Raceway and promoter of the famous Hambletonian race, died here today in St. Francis Hospital.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Leading play producers and concert managers have begun an intensive campaign for the exemption of live theatre, concert and ballet performances from the 10 per cent Federal admissions tax.

Copper stocks continued to decline sharply yesterday with softening prices abroad. Although oils and aircrafts attempted to push upward, the tone of the market remained heavy and The New York Times combined average fell 2.25 points to 339.04.

Colombia University is planning a $17,000,000 superblock on Morningside Heights as the site of a new east campus and three new buildings. These structures will house the School of Law, a Graduate Residence Hall and a Faculty Office Building.
Sermons on the first day of Passover yesterday emphasized freedom from servitude as indispensable to the survival of society.

The market for corporate and municipal bonds was weak yesterday, reflecting the continued pressure that the demand for capital is exerting on the money supply. Only Government securities resisted the price decline.
An article in this newspaper yesterday from Bogota, Colombia, written by our correspondent Tad Szulc, describes in measured terms the strict censorship that blights the Colombian press.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- The Labor Department gave the results today of its job survey of last year's women college graduates. Of those who took jobs, six out of ten went into teaching.
Mayor Wagner expressed yesterday his belief in New York City's "ability and determination" to develop further its waterfront.

An anti-Communist group called yesterday on the American University in Washington either to re-employ Prof. Herbert Fuchs or to "clarify" a decision suspending him without pay until his contract empires June 30.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 27 --Thomas de Hartmann of 23 East Sixty-ninth Street, New York, Russian pianist-composer, died last night at Princeton Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 70.
LONDON, March 27--The Soviet Union proposed today a disarmament plan whose emphasis rested almost entirely on EastWest cuts in military manpower and in conventional weapons.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27--Implacable opposition to communism will be a guiding principle of Ireland's, policy in the United Nations, Prime Minister John A. Costello said today.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- The Columbia Broadcasting System told the Senate Commerce Committee today that ultra high frequency television appeared to have a dim future except in a few "islands" where U. H. F. dominates the market.
Dr. Yang Yung-ching, formed president of Soochow University in China, died in Shanghai on March 6, according to word received-here yesterday. His age was 64.
It begins to look as if the Kremlin would have to wait at least another several months before chortling over the Second Great American Depression.

Fifty-eight business leaders yesterday endorsed President Eisenhower's recommendation that the United States join the proposed Organization for Trade Cooperation.

General liquidation dropped cocoa futures to new seasonal lows yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices were off almost the cent-a-pound limit in all positions during trading. Some selling by foreign interests was noted. There was switching out of the near-bys.
Apartment properties in upper East and West Side areas of Manhattan passed to new control in deals reported yesterday.
The leader of 15,000,000 organized American workers assailed yesterday unions that "amass great power" and "pile up great treasuries."
The Pepsi-Cola Company, achieved in 1955 the highest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report yesterday of Alfred N. Steele, chairman, and Herbert L. Barnet, president.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 28--The campaign to destroy the Stalin myth emerged in public view for the first time today. A long editorial in Pravda charged Stalin with flagrant misrule.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27-- Not all the twenty hits the Chicago Cubs collected against the Giants today could be attributed to the rough and, in spots, unplayable diamond. However, quite a few, like Harry Chiti's homer, carried authority in the Chicagoans' 13-10 decision over the New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Herbert Hoover Jr., Under Secretary of State, told a Senate subcommittee yesterday that "the Chinese Nationalists are shipping to the Communist Chinese quite a number of millions of dollars' worth of goods every year."

The Soviet Union is engaged in a successful campaign to induce, through guile or fear, the return of those who have sought a sanctuary in the free world. This was reported yesterday in a study made by the International Rescue Committee.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27--Yugoslavia's Defense Minister reaffirmed today his country's role of independence between East and West.
Herbert Kay has been named manager of catalyst development for the Climax Molybdenum Company.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27--Motion-picture rights to the stage success "Inherit the Wind" now belong to Stanley Kramer, The independent producer-director is associated with United Artists.

In the spring of 1955 Army carried out the great experiment of the year in college football. Now Michigan is reported to be preparing for what may prove to be the great experiment of 1956. Each case involves an end of all-America caliber.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- The Senate rejected today attempts to revise the Electoral College system by which Presidents and Vice Presidents are elected.

The New York Central Railroad won a costly victory yesterday in its fight to scuttle ferry service between Manhattan and Weehawken, N. J.

TULSA, Okla., March 27 (AP)-- The National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling tournament tonight crowned its first champion in 114.5-pound Dick Delgado. Wrestling for the Sooner Athletic Club of Norman. Okla., Delgado pinned Junior Corr, another Oklahoman, for his fourth straight fall.
DETROIT, March 27 (AP)--For the first time in its fifty-threeyear history, the Ford Motor Company is mailing a detailed annual report to stockholders.

ANDROS TOWN, Bahamas, March 27--There is some thing about an angler hunting bonefish that is similar to Jason's pursuit of the Golden Fleece, Galahad's ardent search for the Holy Grail or a country boy's wild lurch for a greased pig at the county fair.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- Eger V. Murphree, president of the Esso Research and Engineering Company, was appointed today as "czar" of guided missile production.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- The United States-CanadianMexican conference at White Sulphur Springs is important not because it is likely to decide anything but because it is apparently setting a new pattern of personal diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) --A former president of Western Washington College of Education, of Bellingham, Wash., was quoted today as having told two former students he wanted to see a "complete revolutionary change" in the United States form of government.
Operations of the Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, for 1955 were termed "most satisfactory" by Walter H. Sammis, president of both companies.

CAIRO, March 27--The British Embassy denied today that any protest to the Egyptian Government had been made or was being contemplated in connection with "hostile" broadcasts by the Egyptian state broadcasting system.
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP)-- The $15 price for hogs returned to the livestock market today. Both butchers and sows jumped 25 to 50 cents in active trading.

LOS ANGELES, March 27 (AP) --The Governor's committee investigating boxing in California today bumped into a determined rebuttal witness, who charged that Watson Jones, a fighter, had been threatened with jail unless he testified against matchmaker Babe McCoy of the Olympic Auditorium.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 --Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, said tonight that Moscow's anti-Stalinist campaign was running into "natural' opposition at home. But, given time, he said, the old "cult of personalty" would be broken.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Foreign countries spent more dollars in the United States for goods and services in the fourth quarter of last year than in any other quarter in history, the Commerce Department reported today.
