THE children's-wear departments of most local stores have been operating several decibels above their usual pitch during this busy pre-Easter season.

In the closing days of its recent session the New York Legislature passed a bill that would undermine a historic principle of school administration and damage the cause of education. This bill would amend Section 310 of the Education Law, and it should be vetoed.
TAMPA, Fla., March 27--Ten years ago Joe Nuxhall of the Cincinnati Redlegs formally retired from organized baseball to return to junior high school.

BOSTON, March 27 (AP)--Walter Byars unleashed a brutal attack for a fifth-round technical knockout over Bobby Murphy to retain the New England welterweight championship tonight at the arena. Referee Joe Zapustas stopped the bout at 2:23. Byars weighed 139 and Murphy 142 pounds.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 --The Matson Navigation Company is studying the question of developing luxury hotels in the South Pacific but has decided against building a hotel in San Francisco because it would not be economically feasible.

New York's children who need special help will benefit from the month-long exhibition of Gauguin's works that opens next Wednesday evening at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixtyfourth Street.

State Controller Arthur Levitt denied yesterday that he had given blanket approval to the purchasing practices of Suffolk County officials.

A rise in the cost of borrowing money to buy securities was announced yesterday by two leading banks. Guaranty Trust Company announced the increase effective on Friday. Chase Manhattan Bank will follow on Saturday.

LOS ANGELES, March 27-- Senator Estes Kefauver completed five days of intensive campaigning in the Los Angeles area tonight.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 27-- A mobile patrol of British security forces was ambushed tonight. Under fire of an automatic weapon, two members of the patrol were killed.
LONDON, March 27--Chancellor of the Exchequer Harrold Macmillan cautioned today that the Government's deflationary measures would be reinforced if they were slow in producing results.

LONDON, March 27--The Duke of Norfolk asked the British Government today for an assurance that it would tell the visiting Soviet leaders peace was impossible unless religious freedom was restored to the Communist countries.

The New York State Supreme Court yesterday dismissed a petition by the London Sporting Club and its president and matchmaker, Stephen (Tex) Sullivan, to set aside the New York State Athletic Commission's revocation of their licenses.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- The United States Information Agency, with its Voice of America, is projecting a new tour at sea in its drive to override Communist propaganda.

The dates for the season ahead were the main business of the spring meetings of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound and its junior affiliate at the New York Yacht Club yesterday.
LONDON, March 27--The jurisdictional strike that has held up construction work at Cammell Laird's shipyard in Birkenhead for more than six months was severely criticized today.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- A school aid program that for nearly six years has escaped the integration issue was off to a flying start toward renewal today.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- An author-editor accused the chairman of a House Appropriations subcommittee today of "badgering" the United States Information Agency into "destroying" her book because he "did not like" a Government program.

WASHINGTON, March 27--The Eisenhower Administration will send to Congress tomorrow a compromise three-point civil rights program. It is understood that Attorney General .... Herbert Brownell Jr. will ask Congress to authorize these things:
The Association of American Indian Affairs charged yesterday that the Department of Justice was trying to deprive Indians of their rightful claims against the United States.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27--President Eisenhower personally made the decision for new nuclear bomb tests in the South Pacific this spring.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (UP)--The Philadelphia Warriors trounced Syracuse tonight, 119-- 96, to gain a 2-1 edge in their best-of-five series with the Nats for the Eastern Division play-off crown in the National Basketball Association.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27--Casey Stengel has enjoyed his share of pleasant surprises this spring. But the one he received last week, after he had put Tommy Carroll at third base for a few games, heads the list.

EGER VAUGHAN MURPHREE, the Secretary of Defense's new Special Assistant for Guided Missiles, is a tall, quietly spoken chemical engineer.
The State of Delaware raised $10,752,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements by the sale of issues of serial bonds maturing from 1957 to 1976.

TORONTO, March 27 (UP)-- The Toronto Maple Leafs staved off elimination in the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight when Goalie Harry Lumley shut out the Detroit Red Wings, 2-0, in the fourth game of their semi-final series.

ALBANY, March 27--State Controller Arthur Levitt announced today that his department would begin next month making a public record of the fees paid by school districts to architects, engineers and attorneys in connection with building programs.
The National Broadcasting Company's decision to sell radio time to religious groups has stimulated immediate response among some organizations that have long used the medium on a paid-time basis.

GENEVA, March 27--The International wheat conference adjourned here tonight until April 16. No final agreement was reached on prices or quantities of wheat to be covered by an international wheat accord. But it was confidently expected by conference leaders that an agreement would be reached when the conference resumed in London on April 16.

Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, has examined the 1955 enrollment figures and found reasons for optimism. The percentage of Democratic enrolled voters to the total is the highest in ten years, his analysis shows.
Of all the "cultural propaganda" successes the United States has made abroad in recent years among the most striking was the Far Eastern tour early last summer of the Symphony of the Air.

Two women were critically injured when the ceiling of a Bronx synagogue collapsed yesterday during services on the first full day of Passover.
Two women were killed last night in one of two Bronx fires that the police believe were set by angry husbands.

Eight persons were charged yesterday in what United States Attorney Paul W. Williams said were the first indictments in the Government's investigation of racketeering in the garment and trucking industries.

An apartment building accommodating twenty-six families at 1700 Hudson Boulevard in Jersey City, N.J., has changed ownership in a stock-sale transaction. The property was acquired by the M. R. W. Company ...

In an effort to keep patrons at the race track until each eightrace program ends, the Greater New York Association Inc. decided yesterday to make the seventh race, instead of the sixth, the daily feature.

MOST mothers like traditional clothes for their children, Best's Liliputian Bazaar has discovered. Even the woman who will choose extreme fashions for herself is far more conservative when it comes to dressing her offspring.

NEWARK, March 27 (AP)--An agitated parolee today pushed his way into a house and held a family at pistol point around the breakfast table for forty-five minutes before he was trapped in a hotel vestibule and subdued by the police.
HONOLULU, March 27--Dave Beck asserted today that New York's bitterly contested truck union election had beef "100 per cent honestly conducted."
Renovated and rededicated, Haarlem House, 311 East 116th Street, yesterday took a new name, La Guardia Memorial House.
The break-up (net asset) value of the Alleghany Corporation's 4,647,725 shares of common stock stood at $13.89 a share at the 1955 year-end, up from $7.21 a share twelve months earlier.

Because the lives of many of his friends and colleagues in the literary world "ended in the tragedy of alcoholism," Upton Sinclair has embarked on a new crusade. In "The Cup of Fury," he describes the effect "social drinking" played in the lives of members of his family and such intimates as Jeck London, Sinclair ...
WASHINGTON, March 27-- Chances are "better than even" that business activity this year will top last year's record levels, Sinclair Weeks said today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 6 to 13 points yesterday.

The upward trend in sales and earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the first quarter of its fiscal year continued in the fourth month, it was reported yesterday. The company's fiscal year will end next Oct. 3.
THE Bach Choir of Bethlehem, Pa., which has been performing Bach's B minor Mass regularly since 1900 in its home town, came to Carnegie Halt last night, bringing with it this towering masterpiece.
Internal Revenue agents seized the premises of the Communist party and The Daily Worker here and elsewhere in the country yesterday because of nonpayment of income taxes.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 28--A bomb threat with an antiNegro theme resulted tonight in the evacuation of students from the Adelphi College campus, classroom buildings and dormitories.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28--Twentieth Century-Fox added two more story properties to its prospective filming schedule today. Its first acquisition was "Harry Black," a new novel by David Walker, dealing with the adventures of a professional tiger hunter in India.
The teacher boycott of extracurricular activities has drastically curtailed after-school student programs in most of the city high schools.

The chance reading of a newspaper in a hospital in Germany in 1954 resulted yesterday in a reunion between a Ukrainian father and son who had believed each other dead since the German invasion of Russia.

BASLE, Switzerland, March 28 (AP)--The management of Interhandel, huge holding company, won stockholders' approval today of its efforts to force the return of its majority interest in the General Aniline and Film Corporation.
LONDON, March 28--The Soviet Union has agreed in principle to an international system of aerial reconnaissance as part of its latest disarmament proposals.
The State Department's cancellation of a Near East cultural tour by a Symphony of the Air presents a threat to a series of proposed radio concerts by the orchestra.
The Kremlin, which rewrites history for its own purposes, apparently has learned from history.
Prayers for "deliverance from the evils of race prejudice" were offered in a number of communities across the country yesterday.
LONDON, March 28--OutSpoken criticism of its leader's past subservience to Stalinism has raised the question of the future leadership of the British Communist party.

CHICAGO, March 28--Sears, Roebuck Co.'s net sales in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, rose above the 3-billion-dollar mark for the first time to set a new high of $3,306,826,181, the company disclosed in its annual report made public today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) --The Democratic majority on a House Investigations subcommittee today accused Administration officials of "a determined effort to sabotabe and wreck the Federal power program."
Excavating shovels are ready to start working at the Roosevelt and Yonkers harness tracks as soon as Governor Harriman signs the bill authorizing new construction at the tracks.
Passover sermons in temples and synagogues here yesterday dwelt on freedom and adherence to democratic principles.
SINCE Gerhart Hauptmann was a formulative dramatist sixty and seventy years ago and also a Nobel Prize winner in 1912, it is interesting to have a look at one of his plays today.

Eight undergraduates of the University of Connecticut appeared at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to watch while their purchases of fourteen shares of Greyhound and six shares of Union Tank Car-- worth altogether about $400-- were recorded on the ticker tape.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 28-- Pari-mutuel ticket sellers and cashiers tonight rejected a contract offered by the management of Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I.
LOS ANGELES, March 28 (UP) --Two former boxers testified today about alleged fixes that failed to take place.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28--Egypt and Syria asked today for assurances that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold would limit his proposed mission to the Middle East to obtaining compliance with the Israeli-Arab armistice agreements.
ANDROS TOWN, Bahamas, March 28--Five young men have turned up here with the world obviously in their clutch. They were also clutching aqualungs, underwater spearguns and other odd equipment.
MOSCOW, March 28--There are indications that the once imposing edifice of Stalinism is to be dismantled gradually.

The Benevolence Fund of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Fellowship will be augmented by the proceeds from a tea to be held on the afternoon of April 6 in the Della Robbia Room of the Manger Vanderbilt Hotel. Mrs. Claude Douthit will act as hostess at the tea.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- A two-price system for wheat that would yield farmers 100 per cent of parity on about half their crop will stay in the farm bill. The measure is being worked out by conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives.

The spring's out-of-season snow can't last forever. A day will come when the thermometer will go up, buds will bloom and skippers, their mates and their small fry will think of a season of pleasure boating.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) --The Senate approved today the nominations of three Ambassadors, two members of the Eubversive Activities Control Board a number of judges and others officials.

THE Bennington Composers Conference presented a program of contemporary works last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. All of the music was heard for the first time in New York.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 28--The special Inter-American Conference on Resources of Marginal Seas closed today.
In an attempt to overcome its stamp-dispensing problems, the New York post office has hired a new stainless steel employe.
FOR a man who touched off bitter cries of "political persecution," Donald R. Moysey displays surprisingly little interest in ideological, matters.
HAVING run out of persons from the free world to brainwash, the Communists are now busily rinsing the idea that Stalin was a dandy fellow out of the minds of their own people.
The Temporary State Commission on the Courts was severely criticized yesterday for failing to recommend reforms in the selection of judges.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28 (AP)--Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said tonight that efforts had been made in Minnesota and California to organize Adlai E. Stevenson's support "in such an overwhelming show of power that I would be frozen or frightened out" of the Presidential primaries.
WASHINGTON, March 28--A surprised Washington was becoming convinced today that the decision to seize Communist party assets for tax reasons was made without clearance from officials here.

IF the color of Bonnard were multiplied in intensity, and the brush forms magnified, one would have an approximate simile for the abstractions by Charles Cajori at the Tanager Gallery, 90 East Tenth Street.
Opponents of fluoridation of the city's water were described as "fuzzy-minded nitwits" yesterday by a pioneer public-health physician.
THE Easter bunny came to town on an unofficial visit earlier this week, and left behind the finest blooming egg tree this city has ever seen.
VIENNA, March 28--Dr. Burghard Breitner, well-known surgeon, author and former Austrian Presidential candidate, died last night at his home in Innsbruck. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- President Eisenhower has scheduled a conference tomorrow with Clarence A. Davis, Under Secretary of the Interior. The appointment was made amid mounting reports that Mr. Davis would be appointed to succeed Secretary Douglas McKay.

There does not seem to be much doubt that the Internal Revenue Service District Director for Lower Manhattan had cause to take some action under the tax laws in the case of the Communist party and its organ, The Daily Worker.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 28 --Anti-Western circles have succeeded in creating serious doubts all through the Middle East about the motives of the United States proposal that Dag Hammarskjold, as Secretary General of the United Nations, visit this area and seek to reduce tension over the Palestine question.

The Juilliard School of Music presented its Josef Lhevinne Scholarship Concert last night. An outstanding feature of the event was the playing of William Primrose, violist, in Hindemith's Sonata for Viola and Piano.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- The United States has completed stockpiling half of the seventyfour critical materials it will need in the event of an emergency, the Office of Defense Mobilization said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, March 29--The bustling midtown section of this city, crowded with theatregoers and shoppers, was rocked last night by an explosion. One person was killed, two were missing and scores injured.
A national appeal is being organized to raise $595,000 for the restoration and development of the birthplace of Woodrow Wilson in Staunton, Va.
"Mister Johnson," a play by Norman Rosten based on the novel by Joyce Cary, opens at the Martin Beck Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, March 28--A significant test of the efforts of the Democratic Congressional leadership to avoid pre-convention party splits in the South is developing in Texas.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 28 (AP)--Gemerald, a 4-1 shot, gained a front-running victory in the $13,200 Singing Tower Stakes as Dale's Delight, a previously unbeaten filly and the 2-to-5 favorite, finished fourth at Gulfstream Park today.

The five-story remodeled store and apartment building at 1296 Third Avenue has been sold by Max Bregman to an investing client of Rossbach Associates. The property occupies a plot 25 by 100 feet in the block between Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth Streets.

LOS ANGELES, March 28-- Adlai E. Stevenson flew into California tonight in a hastily organized move to stem Senator Estes Kefauver's accelerating progress toward the Democratic Presidential nomination.
Thomas J. Curran, leader of the New York County Republican organization, announced yesterday the party's designations for most of the candidates to be nominated in the primary on June 5.

GINNY is a real doll. Really a real doll. Eight inches high, she is the product, pride and joy of Mrs. Jennie Graves of Medford, Mass. Mrs. Graves estimates that her concern has sold 5,000,000 such dolls in the last eight years.
HONOLULU, March 28--Dave Beck has what amounts to a blank check from the high command of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to clean up corruption in the nation's most powerful union.
TULSA, Okla., March 28 (AP)-- Pete Blair of the United States Navy and an Oklahoma college student, Danny Hodge, gained Amateur Athletic Union national free-style wrestling championships tonight.

Commodity futures prices were generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, rubber, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, copper and zinc rose; cocoa and burlap declined, and price movements for sugar and wool were mixed.
The finances of The Daily Worker, the Communist newspaper in trouble with the tax authorities, are as mysterious as those of some of the multimillionaires it baits.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa had some good news yesterday for the city's real-estate taxpayers.

CHICAGO, March 28 (UP)--A late March storm dumped almost a foot of snow in the upper Midwest today. Meanwhile, a dust storm in the Southwest caused an estimated total of $1,000,000 in damages to crops.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York asked its consumers yesterday to join in urging Governor Harriman to veto a bill that is awaiting his signature.
LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., March 28--The first shock over the publication of criticism of Stalin appears to be over in this region.
Wanderley Da Cunha Camargo, a 20-year-old Brazilian, seems determined to come to the United States as often as he can.

THE New York City Opera Company carries on at the City Center. Economic stringencies have caused it to cut down, but it is presenting a spring season. The three-week term opened last night with Sir William Walton's "Troilus and Cressida," the work that it introduced to New York last fall.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 28--There's a steely glint to his blue eyes and a pugnacious jut to his jaw. Even Billy Klaus' straight; sandy hair rebels at the ministrations of a comb and hangs defiantly over his forehead, completing the impression of a Dead End Kid.
Mayor Wagner will attempt today to end the impasse on teachers' salaries.

Directors of the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday formally approved plans for the bank's sixty-story skyscraper. The building is scheduled for completion in three years and the surrounding plaza should be finished two years later, David Rockefeller, executive vice president, said.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 28--Robert W. Allan, New York Regional Administrator of the General Services Administration, the Federal Government's housekeeping agency, died yesterday in Hackensack Hospital after a short illness.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, March 28--Parliament called today for the withdrawal of United States troops from Iceland This came in the wake of a Government split over the station ing of foreign troops in the country, which was a founder member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28--Chuck Dressen, who could easily pass as the world's outstanding optimist, gave an unqualified opinion today that his Senators were going to be a vastly improved ball club this year.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) --Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today announced the indictment of eight corporations and four individuals on charges of collusive bidding for Government surplus cotton.
The United States Treasury Department's surprise raids and income tax claims on the Communist party and The Daily Worker appeared last night to be headed for court adjudication.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) --The Senate Internal Security subcommittee said that Harry Herman Kaplan, New York real estate man, invoked the Fifth Amendment today when asked if his passport was held by a Soviet agent.

BERLIN, March 28--Premier Otto Grotewohl charged the judicial organs of the East German Government today with abuse of the laws.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- Congress was advised today that it was urgently necessary that the United States dispense its foreign aid without regard for getting the credit for it.
The "experiment in personal diplomacy" which ended at White Sulphur Springs yesterday morning appears to have been successful.

LONDON, March 28--Britain's gross national product, or the money value of the goods and services produced in this country plus net income from investments abroad, amounted last year to 16,634,000 ($46,575,200,000). That is nearly 5 per cent more than in 1954.
APRIL showers may dim the bright day that Easter should be. But you can count on tables inside the house to sing out the song of spring.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 (AP)--Willie Jones of the Philadelphia Phillies charged today that Don Newcombe "deliberately" threw at him yesterday when the third baseman was hit in the head by a ball pitched by the Brooklyn Dodger.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 28 (AP)--The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a surprise countermove, today sought to remove to Federal court a state suit. The suit seeks to dissolve the organization in Louisiana.

LONDON, March 28--A threeman committee, appointed by the Government to inquire into the walkout of 500 joiners at Cammell Laird's Birkinhead shipyard, found unanimously today that it was wholly unjustified.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- Herbert Hoover Jr. will face Congressional requests tomorrow for an explanation of his statement that Nationalist China was shipping to Communist China "quite a number of millions of dollars' worth of goods every year."
The Government's investigation of racketeering in the food industry has been hampered by reluctant and lying witnesses, an Assistant United States Attorney said yesterday.
The police saturation technique to improve mid-city traffic flow was extended yesterday for a second thirty-day period.

After losing a little ground in the morning, stocks rallied late yesterday under the leadership of the oils and closed higher than Tuesday's level. In the upward movement of the last two hours steels, motors, rails and several specialties were outstanding.

The Guild Chapter of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will hold its annual bridge, fashion show and tea next Thursday afternoon at the Parish House, 2 East Ninetieth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- President Eisenhower was in high spirits today as he ended his meeting with the President of Mexico and the Prime Minister of Canada at the Greenbrier Hotel in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. He returned here after the close of the three-day conference.

The Government saved $1,000,000 last year by making more adept handy men of the maintenance workers in public housing projects. Herman D. Hillman, regional director of the Public Housing Administration, made this estimate yesterday at a meeting of Federal, state and city housing officials from the New England and Middle Atlantic states.
PRINCESS RAGNHILD COAST, Antarctica, March 26-- The Stars and Stripes flew tonight at two remote points along the coast of Queen Maud Land as the U.S.S. Glacier continued her exploring mission.
American exporters were urged yesterday to increase participation in international trade fairs as a means of promoting business and combatting Soviet propaganda.

WASHINGTON, March 28--A Securities and Exchange Commission hearing on Alleghany Corporation preferred stock broke down into a shouting match today and little progress was made toward settling the stock's future.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 28 --The Pirates, who do well in the Grapefruit League, put the Dodgers in their place today at Terry Field.
PHRENAROS, Cyprus, March 28--British troopers searched this village of 1,200 persons today for contraband arms.
Two Americans have undertaken a project that some day may restore the fertility and prosperity of an ancient province of the ruined Persian Empire.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- After two days together at a Nest Virginia resort, President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles held an extraordinary two-hour meeting at the White House today. What they talked about was anyone's guess.
NEWARK, March 28--The Public Utilities Commission completed hearings today on the application of the New York Central Railroad to reduce service on its West Shore Division.
A split developed yesterday in the high command of the united labor movement over the question of India and communism.

A citizens' planning group representing eleven north Bergen County communities recommended yesterday that the proposed twelve-mile extension of the New Jersey Turnpike follow a so-called Hackensack River route.

MONTREAL, March 28 (UP) --Aviation experts will meet in Ciudad Trujillo next week to find ways of coping with an aviation boom in the Caribbean. The conference, which will start April 3, was called by the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations specialized agency.
BONN, Germany, March 28-- A new Beethoven Hall, on an eight-acre plot a few blocks from the birthplace of the composer, is rising here on the banks of the Rhine.
Tampering with "yellow sheet" criminal records, used by justices in determining a prisoner's sentence, has been under investigation by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the Police Department.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- Congress approved by voice votes today a Senate-House conference report on the $760,000,000 Upper Colorado Project bill. The measure now goes to the White House for the President's signature.
Henry C. McDermott, district manager in Jacksonville, Fla., for the tire division of the United States Rubber Company, died yesterday in Shreveport, La. His age was 64.
PARIS, March 28--Gen. Henri Navarre, former commander of French forces in Indochina, testified today that military information had been withheld from Paris to prevent leaks to the Communist enemy.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 28--The least talked about second baseman with the Giants in spring training owns the most batting percentage points on the squad. That would be Wayne Terwilliger, more familiarly known as The Twig.

A new book by Henry Wei, author of several studies on international law and economic relations, has been scheduled for April 19 publication by Van Nostrand. Called "China and Soviet Russia," it presents the diplomatic moves, "now friendly, now hostile and always rooted in suspicion," of the two great revolutionary powers of modern Eurasia.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 28--Soviet authorities have given Premier Tage Erlander permission to visit Soviet Georgia, including Tiflis, the scene of recent student demonstrations against the government.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 28--Dutch tactics that have followed recent remarks by Secretary of State Dulles in Indonesia are viewed with alarm in Indo nesian and United States circles here.

"RIGOLETTO" was presented yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera, with Clifford Harvuot singing the title role for the first time there. The event was a special student matinee presented under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.
WASHINGTON, March 28--A Congressional panel reported today that this country was wasting 80 per cent of its potential scientific and engineering manpower.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 20--Racial partnership, the basic idea of the Central African Federation, is receiving a practical application in the establishment of an interracial university here.
Caution is the watchword in Detroit as the traditionally heavy selling season for automobiles draws near.
The first ship to return to New York from the recent. Antarctic expedition docked in Brooklyn yesterday. Some of the crew said they felt colder here than they had in Little America.

Churches will observe Maundy Thursday today and Good Friday tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 28--Permanent headquarters for the United States Mission to the United Nations will be erected at the southwest corner of First Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, it was announced today. The site is now occupied by an automobile parking service.

A syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Eastman, Dillon Co., Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Lehman Brothers will offer for public subscription today a new issue of $50,000,000 of thirty-year 3 per cent debentures of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company. The securities are priced at 100.

Ben Hogan is returning to golf's major tournament trail. Although the Texan stated he was "through" last June, he acknowledged yesterday that present plans would bring him once again into international competition.

Recollections of the Wayside Inn when the late Henry Ford was its landlord were related here yesterday by John W. Burke, 65 years old. Mr. Burke is retiring after forty-two years as the Ford family chauffeur in New York.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation, which operates a chain of twentyseven hotels, set new records for revenues and earnings in 1955, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today.

A twenty-eight-acre tract in Westbury, L.I., has been purchased by Jimmy Maccarone and Abraham Shames for development as an industrial park. The property, on the southeasterly side of Brush Hollow Road, was acquired by Brush Hollow Road Associates through Max Gruber Associates as brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- Two meat unions have agreed on the first merger to take place since the united labor movement was founded last December.
CHICAGO, March 28--Leopold D. Silberstein, financier and collector of companies, moved into the arena of high drama today.
A TECHNICALLY brilliant re-enactment of the last hours of the Titanic was presented last night on the "Kraft Television Theatre" over Channel 4.

Directors of the Gillette Company yesterday elected Carl J. Gilbert as president to succeed J.P. Spang Jr., who becomes chairman of the board to fill the vacancy created by the retirement of William A. Barron Jr. Mr. Gilbert joined Gillette in 1948 as treasurer and two years later became vice president. Mr. Spang, formerly vice president of Swift Co., became president of Gillette in 1938.

FOR Alan Davie, a young British painter who is hav ing his first American exhibition at the Catherine Viviano Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, an artist is still a prophet of the magical and marvelous.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--In one of his more whimsical moments a year ago Birdie Tebbetts offered the sugges tion that baseball also should have a secondary Hall of Fame.

TUCSON, Ariz., March. 29-- Those who saw Willie Mays of the Giants rob Vic Wertz of the Indians with a spectacular running catch in the first games of the 1954 world series should have seen what the Say Hey Kid did to the same man today.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Two-price plans for wheat and rice were approved today by a Senate-House conference committee on the farm bill.

Jazzed up sales are sounding a happy note for makers of musical instruments.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The State Department is considering a Soviet proposal for the exchange of what the Russians call "energetics" delegations.

GENEVA, March 29--According to a survey, the poor countries of southern Europe need at least $2,000,000,000 in outside capital in the next-five years to carry out reasonable programs of economic development.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 29--The Czechoslovak Communist party is going about the downgrading of Stalin in its own cautious way.

A Canadian polio victim who didn't learn to walk until he was 16 years old clambered aboard a bicycle at the age of 20 and pedaled bravely into a new world. Now 27 years old, he is in New York after having completed a 30,400-mile tour of Canada and every section of the United States.

When William Britten goes back to teaching school he should have little trouble putting schoolroom clowns in their place. As of yesterday he is a full-fledged professional clown in the big league of the field: the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.
A quiet struggle between two city departments over a major policy came out into the open yesterday.
Public offerings of new securities here in March showed a marked contraction. Stock flotations were the smallest for a March since 1949.

CANNED ham seems an excellent choice for the Easter table. It is ready to serve, which should ingratiate it with busy cooks. And on a cost-per-serving basis, it is comparatively reasonable.

WASHINGTON, March 29--The strategy worked out for Adlai E. Stevenson to assure his renomination for President by the Democratic party was a thing of beauty --while it lasted. He would be obliged to enter certain preference primaries, an activity he had hoped to dispense with.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- United States officials were hopeful today that continued American use of the Keflavik air base in Iceland could be arranged.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Herbert Hoover Jr. said today that he was all wrong when he told Congress there was a multimillion-dollar trade from Nationalist China to the Communist mainland.
The eighty-five-year-old Tavern-on-the-Green, Central Park at West Sixty-seventh Street, opened as a renovated establishment last night.
The Communist party and The Daily Worker probably will regain their padlocked premises and the use of their battered office equipment early next week.
ALBANY, March 29--Lieut. Gov. George B. DeLuca, the "invisible man" of the Harriman Administration, had his moment in the spotlight today.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The International Cooperation Administration was accused today of bungling technical assistance operations in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- President Eisenhower today accepted, effective April 15, the resignation of Douglas McKay as Secretary of the Interior so he could seek the Republican nomination for Senator from Oregon.

MANILA, March 29--President Ramon Magsaysay's Administration took official notice today of the campaign in the Philippines Congress and a section of the press against United States policy in the Philippines.
The American National Theatre and Academy's Greater New York Chapter is developing its own thrift shop project, which will he housed in the SpenceChapin Corner Shop at 1065 Lexington Avenue.
Cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Closing prices were 4 points (20 cents a bale) higher to 12 points (60 cents a bale) lower than on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- February sales by manufacturers were maintained at about the same rate as in other recent months, the Government said today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 29--The official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist League hailed tonight the rehabilitation of Laszlo Rajk, executed Hungarian Foreign Minister, as a reversal of the verdict of the "most monstrous trial ever held in the world."
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 29 --The Iberia, a Peninsula and Orient liner carrying 1,250 passengers from Britain to Australia, crawled into Colombo today after colliding with an oil tanker.

TRENTON, March 29--Senator Estes Kefauver will arrirve in New Jersey on April 6 to begin five days of campaigning. There was some doubt tonight, however, as to whether he would meet with Gov. Robert E. Meyner.
Along with the parade "on the Avenue," there will be smaller parades for worthy causes on Easter Sunday. Even pets of paraders will participate.

The United States does not always win its battles in U.N. debates. In the membership dickering of last December we got some of our friends into the organization, but were unable to include our former enemy and present friend-- Japan.
CHICAGO, March 29. (AP)--An official of the American Cancer Society said today there was growing belief that a chemical agent might some day be found that would cure all types of cancer.

Postponement of the trial of seven Communists accused of violating the Smith Act will be sought today, a party spokesman said last night. The plea will be made on the ground that Federal seizure of party assets had prejudiced their case.
The rise of Egypt to a position of primary importance in the Middle East today is one of the most dramatic and--in the circumstances-- most disturbing developments of post-war history.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 29-- The advisability of an islandwide curfew next Sunday similar to last Sunday's was being considered today by the British authorities.

WASHINGTON, March 30--A Republican charged today that the Democratic leadership of the House had provided a job for John Maragon, convicted "fivepercenter" of the Truman Administration, by discharging a disabled war veteran.
A long-time laggard among railroad stocks became a leader yesterday as the result of a few written words.
In a time of record-breaking prosperity more American families than ever before are seeking the help of family service agencies across the country.

DEEP PARK, L.I., March 29 --Labor difficulties at the engine division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation have occurred again two weeks after a new contract was signed. The results of three days of turmoil show:
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Government's top housing official opened war today on red tape in the slum clearance and urban renewal field.
Mayor Wagner's executive budget for 1956-57 will include $7,300,000 for extension of the forty-hour week to the 53,000 city employes still on a forty-two-hour schedule.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 29 (AP)--The end of a business that once owned 14,000,000 acres of land was announced today by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway.

QUITO, Ecuador, March 29-- The President of Ecuador has charged that conditions attached by the United States to economic aid in Latin America could create resentment and "sometimes hurt the national pride" of the recipient nations.
TRENTON, March 29--Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed three bills today that will increase the cigarette tax by 2 cents and provide state aid for school con struction.

A former collaborator of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo said here yesterday he believed Dr. Jesus de Galindez, Columbia University faculty member, had been kidnapped and murdered by agents of the Dominican Republic's dictator.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 29 (AP)--The Milwaukee Braves received encouraging news today when an orthopedic surgeon said that Gene Conley's ailing shoulder showed "definite improvement."
BNOT YAAKOV BRIDGE, on Israeli-Syrian border, March 29 --Israel and Syria exchanged prisoners today with the curt formality of nations already at war.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Federal mediators are finding labor-management disputes more complex and difficult settle.

Loans to business on the books of leading New York City banks declined only $23,000,000--far less than had been expetted--in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Authorities agreed yesterday that there would be no lapse in insurance protection for any taxicab passengers, drivers or equipment between April 1 and April 9.
An end to the teacher salary issue appeared in sight yesterday.

An open plaza with a sunken pool will occupy 70 per cent of the site of the Chase Manhattan Bank's new main office structure in the financial district. This is shown in a scale model of the project that goes on public display today at the bank's present quarters at 40 Wall Street.
The primary concern of a newly created special Federal rackets grand jury will be an investigation of seven recently chartered teamster locals and their officers.
For the first time in centuries, Roman Catholic churches over the world observed yesterday major alterations in the solemn liturgy for Holy Thursday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29--Mario Lanza has signed with Warner Brothers for a second film to be directed by Anthony Mann.
HUNGARY'S pudgy political leader likes to tell his own success story by referring to the salami.

Sales of the materials handling industry, which has seen its volume climb seven times higher than pre-war levels, will grow by an additional 50 per cent in the next five years, Elmer F. Twyman, vice president of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, predicted yesterday.
A threat of a primary fight between backers of Adlai E. Stevenson and Carmine G. Do Sapio in the Tammany leader's own Congressional district has been dissolved.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--The Dodger-Yankee world series exhibit came to Al 'Lang Field today. It drew the second largest crowd in the history of the park--a gathering of 8,468--and continued to stick to last October's script.

Thanks to a burst of strength by the rails, led by Pennsylvania Railroad, the stock market yesterday closed the week with a net gain. The New York Times combined average climbed to new historic high of 344.40 and closed at 340.91, up 1.27 on the day and 1.19 on the week.

PARIS, March 29--Europe's purchases of goods from the United States and Canada have increased greatly in the last two years. This is due to the reduction of import quotas on goods from dollar areas and to an expansion of the European economy.

ANDROS TOWN, Bahamas, March 29--Although bonefish are the almost obsessive interest of anglers who come regularly to this subtropical island of sport and ease, big deep-water fish are pursued steadily and with a special atmosphere of adventure.

SOMEONE once said (I think I have said it myself) that the two most popular themes for fiction are reworkings of the stories of Cinderella and Jack the Giant Killer. But I spoke without taking adequate thought. Obviously, an equally popular literary theme since the composition of the Iliad is adultery and the surprising complications it can cause.
HANOVER, N.H., March 29-- Dr. William K. Wright, Stone Professor Emeritus of Intellectual and Moral. Philosophy at Dartmouth College, died today at the age of 78.
MOSCOW, March 29--All Moscow newspapers reprinted in full today Pravda's 7,000-word attack on Stalin published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Dr. Earl Vincent Moore, dean of the School of Music at the University of Michigan was appointed today to the advisory committee of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress.
LONDON, March 28--Hungary is seeking the classification A-1 at Lloyd's for two tugs she is building for Yugoslavia.

VIENNA, March 29--The name of Laszlo Rajk, Hungarian Foreign Minister who was executed on charges of high treason and Titoism in September, 1949, has been cleared. The same thing has been done for his associates who died with him.
LONDON, March 29--The sixmonth-old strike of 500 joiners at Cammell Laird's shipyard at Birkenhead is to end Tuesday.

BOWIE, Md., March 29 (AP)-- Coburn's Wish gained his third consecutive score of the Bowie meeting today in the $4,000 Overbrook Purse before the smallest crowd of the session. Rain held the attendance to 8,789.
ROME, March 29--Devastating criticisms of the Soviet and Italian Communist parties' leadership were heard here yesterday at a meeting of Communist senators.
THE woman who bustles down to buy her annual spring silk has a surprise coming.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings tonight swept into their fourteenth Stanley Cup final by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3--1, in the fifth game of their bestof-seven semi-final series.
The Transit Authority dropped the proposed 40-cent combination fare on the new Rockaway line to 30 cents yesterday. The facility will begin operating on June 28.
ALTHOUGH "Mister Johnson," which opened at the Martin Beck last evening, has come out of a novel, it has not gotten all the way into the theatre.
THE telephone rang in the Meyrowitz optical shop in Madison Avenue at Eightysixth Street a few weeks ago.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 29 (AP)--Gene Littler clipped par by six shots today with a 32, 34--66 to take a one-stroke lead over three rivals in the first round of the $12,500 Azalea open golf tournament.

A bill that would encourage the return of the middle man, selling submetered electric power to tenants in commercial and business buildings, passed the Legislature and is awaiting, we hope, a resounding veto by Governor. Harriman.
Every winter operators of ski areas talk hopefully of a season that will last through Easter. Usually most of them are disappointed.
All television networks will present Easter services on Sunday from various churches. The radio networks have scheduled sunrise services at points throughout the country.
AN adaptation of Rumer Godden's novel "An Episode of Sparrows" was televised to good effect on Channel 2 last night on "Climax!"
Eugene T. Singer of Green Pond, N.J., former senior vice president and director of the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company, died Wednesday in St. Petersburg, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29 --Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization and the Baghdad Pact had tended to "encircle" India.
For three years an invitation court tennis tournament has been held, with representatives of Yale, Harvard and Princeton participating.
MEXICO CITY, March 29-- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines reported to the nation last night on his recent meeting with President Eisenhower at White Sulphur Springs, W.Va.

The Georgia Power Company borrowed $12,000,000 in the bond market yesterday on an issue of first mortgage securities due April 1, 1956. The bonds were bought at competitive bidding by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., at a price of 100.6257 for obligations bearing 3 5/8 per cent interest.

TORONTO, March 29 (Canadian Press)-Copper Cliff Consolidated Mining Corporation and New Royran Copper Mines, Ltd., announced today formation of a wholly owned operating subsidiary under the name of Copper Rand Chibougamau Mines, Ltd.
The National Foreign Trade Council called upon Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks yesterday to remedy a "restricted and weakened" trade information program.

Many car dealers in this area expressed fear yesterday that Santa Claus might interfere with the success of the National Automobile Show. The motor exhibition is to take place from Dec. 8 to 16 at the New York Coliseum.

The Soviet Union operates almost 20,000 military aircraft. It is producing a total of 10,000 military planes annually, 6,000 to 7,000 of them jets. Its stockpile of thermonuclear and nuclear weapons, probably including atomic sea mines, is numbered in four figures.
WESTPORT, Conn, March 29 --A large-scale housing developer obtained an injunction today to keep this fashionable commuter town frown blocking construction of an eighty-dwelling project.
Plans to merge Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., into the Catalin Corporation of America were resumed yesterday. Earlier negotiations to merge were discontinued last November.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29--Ever since fencing became a sport, judging touches has been difficult because the sword thrust may be quicker than the eye.
PARIS, March 29 (UP)--Germinal Ballarin of France hammered out a ten-round decision over Kid Gavilan of Cuba tonight before 12,000 fans at the Palais des Sports.
An investment purchase of an important corner in the downtown Manhattan insurance district was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company.
TAMPA, Flak March 29 (AP)-- Gayle Talbot, Associated Press newsman and sports columnist, died tonight of a heart attack at the age of 54.

Pakistan has acted with political sagacity in refusing to be trapped by Moscow's offer of a trade pact with the Soviet Union. If Pakistan can sell some of her great jute crop to the Soviet Union and the Soviet Union can pay for the purchase there can hardly be rational objection.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity in March totaled $50,877,000, the smallest amount for any month since November, when $23,045,000 was redeemed. The total compared with $63,352,000 last month and $124,678,000 in March, 1955.

A PROGRAM that took account of the Easter season and stressed spiritual content was put together by Guido Cantelli for last night's Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall. The idea was sound in principle, but somehow it did not catch fire.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) --Lufthansa German Air Lines disclosed plans today to start service to South America and to the Middle East, with a terminal in Iran, in August or September.
WASHINGTON, March, 29-- The most powerful Democrat in Congress, Sam Rayburn of Texas, set out today to smash the influence of the most important Southern party bolter of 1952.

An assertion that "the public's honeymoon with television is over" was made last night by Ernest Jones, president of MacManus, John Adams, advertising agency that has sponsored a number of video programs for such clients as Cadillac, Pontiac, Dow Chemical and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing ("Scotch" brand tape).
New York's Bowery, "rich" in flophouses, is destined to become so high-toned that derelicts will never go there, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh predicted yesterday.
After thirty-five years in Wall Street, one of the nation's best known investment bankers is about to get an introduction to professional stock pricing.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The first official figures on the extent of G.I. mortgage "discounting" revealed today that the mortgages were selling for 94 to 96 cents on the dollar in many areas.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve throughout the country found their reserves under less pressure at the close of the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Futures trading in commodities was active yesterday in many New York markets despite the approach of a three-day week-end. Cottonseed oil and hides registered the fourth largest volumes of the year, cocoa the sixth and potatoes the tenth highest number of trades.
Stockholders of the American News Company were told yesterday that first quarter earnings will be higher than a year ago, when first quarter net was equal to 28 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) --Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson has warned Congress that atomic stockpiles are approaching the point where either the United States or Russia could "practically wipe out the world."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29--George Breen of Cortland (N.Y.) State Teachers College set a world record in winning the National Collegiate 1,500meter swimming title tonight. In Yale University's 50-meter pool in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium, the 20-year-old Buffalo athlete smashed the old mark of 18:19 with an 18:05.9 performance.
The Consolidated Edison Company plans to spend $650,000,000 on expansion through 1960, according to the annual report mailed yesterday to 161,956 stockholders.
The Mexican merchant marine may be bolstered by the transfer of fifteen American dry cargo ships built during World War II.
GREEN BAY, Wis., March 29 (AP)--The future of the Green Bay Packers' thirty-seven-year football relationship with this city of 50,000 hinges on the outcome of a referendum on the ballot next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Senator James O. Eastland, no supporter of more liberal immigration laws, has brought two European refugee families to work as sharecroppers on his Mississippi plantation.
Sterling Drug, Inc., set new records in sales and earnings last year, James Hill Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, disclosed yesterday in the annual report.

NEW ORLEANS, March 29 (AP)--A New Orleans cotton broker and a spokesman for a concern indicted on charges of violating the anti-trust laws today denied any "conspiracy or illegal activity" and expressed confidence of vindication.
The President Theatre, 247 West Forty-eighth Street, has been acquired by Gene Leone to expand his restaurant business.
MOSCOW, March 29--The arrival here today of Premier Tage Erlander of Sweden marked the opening of a new phase in the Soviet Union's drive to neutralize all of northern Europe in the "cold war."
The Chicago and North Western Railway, which netted $2,400,000 in all of 1955, so far this year has lost more than twice that amount.
LONDON, March 29--Most groups on the stock exchange were firm today although the holiday atmosphere kept business small.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Chilean copper production in this country at prices based on London Metal Exchange quotations.
ALBUQUERQUE, March 29 (AP)--Senator Estes Kefauver said tonight Adlai E. Stevenson was "still the leading candidate" for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but that he was gaining.
The Women's Division of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will give its fifth annual membership luncheon and fashion show on April 10 in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
LOS ANGELES, March 29 (UP) --A recommendation that a Los Angeles matchmaker, Babe McCoy, lose his state license will be made to the State Athletic ...
Signs of greater cordiality and more warmth in the relations between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia are increasing.
CHICAGO, March 29--Trading in grain and soybean futures today on the Board of Trade was largely a matter of evening up for the long week-end. Fluctuations were irregular.

An industrial building at 281 Palisade Avenue in Cliffside Park, N.J., has been sold by the Wheeler Realty Company to the Dyn Corporation of New York. The new owner will use the property for contract assembling and packaging.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29--V.K. Krishna Menon of India deplored today attribution to President Eisenhower of ultimate responsibility for the decision to hold further tests of nuclear weapons in the Pacific proving grounds. They are projected for April.

The management of the Western Auto Supply Company told stockholders at a meeting in Kansas City yesterday that it had been in touch with Canadian interests that had purchased large blocks of the company's stock. The statement was made

Rehabilitation of the reputation of Laszlo Rajk, executed Hungarian Foreign Minister, appears to open the way for the rewriting of the plots and purges that marked the final years of the Stalin epoch.
PHILADELPHIA, March 29 --Crane operators digging in the rubble today uncovered two of three bodies believed buried at the explosion-wrecked granary near the busy midtown area.
Time is running out for achievement of economic integration--mainly creation of a common market--by Western Europe, a leading Belgian industrialist warned yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 29 (AP)--A state judge issued here today a preliminary injunction against activities of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Louisiana. About the same time a Federal judge in New Orleans ordered the state to show why it should not halt prosecution.
The New York Times industrial and combined stock averages in the last three months reached new high levels for the bull movement.
TULSA, Okla., March 29 (AP)-- Three free-style champions won Greco-Roman wrestling titles tonight at the final session of the Amateur Athletic Union's fourday national tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 --A relaxed and smiling Adlai E. Stevenson ended a day of fourteen speeches and conferences by drawing tremendous applause and cheers from a crowd of 700 at the Central Labor Temple here tonight.
MACY'S new California fashions are as refined as Grace Kelly. Many are blonde, too. And pretty.
Former Foreign Minister Laszlo Rajk of Hungary will not benefit by the decision of the Hungarian Government, announced yesterday over Radio Budapest, to "rehabilitate" him.
Four players, listed as starters in tonight's East-West College All-Star basketball game at Madison Square Garden, were declared ineligible for the contest yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union.

Treasury Department seizure of Communist party assets to satisfy a tax lien was the basis yesterday of a motion to postpone the trial of seven secondary Communist leaders scheduled for April 9. Federal Judge Alexander Bicks reserved decision.
"THE mistake most brides make when buying furni ture is this--they think they are committing themselves eternally to their first purchases. This should not be so. It only makes them overcautious."

A Canadian physician denounced here yesterday "criminal malpractice" in "many" sanitariums for alcoholics. He said that many alcoholics and been killed through mistreat ment by "medical racketeers" who for years "have had everything their own way."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 29--Indonesia's most pressing problem can be traced in the light of a burning town, miles of rusted rail line and acres of fertile fields lying fallow because of fear of bandit hordes.

WASHINGTON, March 30, (AP) --John B. Hollister said today that he had no evidence of "any direct trade" between Nationalist and Communist China, thus ending what appeared to have been a disagreement with the State Department. Mr. Hollister is director of the International Cooperation Administration.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 30 (AP)--Senator Ester Kefauver was assured today of solid first ballot support from Indiana's twenty-six delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

Despite growing recognition that the Soviet economic offensive is developing into a real problem for the free world, opposition appears to be rising in Congress against both our aid and our trade policies designed to cope with this problem.
WASHINGTON, March 30--The next best thing to eyes in the back of the head came out of the patent list this week. It's a pair of eye-glasses equipped with rear-view mirrors.
Observers of the religious scene predict that tomorrow more churchgoers will attend Easter services than ever before.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Delays in the presentation to Congress of the Eisenhower Administration's civil rights program set off a move today to force a Democratic program to the House floor.
TRENTON, March 30--Mrs. Louise Brigham Chisholm of Cleveland, originator of "box" furniture, lecturer and writer, died today in the Sylvan Nursing Home after a long illness.
DETROIT, March 30 (AP)--Detroit's milk supply was cut by 60 per cent today as angry upstate farmers blockaded tank trucks and dumped thousands of gallons.
CLEVELAND, March 30 (AP)-- The Automotive Gear Works, Inc., of Richmond, Ind., today became a subsidiary of the Eaton Manufacturing Company, officials announced.
STOCKHOLM, March 24-- Sweden's first serious bid for a share of America's foreign automobile market will hit full stride at the International Motor Show in New York from April 28 to May 6.
THE man who admits he gets most of the brickbats, but few of the bouquets (if any) connected with the city budget is the Budget Director, himself, Abraham D. Beame.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- The Justice Department brought today its sixth major antitrust suit under a 1950 law barring certain corporate mergers.
AKLAVIK, Northwest Territories, March 30--This whole Arctic community crowded onto the frozen Mackenzie River today to give Governor General Vincent Massey of Canada typical northern welcome.

LONDON, March 30--E.C. Bentley, author of "Trent's Last Case," one of the classics of detective fiction, and of comic verses that have added a new word--clerihew--to the English language, died today at the age of 80.
WILMINGTON, N.C., March 30 (AP)--Gene Littler fired a 2under-par 70 today to cling to his one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $12,500 Azalea open golf tournament.
The $3,000,000 St. John's indoor recreation center in Brooklyn will open Monday at 2:30 P.M.
A 38-year-old man who had contended in Bronx Supreme Court that he lost his senses of taste and smell as a result of an accident was awarded $150,000 yesterday.

The Parliament of Iceland has voted by a majority of 38 to 18 a self-contradictory resolution which has caused concern throughout the Atlantic community. The resolution reaffirms the country's adherence to the North Atlantic alliance, of which it is a founder-member.
LOS ANGELES, March 30 (AP) --Babe McCoy's past and present life, were under fire again today before the Governor's committee investigating boxing in California.
"Amos 'n' Andy," will give way to public affairs programs from 9:30 to 9:55 P.M. Mondays through Fridays in a schedule shift by the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Investigating Senators unexpectedly rejected today what was to have been the final draft of a report on activities by an oil industry lawyer in behalf of the natural gas bill.
TRIPOLI, Libya, March 30-- The Libyan Parliament was reported today to have supported overwhelmingly the Libyan Government's rejection of Soviet aid.
TAMPA, Fla., March 30--Don Zimmer, who has run into more than a few obstacles in his stride toward a regular post with the Dodgers, apparently has hit another road block.

LAWRENCE, Kan., March 30 (AP)--The State Board of Regents today turned down Dr. Forrest C. (Phog) Allen's request to waive a retirement rule and permit him to coach the Kansas University basketball team again next year.
QUITO, Ecuador, March 29-- A top contender for the Presidency in the June 3 elections is described by his foes as a Communist demagogue.
NEW DELHI, India, March 30 The exodus of Hindus from East Bengal, in Pakistan, has increased to a degree officially described as alarming.
Fifteen sites are under study by the City Housing Authority for most of the 8,000 low-rent housing units allocated here by the Federal Government.
Roman Catholic and Protestant dignitaries have issued Easter messages hailing the victory of Christ over tyranny and death.
Several jazz groups took note of the season by offering an "Easter Jazz Festival" at Town Hall last evening.

BERLIN, March 30--East Germany's new armed forces made their first public appearance today when several hundred soldiers, sailors and airmen marched into the closing session of the Communist congress.
A strongly moving performance of "Parsifal" was the Good Friday offering at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- The United States will raise no objection if Britain joins France in selling arms to Israel.
JERUSALEM, (Jordanian Sector), March 30 (AP)--Pilgrims from many lands plodded through rain, sleet and snow today in a processional march along the path Christ took from his trial to Calvary.
WINTER PARK, Fla., March 30 (AP)--Stuart Miller shut out Alabama on seven hits today, pitching Yale to a 7-0 victory in the opener of a Rollins baseball week double-header.

We quote from the recent summary of the State Legislature's actions, as published by this newspaper: "Reduced the work week for state employes by four hours, from forty-eight to forty-four in some cases and from forty-four to forty in others. *** Established a forty-hour week for municipal police."

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., March 30--The rector of Leningrad University, in talking of the reorientation of Soviet life away from the adulation of Stalin, said today "it is necessary to introduce changes step by step."
RABAT, French Morocco, March 30--Thirty chiefs of the Moroccan "Army of Liberation" knelt in submission today before Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef.
Ships of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service answered fifty-eight calls for assistance last year from vessels in various parts of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and in the Mediterranean.
The forthcoming launching of earth satellites will be one of the greatest scientific achievements in years, it was predicted here last night.
PARIS, March 30--France protested today against the terms of an Arab Leagae resolution offering "full support" to Algerians in rebellion against French rule.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 --A warning that the theatrical feature films now moving from motion-picture studio vaults to television can "easily set back the standards of TV five or ten years" has been made by Frederic W. Ziv, chairman of the board of Ziv Television Programs.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (U.P.) --A former national officer of the Communist party identified today four persons said to have connections with the Washington (state) Pension Union as having been party members.

Prominent international figures will be among those attending the spring charity dance to aid the Pestalozzi Foundation of America. The dance will be held in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria next Friday evening.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30--Casey Stengel rediscovered a baseball truism at Al Lang Field today: Any time you have the Phillies hitting on one side and Robin Roberts pitching against the other, you are not going to see much scoring.

Colorado Interstate Gas Company announced yesterday that it would spend $76,000,000 on expansion in 1957. This will complete a two-year program totaling $116,000,000 and covering nearly 800 miles of new main transmission lines, six compressor stations and related improvements.

AT 10 girls dream of cathedral weddings with ushers in uni form and carrying swords; at 21, the scene shifts to little garden weddings when the apple tree is in bloom. Then they get engaged, pencil the first name on their guest list and the dreams become reality--grim reality.
Producers are running plant construction to meet a record demand for a rock whose use is rooted in antiquity.
Merchants here wore unaccustomed smiles yesterday. Sunny and mild weather made for the first really strong selling day in a fortnight.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 30 (U.P.)--Rocky Marciano said today that he was seriously thinking of retiring from boxing, at the urging of his wife and friends who "want me to quit while I'm on top."
Bus passengers transferring at Columbus Circle find there's no truth in the adage that the longest way round is the shortest way home.
The Iron Man, whose magnetic fingers gathered in two and onehalf billion dollars nationally in race-track bets last year, is ready for business again.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., March 30 --George Aubrey Hastings, onetime administrative assistant to former President Herbert Hoover, died today at his home, 227 Woodside Avenue. He was 71 years old.
Two official trade experts from Communist Rumania have been quietly touring this country for five weeks and concluded that this is a fine place to do business.

WASHINGTON, March 30--A $1,200,000,000 soil bank proposal designed by the Administration to bolster sagging farm prices and income in this election year was approved tonight by SenateHouse conferees on the farm bill.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Eisenhower has told the Canadians that United States public opinion would not tolerate recognizing the Chinese Communists or bringing them into the United Nations.
The third day of the Jewish Passover, Maundy Thursday in the Christian calendar, witnessed a poignant little ceremony at the crossing of the Jordan, on the Syrian-Israeli border.

ATLANTA, March 30--Eleven officeholders and three other members of the Atlanta League of Women Voters resigned today. They protested in a statement against the organization's refusal to bar Negro members.

BOWIE, Md., March 30 (UP) --The trainers of Nashua and Swaps, those arch-rivals of the turf, today officially withdrew their charges from the $100,000 added John B. Campbell Memorial Handicap at Bowie on April 7.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30--The 50-yard free-style race for the National Collegiate swimming title ended in a dead heat tonight.

A deal in the Murray Hill are of Manhattan was announced yesterday by Pease Elliman, brokers. They sold the fourstory town house at 135 East Thirty-eighth Street for Mrs. Patricia Dagg to Frederick A. Jambes, realty investor.
Cherif Hamia, an Algiers-born Parisian featherweight, showed a lot of spark in forging a tenround decision over Carmelo Costa of Brooklyn in Madison Square Garden last night.
BONN, Germany, March 30 (AP)--West Germany's booming automobile industry expects to roll out more than 1,100,000 vehicles this year for a new production record.

A CENTURY or so in time separates this morning's books and the difference in point of view is often pretty striking. Both are imaginatively concerned with Wild Western ways between the Tetons and the sea. Having read them alternately during the last month, I can recommend them as highly complementary.
Arthur Martinus Hartmann of Woodstock, N. Y., violinist and composer, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after having suffered a stroke. His age was 74.

AS inevitable as the scratch that will some day mar the new pink garbage pail is the certainty of some disagreement once the honeymoon is over. This is as much to be expected as smiles at the wedding.

SHE is a frivolous bride who dares to laugh off the old theory that the way to a man's heart is through his stomach. From crib to coffin, eating remains a prime pleasure for men (and women) of sound mind and body. An inviting table compensates for some of the inevitable difficulties of life and marriage. Round the world, sophisticates agree, bad cooking is an unnecessary strike against a household.

With reasonably comfortable weather in prospect for Easter Sunday, rail, air and bus lines yesterday scheduled extra accommodations for holiday travelers. And final plans took shape for egg-rolling parties and the traditional promenade on Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) --The rate of child-bearing by American women rose about 11 per cent between 1950 and 1954.
The campaign of the city's teachers for higher salary increases picked up national support yesterday, but it lost local backing.

ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, off Princess Martha Coast, Antarctica, March 29--The seagoing support phase of Operation Deepfreeze I ended tonight with the raising of the Stars and Stripes at Atka Bay on the coast of Antarctica's Queen Maud Land.
PARIS, March 30--Pierre Poujade, leader of a right-wing anti-tax movement, offered today to resign if his followers so wished.
Four men were seized in the Bronx yesterday as they attempted to hold-up a gasoline station. One of the them fired his .32-caliber pistol at a policeman at point-blank range, but it did not go off.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- The nation's housewives are in process of proving to the Government's housing agencies that all the talk about conformity in the United States is a myth.

The General Dynamics Corporation and its subsidiaries had consolidated net earnings last year of $21,254,336, equal to $4.23 a share, John Jay Hopkins, chairman and president, said in the annual report issued for publication today.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 --Adlai E. Stevenson took a plane for Chicago today "very much reassured" over his California Presidential primary campaign.

VANCOUVER, March 30 (Canadian Press)--British Columbia skiers swept the first twelve placings in the Class A men's slalom event today as the combined Western Canada Alpine and North American Nordic ski championships began.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 30--Communism seeks to attract small powers by promising them industrialization and a balanced economy. Therefore, after the revolution had firmly clamped itself on Bulgaria, it set out to follow this customary pattern.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP)--The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad reported today its passenger revenue increased more than $250,000 a month after it began handling the Union Pacific's Chicago-West Coast passenger trains in October.

Sales and earnings of the Colonial Sand and Stone Company last year were the highest in its history, Anthony Pope, president, reported yesterday. Confident of a continued favorable trend, Mr. Pope said the company was "actively continuing to explore new areas of construction and new sand plant sites at economic distances from its main operations."
DALLAS, Tex., March 30 (AP)-- Spokesmen for two Dallas cotton concerns today denied charges that they had taken part in collusive bidding on Governmentheld cotton worth $30,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- The United States Court of Military Appeals upheld today the authority of military courts to try civilians accompanying the armed forces overseas.

LOS ANGELES, March 30-- A car without any gearshift, cooling system, carburetor or ignition system completed today a four-day transcontinental trip that may presage the future motoring mode.

A young woman returning by air from Paris cut herself in the throat, wrists and one ankle yesterday morning as the plane neared New York International Airport, at Idlewild, Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices increased 2 per scent between mid-February and mid-March. This raised them 3 per cent above the Jan. 1 level.

The Legislature has handed Governor Harriman a tough problem in passing on to him, for veto or approval, the bill to create twenty-one new judgeships in the state. A FAMOUS author often presents various faces to succeeding generations--the official pose adopted in his published works, the confiding glance of autobiography and the mask which he assumed for the greater number of his contemporaries. In some men there is little difference in the faces, merely slight changes of expression. In others, like Edward Gibbon (1737-94), the variation is so great that it is difficult to believe they represent the same individual.
