International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries achieved new highs last year in sales and net income both on a consolidated and parent company basis. This was disclosed in the annual report released over the week-end.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 1-- Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cooper Hewitt have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Leslie Guion Hewitt, to David Waddell Bird. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred George Bird of Birmingham, Mich. An autumn wedding is planned.
Tammany Hall again has selected Anthony B. Akers to bid for the House seat held since 1946 by Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr.

In the light of the desegregation decisions of the United States Supreme Court, the work of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., 22 East Fifty-fourth Street, New York 22, has taken on added significance.
The crash of a Trans World Airlines plane yesterday was the nation's first major commercial air disaster this year.
LONDON, April 1--The Cunard liner Franconia, which left Southampton and Le Havre Thursday for Halifax, N. S., and New York, is on her way back to Southampton today with engine trouble.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 1 (AP)--Brown University's crew, skippered by J.C. Quinn, won the MacMillan sailing trophy today on the final leg of the last race of the two-race intercollegiate series at the Naval Academy.

A total of 6,250 persons attended three morning services at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday. The capacity congregations heard the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell preach on "Easter's Song of Triumph."
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 1 --Glenn Foster gained his third successive victory and fifth of the champions hip Frostbite season at Larchmont Yacht Club today.
NICKNAMED "Tiger" for his toughness and "Fox" for his wariness, Egypt's Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser has been described as "a dictator by default" in a "revolution without a doctrine."
Few recent international developments are more important than Moscow's decision to try to resume the policy of united fronts with parliamentary Socialists in the free world.
After having occupied space in the old downtown textile district since 1865, Woodward, Baldwin Co, is moving to 111 West Fortieth Street.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 1-- A semi-official study group reported today that Connecticut residents "face a possible tax increase of almost $60,000,000 in financing the General Fund Budget" for the two-year period beginning July 1, 1957.
WASHINGTON, April 1--In the Easter recess the Administration is doing some missionary work on behalf of its foreign aid program.

LONDON, April 1--Because of the imminence of the long Easter holiday and a budget little more than a fortnight ahead, activity in the stock markets was further reduced last week. Despite this pronounced lack of public interest--or maybe because of it--the markets held surprisingly steady.
Five thousand persons filed into St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10 A.M. yesterday to herald the Resurrection. The solemn pontifical mass was celebrated by Cardinal Spellman.

The City Administration's chief opponent of fluoridation said last night it could affect adversely-8,000 New Yorkers-- one-tenth of 1 per cent of the city's 8,000,000 population. Com missioner Arthur C. Ford of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity
Wreckers will go to work today on the 103-year-old Bible House to clear the way for a block-square new building for the School of Engineering of Cooper Union.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)-- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee and Adlai Stevenson invade Florida this week in their battles for the state's twentynine delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 --The Screen Extras Guild announced today it would terminate in sixty days a collective bargaining contract with producers of theatrical and television movies unless a "deadlock" in negotiations is broken.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 1 (UP)--The Fort Wayne Pistons defeated the Philadelphia Warriors, 84-83, tonight on two lastminute free throws by George Yardley. The victory squared the National Basketball Association play-off series at one game apiece.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York has granted $85,000 to finance an American Assembly to study United States representation abroad. The conference will be held at Arden House, Harriman, N. Y., May 3-6.
Soviet moves aiming at exchanges, of students and teachers with the United States are creating problems for and controversy among United States Government officials.
The Socialist Labor party yesterday nominated Eric Hass, its Presidential candidate in 1952, to run for the United States Senate next fall.
THE most nostalgic women in town today, aside from those who work for Henri Bendel, should be the thousands of New York debutantes this store has dressed and sent out into society.
PITTSBURGH, April 1--The steel industry has just finished the most productive quarter in its history but there is already evidence that the second quarter will match or better the first.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1--In Casey Stengel's book there had been a big question mark alongside the name of Mickey McDermott. It was put there last Monday when Mickey was cuffed for eleven runs in one inning by the Dodgers at Vero Beach.
JERUSALEM, April 1 (AP)-- Rumors of war and new shooting incidents along Israel's borders broke the Easter peace of the Holy Land today.
WILMINGTON, N.C., April 1 (AP)--Mike Souchak rolled in a five-foot putt for a birdie on the last green today to win the Azalea open golf tournament by a stroke from Dick Mayer.
Five new films, including imports from the soviet Union and India, are scheduled to open this week. The programs follow:

A tract of 135 acres on the east side of Walt Whitman Road in Melville, town of Huntington, L.I. has been purchased by Jack Wilder for improvement with an industrial center. The seller was Joseph Kowalski. Jr., represented by Harry Brenner as attorney.
It was reunion day yesterday for old grads of the dog pound of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
MOSCOW, April 1--Pravda accused the United States today of broadcasting propaganda to the Soviet Union from a radio station masquerading as a clandestine Soviet transmitter.

LONDON, April 1--Georgi M. Malenkov visited Canterbury Cathedral, today and, had lunch and tea with Dr. Hewlett Johnson, the Dean of Canterbury also known as the Red Dean because of his Leftist views.

The Harlem Globetrotters devoted little time to their usual antics at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The Trotters went about their business methodically as they defeated the College All-Stars twice.

AKLAVIK, Northwest Territories, March 31--An Arctic Venice, built on cement piles sunk into the permanently frozen soil of the Mackenzie delta, is in the making thirty-five miles northwest of this far north community.

The Southern Railway System has announced that John E. Hyde, vice president since 1932, will retire on May 1. He will be succeeded by Charles M. Davison Jr., controller. Mr. Davison's assistant, Robert B. Curry, will become controller.
WASHINGTON, April 1-- President Eisenhower got a report yesterday that is expected to stir quite a rumpus this election-year.
CAN Christian Dior do for the bathing suit what he has done for dress design? Cole of California intends to find out.

DETROIT, April 1--Rocks, clubs and fists flew today in Michigan's week-old milk strike. Striking dairy farmers battled nonstriking producers in an attempt to throttle supply, lines and force creameries to meet price demands.
LONDON, April 1--British sources said today that India had placed a multimillion dollar order for British jet bombers, tanks and other weapons after she had rejected a cutprice offer of Soviet arms.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., March 31--More young men and women than ever before are getting married these days, the manager of a district registration bureau here said today. Her views coincided with those of officials in Moscow, although no universal statistics were available.

PITTSBURGH, April 1--An eastbound Trans World Airlines plane crashed into a hillside near here tonight and burst into flames, killing twenty-one of he persons aboard. The two-engine Martin 4-0-4 crashed seconds after take-off at 7:15 P.M.
The shipping industry which thrives or falters in direct ratio to water front labor stability, studied last week the implications of a loan that did not go through.
Overcoats and winter furs abounded in the Easter parade on Fifth Avenue yesterday. The earliest Easter since 1951 was also one of the chilliest in recent years in New York.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP)--Ch. Wilber White Swan's string of major best-in-show triumphs came to an end tonight at the International Kennel Club's sixteenth annual all-breed dog show.

Racing will return to New York today as the thoroughbreds and the harness racers start their 1956 campaigns. The flat runners open at Jamaica this afternoon, while the high-steppers perform at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., tonight.
SINGAPORE, Monday, April 2 (Reuters)--Malaya's Chief Minister, Tengku (Prince) Abdul Rahman, rejected today a new move by Malaya's Communists to meet him for peace talks.

FIFTY-TWO years ago, Julius Neergaard, a Dane, opened an apothecary shop in Brooklyn's Fifth Avenue just above Ninth Street. He set up an allnight-service policy. He has been one with the dust, now, for thirty-four years, but the tradition still holds.

Spring may be in the air for major leaguers, but for baseball coaches, athletic directors and students at New England's prep schools it's still winter. In practically all cases diamonds are well covered with snow.
Premier Jozef Cyrankiewicz of Poland appears to have become the first Communist leader to offer a public explanation for acquiescence in Stalin's dictatorial rule.
MADRID, April 1--A Moroccan nationalist leader said here today that nationalist rebels would not attack French troops anywhere in Moroccan territory, including the area bordering on Algeria.
BUENOS AIRES, April 1-- Discovery of a new plot against the Argentine Government and the arrest of seventy persons, including non-commissioned Army officers, was announced here early today.
PENDLETON, Ore., April 1-- (UP)--A private passenger plane crashed in the middle of a wheat field about seven miles east of here today, killing all four persons aboard.

TOKYO, April 1--Union leaders agreed early today to settlement of a strike that has tied up all of Japan's fifty-six major coal mines and many small ones since March 19. Unless union members balk at the terms, the mines will be back in operation tomorrow.
Leaders of American industry will pay tribute on Wednesday night to a Government agency which is little known to the public but closely connected with the nation's private industry.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 1-- This was getaway day for the Giants. They broke camp after a 7-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs and headed for Albuquerque, N.M. the first stop on the long trek home.

THE Knickerbocker Chamber Players are professional musicians who like to vary the routine of their bread-winning jobs by giving concerts in which they join in groups of varying sizes to perform the Sort of music they enjoy playing.

The final week of the current Metropolitan Opera season will open Wednesday evening, April 11, with Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier." On Monday and Tuesday of that week the company will play at the Lyric Theatre in Baltimore.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 1--Mr. and Mrs. William Raymond Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Low Raymond, to James Appleton Woods.
LIMASSOL, Cyprus, April 1-- An elderly British civilian was shot and killed here today while strolling in the heart of the business district.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1-- Business men throughout India went to their offices this morning to find that a director of a company cannot appoint his relatives to offices of profit in the company without permission of shareholders.
A conductor of a television program for children apparently has won the job of master of ceremonies for "The $64,000 Challenge," which makes its debut Sunday.

Despite increased expenditures for research and development, the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation achieved higher earnings last year. Earnings in 1955 amounted to $4,270,650 on sales of $154,412,491, compared with $4,134,015 on sales of $140,428,318 in 1954.
COLOMBO. Ceylon, April 1-- There is a national election to be held in Ceylon this week and the Government is running scared.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The nation's farm surplus will double in the next ten years if current production trends continue, a report by the National Planning Association said today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 1--The hitherto truculent Bulgarian People's Republic is now trying to improve relationships with its traditional Balkan enemies, Greece and Yugoslavia. This suits Moscow's book.
Record sales and earnings were reported by the Clark Equipment Company in its 1955 annual report, mailed to stokholders over the week-end.

Three persons were injured late yesterday afternoon when an Austin automobile crashed into the rear of a horse-drawn carriage in Central Park. The horse broke loose from the wrecked cab and raced south nine blocks to Columbus Circle, Where it was captured by another horse-cab driver.
MOSCOW, April 1--Pravda published today for the first time sharp criticism of the Communist party organization of Soviet Georgia.

WASHINGTON, April 1--Plans are being laid here for another campaign charging a "do-nothing Congress." But this time the Republicans are doing the firing and the Democrats are the targets. Members of the Democratic-controlled Eighty-fourth Congress are out of town on a ten-day Easter recess.
MOSCOW, April 1 (AP)--Pravda and Izvestia said today the enw Soviet disarmament proposals provided the first realistic solution for the ten-year disarmament deadlock.
TUCSON, Ariz., April 1 (AP)-- Herb Score yielded only one hit and struck out four batters in pitching five scoreless innings today as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5--3.
In a joyful "entrance service" yesterday afternoon, 3,000 persons worshiped for the first time in the main auditorium of the Concord Baptist Church in Brooklyn.
SERVE a smorgasbord, the import from Sweden that enjoys such vogue in this country. Guests like it because it is fun to choose what they wish from the tempting assortment of foods on the buffet.

Panama hats are made in Ecuador. How come? There's a very simple explanation. During the years the Panama Canal was being built--from 1882 to 1914--the construction workers on that gigantic enterprise bought thousands of the distinctive hats in local market places.

The power of the soul to defeat every temporal oppression was the theme of the Easter sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. James H. Robinson at the Presbyterian Church of the Master, Morningside Avenue and West 122d Street.

ZURICH, April 1--Stock Exchange business here was erratic last week for these reasons: In New York a setback occurred last Tuesday, notably in copper stocks, and, after the four-day week closing Thursday, the Zurich Stock Exchange and all Swiss banks remain closed for four days. Selling grew heavy.

WASHINGTON, April 1-- Advocates of a constitutional amendment limiting the Government's power to tax are on the move again. The seventeen-yearold campaign appears, however, to be as much of a, lost cause as ever.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 1--Richard R. Lewit, who was in the automotive supply business for many years, died of a heart attack yesterday in the East Orange General Hospital. He was 59 years old and resided at 55 Warren Court.
WASHINGTON, April 1-- President Eisenhower attended Easter services this morning, posed for pictures with relatives, and made some comments about his wife's hat.
Yesterday's Easter parading was not confined to pedestrian activity. Thousands in the New York area took to the highways to enjoy the clear but chilly holiday.
Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the State Assembly declared yesterday that Governor Harriman had been "absolutely wrong" in trying to remove 500,000 persons from the income tax rolls.
Those early hints of spring in the air will undoubtedly bring joy to young lovers, baseball fans, flower seed sales men and to Tin Pan Alley lyricists hard pressed for inspiration. But
Mayor Wagner gave New York a pat on the back yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1--Employers have designated Charles H. Smith Jr., 35-year-old Cleveland manufacturer, to head the United States seven-member employer delegation to the 1956 International Labor Conference in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, April 1-- Harry Morgan Moses, the management spokesman whose manto-man contract negotiations with John L. Lewis helped bring five years of labor peace to the soft coal industry, died of cancer today in Doctors Hospital here. He was 59 years old.
The city's teacher's yesterday continued to press their demands for greater pay raises than those approved by the Mayor.
THE one thing a returning tourist brings back from the baseball camps in Florida is the conviction that the Yankees and Dodgers again will meet in the world series this year.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 1 --Atoms for Peace Awards Inc. announced today details of its operating procedures.

An enchanting cargo rolled into town yesterday. This almost mile-long red and silver townon-wheels moved on box, flat and sleeper cars into the Harlem River railroad yards in the Bronx at 1 A.M. Hours later the sunbeams danced on the silvery letters that proclaimed:
PARIS, April 1--Paul Ramadier, Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs, has stepped up France's efforts to further remove import quotas and stimulate trade with Western Europe and the sterling zone.
ROME, April 1 (AP)--Following, in transaction from, the Italian, is the text of the Easter-address by Pope Pius XII, as released by the Vatican Press Office:

AS everyone must know by now, a great new musical has swept into town, called "My Fair Lady." Laid in the 1912 period, the show has 250 superb costumes by the British designer, Cecil Beaton. Now, for all the ladies who leave the show wanting to "look just like that," there is great news.

Joseph F. McLoughlin, chief clerk of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in New York County and prominent for many years in Irish societies here, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital of a heart ailment. His age was 71. He resided at 1230 Park Avenue.
F. Hugh Herbert's adaptation of a comedy by Eduardo de Filippo, Italy's leading playwright, is slated for Broadway production in November.

Continuing reports from both India and Pakistan are disquieting. There have been frequent small border incidents and each country accuses the other of having been at fault. India complains that Hindus from East Pakistan are being put under such pressure that they feel obliged to migrate into Indian Bengal, which cannot support them.

The public school children of New York City have a right to expect one thing from the Superintendent of Schools when he starts negotiating with teachers today on the salary question: that is the full, cheer
MONTOUR, FALLS, N.Y., April 1 (AP)--More than 5,000 fishermen braved a cold, dark morning to get the trout season under way today at Catharine Creek.
CAIRO, April 1--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser has declared that he still holds in his pocket a Soviet offer to help finance the construction of the proposed High Dam at Aswan.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 1-- The marriage of Miss Roberta Irene Sanderson, daughter of Countess Irene von Wertha, to David Barry Sheldon, son of Dr. John H. Sheldon of Glens Falls, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Sheldon, took place today at Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.

A symbolic dawn was created for nearly 7,000 worshipers in the Radio City Music Hall yesterday at 7 A.M. Successive waves of blue, green and gold light, with streaks of fiery red, flooded the theatre as the prelude to the Eastern Dawn Service held under the auspices of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

Foreign trade liberalization is a difficult, subject. Those who expect to be hurt by it are few but extremely vocal. Those who gain seldom are conscious of the fact and, in any event, are not inclined to make loud noises.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon is the subject of a second book to be published this season. On April 23 Putnam will issue James Keogh's "This Is Nixon," which not only gives the life of Mr. Nixon, but also presents his views on the important issues.

The steamship charter market experienced another "strong" week last week despite the abbreviation of work days caused by the Jewish and Christian holidays. Volume was off slightly, but rates continued to climb.

Two principles may well guide the Western Powers in any discussion of armaments with the Soviet Union: first, the West should not accept any trick formula that would increase Russia's relative military strength; second, the West should not reject any proposal that

"Damn Yankees" led the field in six of eighteen categories last night as the outstanding musical in the American Theatre Wing's tenth annual sweepstakes for the "Tony" awards. "The Diary of Anne Frank" was named the top play of the season.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) --Senator Irving M. Ives, who opposed the original Bricker amendment, said today his "present inclination" was to support the new simplified version "unless President Eisenhower strongly objects to it."
Two Easter services at the Riverside Church yesterday attracted nearly 5,000 worshipers.

THE observance of Easter on television was con cerned primarily with the holiday's religious aspect. But still there were remnants of the commercialism and publicity carnival that evoked so much criticism a few years ago.

PEARL S. BUCK, this country's only woman Nobel Prize winner for literature, is one of the most prolific writers of her time. Since the publication of her first novel, "East Wind: West Wind," in 1929, Mrs. Buck has written approximately forty-five books.
Two men wearing knitted wool caps over their faces accosted the cashier of the Town and Country Restaurant last night, forced him to open a safe and fled with at least $4,000.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)-- The Office of Defense Mobilization authorized Federal tax benefits today to help seven commercial airlines buy 258 new planes at a cost of $509,935,000.

CHICAGO, April 1--The approval of a high price provision for support levels on farm crops by the House-Senate conference failed to have much effect on wheat prices last week. It was feared that a veto might be the answer.

When people complain about high taxes, exercising the right lodged in every citizen, Mayor Wagner often remarks that there are no taxes to pay in the jungle. This is his way of emphasizing that civilization brings its obligations as well as its comforts, benefits and pleasures.
The pen and brush work of the Columbia University family will go on public view today at Morningside Heights.
The New York City Housing Authority will begin today the distribution of applications for the 1,177 apartments in the first division of the Senator Robert F. Wagner Houses.

The Conference Committee named to reconcile the Senate and House versions of proposed farm legislation voted last week, among other things, to return "for one year" to high fixed support prices for the so-called "basic" farm commodities.

United States membership in the Organization for Trade Cooperation is essential to combat the new Communist economic offensive, the foreign commerce committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce declared over the week-end.
Samuel Klein, known as the dean of the coat and suit industry, died yesterday at his home, 290 West End Avenue. His age was 78.
HOUSEWIVES, look to your tabletops, rugs and other furnishings--cigar smoking is on the upswing.
WASHINGTON, April 2--Guy Mollet, Premier of France, has delivered another installment in French criticism of United States and Western foreign policies.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The outlook for the Administration's civil-rights program in this session of Congress is decidedly gloomy.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 2 --Miss Janet Glynn Bradley was married to Frank Day Taylor 2d here this afternoon in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

Hugh Gallaher, vice president of the Penn Metal Company, Inc., died Sunday of cancer at the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 62 years old. He resided on Leroy Avenue, Darien, Conn.

DETROIT, April 2 (AP)--The nation's auto makers built about 1,742,000 passenger cars in this year's first quarter. According to present plans they will build only slightly more in the three months ahead.
LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., March 31--The downgrading of Stalin is said to be encountering less resentment in this city than in other places in the Soviet Union.
Municipal Court Justice Carson DeWitt Baker, who was convicted of twenty-four parking and traffic violations, denied yesterday that he was a scofflaw.

SARASOTA, Fla., April 2-- The Red Sox completed a sweep of their exhibition games with the world champions by beating the Dodgers, 7--4, today at Payne Field. In one of their three spring meetings, Manager Mike Higgins' squad had scored by 17--5.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The Defense Department listed today the relative standing of 100 huge corporations that accounted for 62.6 per cent of $123,260,900,000 in prime defense contracts in five years.
A two-hour meeting between Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, and leaders of teacher groups active in the current salary controversy ended yesterday on a note encouraging to teachers.
CECELIA WARD, mezzo-soprano, sang a debut recital in Town Hall last evening. Miss Ward, a native of Louisiana, was trained at Louisiana College and the Cincinnati Conservatory.
Communist party officials, charging that four documents were missing, refused last night to pay Internal Revenue officials $1,500 to recover the party's seized New York offices.
Market specialists in Government securities are as excited as baseball fans about curves right now.
WASHINGTON, April, 2--A suit to test the use of confidential information in deportation proceedings was filed in Federal District Court here today.

LONDON, April 2--The United States will make "far-reaching" proposals for international control of nuclear weapons "in the very near future," according to the spokesman of the United States delegation to the United Nations disarmament subcommittee conference here.

A leprechaun bounced into the office. He carried a topcoat and a Dakota-type cowboy hat. His white hair was neat and newly trimmed. He had a bit of pink in his snubbish nose that matched the tint of his unwrinkled cheeks.
The Huber Wagon Works has leased a new one-story building at 54-69. Forty-sixth Street in the Laurel Hill district of Long Island City, Queens, and will use it for the manufacture of truck bodies.

Hardy Smallwood of Brooklyn scored a ten-round upset victory over Gaspar Ortega of Mexico City at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The Brooklyn boxer, at 157 pounds, was too strong for his 152 -pound rival.
The secretary to whom Lenin dictated his famous "testament" to the Communist party, warning against Stalin, has survived the purge years and is alive in Moscow today.

William Z. Foster, American Communist leader, has come to the defense of Soviet leaders who worked with Stalin while the dictator ruled the Soviet Union. By implication, Mr. Foster defended his own pro-Stalinist policies in the Communist party since the Nineteen Twenties.

SEATTLE, Wash., April 2--A Northwest Airlines Stratocruiser carrying thirty-eight persons crashed into Puget Sound today shortly after taking off for New York. Rescue planes and boats saved thirty-three persons.
ALBANY, April 2--The state took in $32,900,000 more than it spent in the 1955-56 fiscal year, Controller Arthur Levitt said today. The fiscal year ended Saturday.
The circus went to court yesterday in an effort to prevent labor trouble from blocking the opening of the big show tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 2-- The newly designated head of the employer delegation to the International Labor Organization does not think too highly of it. But he says he is willing to be shown if it is helping the United States.
Comic books were termed an "important track" to the education of children yesterday as achievement awards were presented to publishers.

New York must have more policemen than are provided for in the 1956-57 executive budget or the city will be "actually retrogressing" in its campaign for full protection, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy declared yesterday.
DETROIT, April 2 (UP)--New violence broke out in Detroit's week-old milk strike today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 2--Although excluded from the new coalition Cabinet of Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo, the Communist party remains a threat to the stability of the Indonesian Government.
MONTREAL, April 2--The British freighter Manchester Regiment arrived here at midafternoon today, marking the official opening of the ocean navigation season for the big inland seaport of Montreal.
WASHINGTON, April 2-- President Eisenhower warmly welcomed the 6,157 persons present today at the annual Easter Monday egg-rolling on the White House lawn. He then told them:

Sales of New York department stores, although curtailed sharply by bad weather; were 2 per cent higher last month than in March of last year. The month's sales were the worst, on a year-to-year comparative basis, of any month since last April.
WASHINGTON, April 2-- President Eisenhower is expected to announce soon a national committee on the development of scientists and engineers.

PITTSBURGH, April 2--A. Barr Comstock, former Department of Justice and State Department aide and an expert on foreign policy, died here on Saturday at the home of a son, A. Barr Comstock Jr. His age was 69.

TO read Jean Anouilh's "Antigone" is to have an impression of moral valor. To hear it performed at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse, where it opened last evening, is to have an impression of acting that lacks classical conviction.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 2 (AP)--The Rev. M.L. King Jr. and several other leaders of the Negro boycott against city buses were denied permission today to establish an all-Negro bus company.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 2-- Adlai E. Stevenson charged today that Senator Estes Kefauver, his chief rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, was creating "hostilities and divisions" within their party on the basis of false charges.

CAIRO, April 2--Communist China's friendship offensive in the Middle East marched forward today. A large and impressive trade exhibit opened in Cairo and it was announced that Peiping had bought the equivalent of almost $17,500,000 worth of Egyptian cotton since last August.
ORLANDO, Fla., April 2--An assortment of ailments is troubling the Yankees this spring. But happily for the American League champions, Yogi Berra manages to stay in one piece.

I present for your consideration the executive budget for the fiscal year 1956-57. This budget consists of expense budget appropriations totaling $1,853,795,103.22, an increase of $113,728,993.64 over the current year, and $63,429,314.80 for services to

WESTBURY, L.I., April 2-- Harness racing was welcomed back enthusiastically to the metropolitan area tonight. A crowd of 20,673 whooped it up in mid-season form to herald the start of the 1956 campaign at Roosevelt Raceway.
Former President Harry S. Truman's contribution to public affairs in America, the peripatetic press conference, moved through Times Square yesterday morning like a swarm of hornets.

ROME, N.Y., April 2.--The Zion Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Emily Kathryn Russell to W. Kent Ford Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Sykes.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether labor unions may under the Taft-Hartley Act engage in slowdowns and other harassing tactics to back lawful bargaining demands.

TOKYO, April 2 (AP)--Table tennis players from Communist China defeated a United States team, 5--4, today in a tense world tournament match that marked the first athletic meeting of the two countries.

With greater loan volume and higher interest on loans earnings of New York City banks in the first quarter of the year exceeded those in the like period of last year. shown by the first group of quarterly bank reports issued yesterday.
Everyone felt sorry for John Kelly yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street.

PARIS, April 2--France is the object of what the newspaper Combat called today "a new offensive of smiles launched by Moscow." Combat added that France had responded by a "counter-offensive to the Russian campaign of smiles."

The Federal Maritime Board yesterday announced that sales of Mariner-class cargo ships after June 30 would be on a fixed minimum-price basis. Allowances for depreciation based on age will cease after that date.

Increased bitterness and further confusion over the future of the Rev. William Howard Melish were the chief results last night of the annual congregational meeting of the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.
DRUMRIGHT, Okla., April 2 (AP)--Tornadoes struck at half a dozen points in Oklahoma tonight, killing at least four persons and injuring more than a score.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 2 --Upsala College's baseball team extended its two-season winning streak to sixteen today by beating Colby, 7 to 4.
PITTSBURGH, April 2 (AP)-- Following are the persons identified as dead, those tentatively identified dead, those unaccounted for, and survivors of yesterday's airliner crash:

WASHINGTON, April 2-- President Eisenhower has decided to continue keeping on ice Israel's request to buy arms in the United States. The decision was made at a long conference with Secretary of State Dulles last Wednesday.

The city of Philadelphia, Pa., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $12,323,000 on issues of serial bonds on April 25. The obligations will be dated June 1, 1956, and will come due on July 1 from 1957 to 1981.
Alfred P. Sloan Jr. retired yesterday as chairman of the General Motors Corporation.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 (UP)--Red Schoendienst walloped a three-run homer with two out in the ninth today off Howard Pollet to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 6-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 --Lewis Milestone, who returned recently from a long stay in Europe, will direct Kirk Douglas in "King Kelly."
Mayor Wagner's new budget for New York's housekeeping of the fiscal year 1956-57 lives up to expectations on size, and is of course the city's largest ever.
HARTFORD, April 2--Highway fatalities in Connecticut have dropped nearly 15 per cent since Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff ordered a crackdown on speeders three months ago.
PARIS, April 2--Algerian demonstrators clashed with policemen and troops today in several towns in the North and East of France.
ATHENS, April 2--King Paul of Greece predicted today that the cause of "democracy and freedom" for Cyprus would triumph.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- The National Association of Wool Manufacturers today urged the Government to increase the duty on imported woven wool fabrics to 45 per cent of their value.

After a month's steady diet of news telling of the fantastic bungling of the farm problem at the legislative level in Washington it is a relief to come across a story dealing with the problem, for a change, in nonpolitical language.
A random sampling of actual tax payments by individual property owners in the five boroughs brought light--if not definitive answer--to the question: Is real estate overtaxed?
MAINE trout fishing has started the hard way and prospects are not good for at least a couple of weeks, perhaps longer.
Magazine distributors here were inclined yesterday to scout a warning from Canada that a tax on United States magazines might be necessary in the dominion to protect Canada's publishing industry.
KELANIYA, Ceylon, April 2 --"Sabotage" said the local campaign manager, darkly. "The Prime Minister is due here any minute and the loudspeaker is missing. Looks like sabotage."

My good friends of Florida: I am happy to be here with you this evening and to be appearing on this program with my good friend and one of your fellow residents, J. Howard McGrath, the distinguished former Senator and Governor, and former Attorney General of the United States.

Sale of a full year's production of household appliances and other consumer goods in the next nine months is the goal of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, fighting to recover from a five-month strike.
WASHINGTON, April 2--A man who farms, paints, skis, bowls, golfs, dances-- and accounts--was sworn in today as President Eisenhower's third Director of the Budget, succeeding Rowland R. Hughes.

"LANDSCAPE WITH DEAD DONS," by Robert Robinson, is a satiric mystery story about Oxford and a spoof on the academic life everywhere. Many an American university pundit would probably have preferred writing it to marking term papers, baby-sitting and contributing to the avant garde and rearguard quarterlies.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 2 (AP)--Richard K. O'Malley, Associated Press chief of bureau in Moscow, was given seven days to leave the Soviet Union after having been charged with illegal currency transactions. He arrived in Stockholm yesterday.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 2--Last Friday, Bill Rigney, the manager of the Giants, went on record that "Dusty Rhodes is my regular left fielder." As a precautionary measure. Rigney added, "as of now."

THE way to develop responsibility in children is to give them more of it, two child specialists indicated yesterday. What's more, parental insistence on safety and security may have to give way at times to "the calculated risk," one of them held.
Commodity futures generally declined yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Volume was light, with only cocoa, hides, potatoes and cottonseed oil registering normal activity.

KENNETH ARMITAGE, whose current visit to New York was prompted by an admiration for the fact that "America hasn't been pulled back into the past," is a 40year-old British sculptor of international reputation.

MONTREAL, April 2 (AP)-- The Detroit Red Wings, with three defense men physically under par, today brought up a farmhand to bolster their backline for the second game of the final Stanley Cup play-offs with the Montreal Canadiens tomorrow night.

The president and executive vice president of Jules S. Sottnek Co., Inc., stevedoring contern, testified yesterday to payments of approximately $38,000 to a shipping agency official and a loan of $11,000 to a longshore union business agent.
The Climax Molybdenum Company last year had the highest sales and earnings in its history, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
"A Month in the Country" will open at 8 o'clock tonight at the Phoenix Theatre under the auspices of T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton.

WASHINGTON, April 2--The Supreme Court decreed today that the states had no power to punish persons who advocated overthrow of the Federal Government by force or violence.

CHICAGO, April 2--Soybean futures were active and strong on the Board of Trade today. The May, July and September deliveries made new crop highs on buying by commission houses which absorbed profit taking sales easily.
The charm of Louis E. Wolfson, which clouded over on occasion last year when he was fighting a losing proxy battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co., shone in all its splendor again yesterday.
Claude Rains has been cast to portray a Supreme Court Justice who is drafted as a Presidential candidate in a play titled "President."
Textron American, Inc., has agreed to buy all the outstanding stock of the Benada Aluminum Products Company of Girard, Ohio, it was announced yesterday, The purchase price was not disclosed.

BRISTOL, Conn., April 2--Six New York actors took parts of Shakespeare out of the textbook today and brought them to life before interested educators and students of this New England community.
WASHINGTON, April 2--A House investigating subcommittee urged Congress today to go to the rescue of the disappearing family farms in the United States.
For expert picking a nod should go to a West Coast reader.

ROME, April 2--Millions of European television viewers tonight watched Pope Pius XII as he attended a concert in Vatican City. The Pope, who is a music lover, was shown in some candid shots marking time with his folded hands.

KATHARINE CORNELL made her dramatic debut on television last night in her stage success "The Barretts of Wimpole Street." There can be no doubt that she will be back again, even if last night's production was just a little disappointing.
ORLANDO, Fla., April 2-- Senator Estes Kefauver challenged his native southland today to adopt a liberal policy in the segregation controversy.
MOSCOW, April 2--Many victims of illegal arrest by the secret police are being freed in Soviet Georgia under a new policy enunciated at the Communist party congress in February.
Mayor Wagner sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday an executive budget of $1,917,224,418 for the fiscal year starting July 1.
TOKYO, April 3--Japan and South Korea agreed last night to release and repatriate most of the citizens of each the other holds.

A wide selection of chemicals, metals, oils, papers, steels and lumbers made strong gains yesterday and The New York Times industrial and combined averages both ascended to new historic highs.

THE winning horse players thought it was a glorious opening to the New York racing season yesterday. But they were definitely in the minority. Most of the mob recognized Jamaica for what it was--cold, bleak and unattractive.
THE Monsignore Restaurant has a delightful new home at 61 East Fifty-fifth Street. The same accommodating waiters, speaking Italian among themselves, serve with unobtrusive skill.

One symbol of the vast tragedy wrought by the Second World War has disappeared from the European scene as a result of the closing by the German Government of the last "displaced person" camp.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2--The United States lined up today with non-administrator delegations in the Trusteeship Council.
The General Electric Company is planning to raise $300,000,000 in the public market by the sale of long-term debentures.
KANSAS CITY, April 2 (AP)-- Bill Russell led the College AllStars to an 86-79 victory over the Buchan Bakers of Seattle tonight as the United States Olympic play-offs opened.

A horde of happy horse players--40,492 of them--stormed Jamaica race track yesterday. It was the opening day of the 1956 season, the first full season under the promotion of the Greater New York Association, Inc.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., April 2 --The country home here of Billy Rose, New York showman, was destroyed by fire early today. A large collection of marble statues and oil paintings was burned, but big statues outside were saved.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru in effect rejected today the idea of holding a plebiscite in Kashmir to determine whether the disputed territory should go to India or Pakistan.

SAMARRA, Iraq, April 2-- King Faisal II dedicated a dam on the River Tigris here today that is the key element of a huge flood-control system planned to save thousands of lives and millions of dollars.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2--Influential Latin American diplomats complain that Washington is slighting its friends of the Western hemisphere on the economic assistance front.

Murray and Edward Levy, representing the family ownership of the former building concern of Kidansky Levy, have sold the four six-story apartment houses at 745-57 Second Avenue and 237-45 East Fortieth Street to Maurice Epstein, president of Seventh Estates, Inc.
There are few developments in the field of trade and finance more dramatic and more satisfying than the growth of Canada. The postwar upsurge has rightly caught the imagination of the world.
MADISON, Wis., April 2-- Wisconsin's Presidential primaries tomorrow gives the state's farmers an opportunity to express their opinion on the Eisenhower Administration's farm policy.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 2-- In a day marked by numerous bombings, British authorities were forced today to close two schools in Paphos and to impose the second curfew on the Limassol business district in as many days.
The National Collegiate swimming championships at Yale last week-end were highly provocative from many points of, view in this Olympic year.
LONDON, April 3--The United States offered today a draft disarmament treaty that was described as combining the best features of proposals made so far by the East and the West.

Combined net operating earnings of the First National City Bank of New York and of the affiliated City Bank Farmers Trust Company in the first quarter increased to $12,337,572 from $9,077,186 last year. The net is equal to $1.23 a share, compared with 91 cents a share a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, April 3--Dr. Eugene M. Kulischer, one of the world's leading population experts, died here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

All who are familiar with the long record of the National Jewish Welfare Board in its services to our armed forces and to the Jewish community centers of this country will watch with interest the proceedings of the board's biennial convention opening tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Some 1,000 delegates--all leaders in their respective communities--will converge upon New York City for this event.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3--Don Larsen, a Yankee righthanded pitcher, appeared none the worse today following an early morning automobile crackup.
The Navy expects Operation Deep Freeze to produce scientific material of vast importance and to make it possible to explore the few unexplored areas of the Antarctic.
HAVANA, April 3--A military conspiracy to seize control of the Cuban Government was frustrated today, the Army announced tonight.

WHAT a charming play "A Month In the Country" is! When Turgenev wrote it in 1850, it must have seemed like a breath of fresh air, for no one in any nation was writing so sensibly then. Even now it seems like a breath of fresh air.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Army Chief of Staff, asserted today the Nike anti-aircraft guided missile was effective against any "currently operational aircraft, regardless of height and speed."
The Cominform publication has reported a purge of the Greek Communist party leadership, which directed the Greek Communist revolution of 1946 to 1949.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- Five small fires, all of which were quickly smothered and did no damage, were set in the White House and the Executive Offices of the President by a woman visitor today.

CHICAGO, April 3--"Gradualism" in the application of antisegregation laws was rejected today by twenty Negro clergymen from eleven states. They met here to draw up "Negroes' Declaration of Intention."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 3 --In its essence Titoism is not an original dogma but a new practice of the old Communist orthodoxy. Moscow, Vatican of the Marxist world, has not accepted Tito's interpretation of doctrine but has acknowledged that even his heresy can attain communism's ultimate goals.

An official of a stevedore concern told a Waterfront Commission hearing yesterday about large sums of money given to ship captains in the form of gratuities and known as funds for "the captain's hat."

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 3--Bill Pollack, junior right-hander, pitched and batted Upsala College's baseball team to its fifth straight victory this season as the Vikings defeated Williams, 8--3, today.
Last year was the most profitable for the New York Stock Exchange since 1929, Keith Funston, president, said yesterday in his annual report.
ALGIERS, Algeria, April 3-- Recent developments have focused attention on the attempts of two rival organizations to dominate the nationalist rebellion in Algeria.
MOSCOW, April 3--The Soviet leaders applied themselves tonight to the task of promoting neutralism in Northern and Western Europe.

DURING the last ten years a dozen or more Italian novelists have been introduced to American readers. All of those whose books I have read have been blessed with substantial talent, but most of them have written grimly realistic studies of poverty and the least attractive aspects of the mating instinct.

STATE Public Works Departpartment crews began yesterday to cover up some of the ugly trash-and-garbage dumps along the banks of the Beaverkill and the end of a weary fight may be in sight.

WASHINGTON, April 3--An examiner recommended today that the Civil Aeronautics Board authorize a third carrier to fly the New York-Miami run. He favored Delta Air Lines, Inc. over seven other applicants. Important Changes Proposed
WASHINGTON, April 3-- President Eisenhower said today that a dollar spent on foreign aid and in the telling of America's success story abroad was worth $5 laid out on armaments.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- Representative Howard W. Smith, author of the Smith Act, called today for a law to allow state prosecution of persons seeking violent overthrow of the Government.

CHICAGO, April 3--All deliveries of wheat touched new highs for the season today on the Board of Trade, although prices later slipped. May wheat was extremely tight at times and moved up on short covering.

Hamilton, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 25 on an issue of $4,000,000 of first mortgage electric plant system revenue bonds dated April 1, 1956 and maturing serially on April 1 and Oct. 1 from 1957 to 1976.

VIENNA, April 3--Bulgaria has now restored to grace the name of a leader who was executed for high treason and Titoism. The Central Committee of the Bulgarian Communist party cleared a former Deputy Premier, Traicho Kostov, who was put to death in 1949.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Secretary of State Dulles issued a reminder today that the Soviet Union still was in the grip of dictatorship and still following "predatory policies" despite the repudiation of part of Stalin's tyranny.
Dr. Manuel De Moya Alonzo, Secretary of State Without Portfolio in the Dominican Republic, has denied that that Government was responsible for the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez.

MOSCOW, April 3--The planned destruction of the Stalin legend took two more steps forward today. Krasnaya Zvevda, organ of the Defense Ministry, charged that blind subservience to Stalin had led to stagnation and outright distortions in Soviet science, particularly the art of warfare.
The Government's experimental program to give its fleet of laid-up Liberty ships potentially higher speed and greater commercial usefulness will reach the sea-going stage this month.

LONDON, April 3--"Troilus and Cressida," plucked from its classical setting and staged in modern dress, opened at the Old Vic tonight. The critics here, usually uncomfortable with unconventional staging of Shakespeare, thoroughly approved.
BOSTON, April 3 (UP)--The world and Olympic figure skating champion, Hayes Alan Jenkins, termed the Amateur Athletic Union code "unrealistic" today and said he had lost money on his expense account.
Mrs. Shirley Ayers is arranging to enter the managerial field next season. She is the widow of Lemuel Ayers, producer and an outstanding scenery-costume designer.
A union meeting delayed the opening of Macy's a half hour yesterday morning.

The Armor Elevator Company, in an expansion move, has purchased the one-story building at 35-30 Thirty-sixth Street in Long Island City, Queens, from the Foremost Milk Company, Inc. The property immediately adjoins the excutive offices and shops of the buyer.

The American Association of University Professors was asked yesterday to censure American University in Washington, for dismissing Prof. Herbert Fuchs. He admitted he had been a Communist and named former associates in the party.

Magistrate J. Randall Creel took a second step in what he calls "Operation Birthright and Heritage" yesterday. He ordered a young defendant to write a song about St. Augustine, Fla., and make the Spaniards who settled there as popular as Davy Crockett.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 --A television code of principles designed as a guide to production has been completed and is ready for presentation to the industry.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 4 (AP)--The United States men's team suffered its second defeat in four matches in the world table tennis championships today, while the American women, after losing their first three matches, collected their second straight triumph.

ST. LOUIS, April 3--The enrollment in Roman Catholic schools and colleges has reached a record of 4,500,000, it was reported here today. By 1960 this figure is expected to have increased by 1,000,000 additional.

No price trend appeared in the stock market yesterday, although the averages declined Slightly. Volume fell to 2,760,000 shares from 3,120,000 on Monday, and prices jogged a little lower as 617 issues fell and only 354 rose of the 1,218 traded.
Municipal Court Justice Carson DeWitt Baker shouldered the blame yesterday for his office staff's failure to answer twenty-four parking and traffic summonses in his name.
LONDON, April 3--Two hundred British civilian policemen have been serving on Cyprus. The first special contingent has been quietly transported to the island in the last three months.

The city moved yesterday to salvage as many new policemen as possible from the Civil Service pool.
WASHINGTON, April 3--An expert in cancer research reported today that control of cancer was a possibility not too remote from accomplishment.
Two runaway baby elephants named Cass and Dale gave thousands of New Yorkers a sidewalk sideshow last night in advance of the circus' televised dress rehearsal in Madison Square Garden.
The men's wear trade yesterday began planning for a "fifth season," designed to increase sales in the summer months and lessen the losses from clearances after Father's Day.

United States Government securities declined sharply in price in the dealers' market yesterday, accentuating a vulnerability to selling which first became visible when major banks raised their lending rates here last week.

DRUMRIGHT, Okla., April 3 (AP)--Relief crews and disaster experts from neighboring towns pitched in to help Drumright clean up today in the wake of a tornado that left five dead and property damage estimated at $1,000,000.

EIGHT of the city's twelve workers in Venetian glass mosaic have just finished one of the most unusual murals ever made for a New York skyscraper. It is an abstract, the creation of Hang Hofmann, 76-year-old German-born painter.
CHICAGO, April 3--Tornadoes, striking the nation's midcontinent for the second successive day, killed at least thirtytwo persons today.
After nearly nine years of "temporary" operation as an air carrier over the Atlantic, Seaboard and Western Airlines will start scheduled services next Tuesday.
A program for a 20 per cent increase in the $125,000,000 annual volume of advertising given to public service causes was announced yesterday by the Advertising Council.

LUBBOCK, Tex., April 3-- Eight straight hits gave the New York Giants nine runs in the second inning today, but it was not until almost three hours later that they fashioned the run that beat the Cleveland Indians, 14--13. An error, two intentional passes and a sacrifice fly went into the production of the deciding counter in the ninth.

Business prospects for the last six months of 1956 are better than those for the first half year, Charles T. Broderick, chief economist for Lehman Brothers, investment banking concern, said yesterday. He spoke at the third annual seminar on new product introduction sponsored by the Hilton Riggio advertising agency in the Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The Government's $12,000,000,000 bank for financing price supports and related farm aid programs is down to $250,000,000.

Things weren't quite back to normal at the Jamaica race track yesterdy. Conn McCreary contributed a front-running performance almost all the way to win the feature. His mount was Bless Pat of the Pin Oak Farm.
DETROIT, April 3 (AP)--Dairy farmers called off their violenceridden milk strike today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland, said tonight the United States should make every effort to keep Russia "and her barbaric goon squads" from the 1956 Olympic Games in Australia.
Mrs. Ruth Cranston, a writer and lecturer on religious subjects, died Monday night in St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. Her home was in Sierra Madre, Calif.
The election of six vestrymen backing the Rev. William Howand Melish, controversial Brooklyn clergyman, was called invalid yesterday by officers of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

MONTREAL, April 3 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens tonight routed the Detroit Red Wings 5--1, and took a 2-0 lead over the defending champions in the four-out-of-seven game Stanley Cup finals.
JERUSALEM, April 3--President Eisenhower's reported decision against the sale of arms to Israel at present was a sharp blow to Premier David Ben-Gurion's Government.
MADRAS cloth proved to be as masculine and bold as sari silk is subtle and feminine during yesterday's showing of men's fashions at the Government of India Trade Center, 19 East Forty-ninth Street.
A bid from West Coast musicians for help in their fight against James Caesar Petrillo, president of the American Fedederation of Musicians, has been turned down by leaders of Local 802 here.

A national campaign for $2,000,000 was opened yesterday by the United Negro College Fund. This goal and New York's quota of $500,000 to help achieve it were announced at a meeting of 1,000 persons in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
John J. O'Rourke seized control of the strife-torn Teamsters Joint Council yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 3--The Soviet Union promised tonight to investigate the disappearance of Raoul Wallenberg, a Swedish diplomat, in Hungary at the end of World War II.

The five college players who will represent this country in the international students' chess tournament beginning in Uppsala, Sweden, tomorrow, left yesterday on an Icelandic Airlines plane from the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
The Communist party and The Daily Worker regained possession of their padlocked premises last night, one week after the quarters were seized by Internal Revenue agents.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 3--The 19-year-old Don Drysdale helped win a ball game today with his pitching and his batting and probably won a spot on the Brooklyn Dodger staff as well.
Tuberculosis deaths in New York City did not decline significantly in 1955 from the previous year for the first time since the advent of the antimicrobial drug treatment.

A one-story garage containing about 6,700 square feet of space at 575 Water Street has been purchased by Frederick Brown, real estate operator and investor, from the J.A. Kennedy Realty Corporation. The property, which has a frontage of ninety-three feet in the block between Clinton and Montgomery Streets, is presently occupied by the Tidewater Terminals Transportation Company. The lessee will give occupancy to the buyer on July 1.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3--The Yankees ended their spring activities at Al Lang Field today on a rather sour note.

Heavy commission house liquidation, trade selling and stoploss ordering tumbled all cocoa futures the 1-cent-a-pound limit during trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Scale-down short covering, profit taking and manufacturer buying for price fixing raised prices from the lows of the day toward the close.

If the members of Congress who are now back home enjoying the Easter recess have discovered that their constituents are none too pleased with what's been going on at the Capitol, no one should be surprised. For the second session of the Eighty-fourth Congress, about to begin its final lap, has a remarkably thin record even for an election year.
Grace Kelly, screen actress, will sail at noon today for Europe to be married to Prince Rainier III of Monaco. Her parents and sixty members of her wedding party will go with her.

A COOK can sign her own personalized signature to a cake baked from a standardized mix by covering it with a fine, homemade frosting. The frosting gives her, in fact, chance to individualize a cake, whether it be of the quick-mix variety or purchased from a local bakery.
Park and Tilford Distillers Corporation filed a $90,000,000 civil anti-trust suit yesterday in Federal court against four major world distillers and ten subsidiaries.

When the Russian spokesman in the Security Council yesterday began to speak on the pending United States resolution on the Mideastern crisis it was clear that he was playing the same old tune on the same old balalaika. Mr. Sobolev was, of course, listening to the voice, or voices, from home. This voice or voices did not sound too different from what used to be heard when Mr. Stalin arranged the words and music.

OXFORD, Md., April 3--Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene today at noon for the marriage of Miss Nancy Elizabeth Webb to Thomas Lennan Lincoln. The Rev. Parker Crosby Webb, father of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Lyman C. Bleecker.
WASHINGTON, April 3--Secretary of State Dulles said today that President Eisenhower would prefer to have Congressional authority before committing United States troops in any Middle East crisis.

NAHA, Okinawa, April 3--They American Deputy Governor of the Ryukyu Islands, exhorted the Legislature today to "develop a greater awareness" of Communist infiltration of the civil population of this base.

SEATTLE, April 3 (UP)-- Northwest Airlines said today that faulty wing flaps might have caused the ditching of a Stratocruiser in Puget Sound yesterday. Thirty-three persons were rescued, four drowned and a crewman still is missing.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday to close 4 points higher to 11 points lower than on Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 3-- President Eisenhower issued today an executive order setting up the Federal Council on Aging.

NEWARK, April 3--The first section of the Newark Bay-Hudson County extension of the New Jersey Turnpike will be opened to traffic tomorrow. It extends from Newark Airport east to Avenue E. Bayonne, a distance of 3.6 miles.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, April 4--President Eisenhower appeared this morning to have polled about 55 per cent in yesterday's Wisconsin Presidential primary election.
TRENTON, April 3--New Jersey henceforth will recruit most of its state employes from the graduating classes of colleges and universities throughout the country.

It is good news that the veteran career officer Willard Beaulac has been named United States Ambassador to Argentina. The news is good on two counts: first, because Mr. Beaulac is one of the most able American diplomats in the career service, with a long and fine record in Latin America, and secondly, because the Buenos Aires post needs a fresh start.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 3--The Soviet Union accused "certain Western states" today of having planned armed intervention in the Middle East. It charged that this violated the rights of the Arab countries.

EUGENE ORMANDY and the Philadelphia Orchestra saw to it at their final Carnegie Hall concert of the season last night that they will be remembered until next fall. They gave a resplendent performance of Mozart's great Mass in C minor.
ST. LOUIS, April 3 (AP)--The Justice Department, rejecting a grand jury's recommendation, has decided to end the panel's inquiry into tax-fixing in the Truman Administration.
Governor Harriman said yesterday he would act on the $40,000,000 Republican income tax cut bill by the end of this week.

LENINGRAD, U.S.S.R., March 31--City officials hope to have the housing problem solved in five to seven years, the director of the Committee for Relations with Foreigners asserted today.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 3--Senator Estes Kefauver called on leaders of both races in the South tonight to start on a 'grass-roots dialogue" looking to the solution of the integration problem.

NORMAN WELLS, Northwest Territory, April 2--Governor General Vincent Massey visited this far northern oil field today. The field supplies much of the gasoline and oil required on the Defense Early Warning line.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- President Eisenhower established today a new National Committee for the Development of Scientists and Engineers. Its job will be to "foster the development of more highly qualified technological manpower."

Patronesses have been announced for the annual spring festival for the benefit of the organ fund of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church. The benefit is scheduled to take place in the parish house of the church the afternoon and evening of April 26 and the afternoon of April 27.

Investors have been showing a marked interest in shells--corporate shells--because of their name value and their listings on major exchanges. In at least two recent cases, financial operators have bid for the residue of companies after the physical assets were sold.

When the New York Legislature adjourned on March 23 it had passed 1,288 bills, most of its lawmaking completed as usual in the last few days of the session, which began on Jan. 4. Before adjournment Governor Harriman had a chance to act on only 187 laws approved and ten vetoed.

ALBANY, April 3--The already muddled state income tax picture has been further complicated by Governor Harriman's failure to act on a bill that could mean substantial benefits to New York taxpayers who received sick pay from their employers in 1955.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 --Ben Gazzara and Jack Garfein, star and director, respectively, of the 1953 Broadway presentation of "End as a Man," will make their screen debuts in the film version to be produced by Sam Spiegel.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 3-- Another name was added today to the list of innocent dead from terrorist bombing and sniping in Cyprus.

Some of the economies claimed by Mayor Wagner for his $1,917,224,418 executive budget for 1956-57 were branded yesterday as nonsense.
RABAT, French Morocco, April 3--Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef said tonight that he was going to Madrid tomorrow with the aim of assuring recognition of Moroccan independence and unity.

THE voice on the car radio was droning away last week. However, only the last few words registered: "* * * in Augusta, the golfing capital of the nation." The description struck home immediately. Starting tomorrow on the artfully tailored Augusta National links, the golfing capital of the nation actually will be where the man said.
LONDON, April 4 (Reuters) --Louis Armstrong, gravel-voiced king of the hot trumpeters, will tour Britain next month, it was announced here today.
New York will get a stage version of Nelson Algren's prizewinning novel "The Man With the Golden Arm" during the week of May 20.
A heavy fog and wet grounds forced the postponement of the Columbia-Manhattan College baseball game at Baker Field yesterday.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., April 4--An estate of $7,000,000 was left by Daniel C. Jackling, San Francisco mining engineer, according to his will filed in San Mateo County Superior Court here today. He died on March 13 at the age of 86.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 --A healthy upsurge in the employment of writers in Hollywood television has been reported by the Western branch of the Writers Guild of America.

Escanaba, Mich., borrowed $7,000,000 in the bond market yesterday on an issue of electric utility revenue obligations due serially from 1959 to 1987. The city sold the securities at public sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by F.S. Smithers Co. at an interest cost of 3.89 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The Secret Service said today its agents still were checking into the illness of three persons who drank ginger ale aboard a private railroad car later used by President Eisenhower.

The results of the Wisconsin primary don't prove very much, but they do give Senator Kefauver another important psychological boost. As usual in elections in which there is no clear-cut contest, the many cross-currents affecting voters' decisions in Wisconsin make it difficult to reach meaningful conclusions. Yet there are inferences that can fairly be drawn even from this primary.

Income of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, will continue to rise this year, David G. Hill, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. BONN, Germany, April 4-- The mystery of who bombed Freiburg May 10, 1940, was cleared up today. It was Hermann Goering's Luftwaffe, the terror of Europe then, and not the Allies, as had been charged.

WASHINGTON, April 4-- William Swift, Securities and Exchange Commission trial examiner, has stricken from a hearing record a charge by Robert R. Young that Randolph Phillips was a "liar."

BUENOS AIRES, April 4 (U.P.) --The Government announced today that it would welcome the participation of private capital in the development of commercial air transport in Argentina.
Members of the Women's Council of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York will hold their annual luncheon and card party today at the headquarters of the institute at 25 South Street.

THE month of April has been chosen by a new group of in terior designers for presentation of their first collective effort. Twelve room settings by the Interior Designers Associates, composed of professional decorators who live and practice in Fairfield County, Conn., will be on view to the public through April 30 at the Silvermine Guild Hall and Galleries, Norwalk, Conn.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- Bulgaria has sounded out the United States on the possibility of restoring diplomatic relations between the two countries after a six-year breach.
WASHINGTON, April 4--A sentimental journey to yesteryear reached the Library of Congress today on a mile of nostalgic microfilm.

Dr. Carl Frederick Floe has been elected a director of the Walworth Company, manufacturer of vales and pipe fittings. Dr. Floe is professor of metallurgy and assitant provost at the Massachusetts Instiute of Technology. He is also a director of the New England Materials Laboratory.
HAVANA, April 4--Military authorities today prepared to court-martial Army officers arrested late yesterday on a charge of conspiring to overthrow the Government of President Fulgencio Batista.
President Eisenhower was compared unfavorably with former President Truman last night because of his position on racial desegregation in the South's public schools.

An elephantine fog sat down heavily on New York yesterday. The gray mist sheared off the tops of the city's towers, pinned down commercial air travel, held the Cunard Line's Queen Elizabeth in her berth and delayed Staten Island ferryboats.
CHICAGO, April 4--Wheat futures rose sharply again today, led by the May, which was extremely tight as shorts grew alarmed over the steady decrease in local stocks.
The proposal for a 415-car parking garage in the heart of the Grand Central zone was killed yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

The Southern Pacific Company, the nation's second largest railroad (after the Santa Fe), has a firm policy that if it is going to lose traffic it might as well "lose it to ourselves."
The market for basic investment yields showed signs of stabilizing yesterday after a week of heaviness.

TODAY, 11:30 A.M.: Two stories will be told at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. Story hours will also be given on Friday and Saturday at the same hour. Following this on Saturday, a live-animal program will be offered at 1:15 P.M., cultural history, science and planetarium demonstrations at 2:30, 3 and 3:30 P.M. Free.

The Babcock Wilcox Company, whose current backlog of orders totals $286,000,000, will spend a record amount this year on capital expansion of its boiler and general industrial production.

The executive committee of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches met yesterday with members of that denomination who oppose a plan for its union with the Evangelical and Reformed Church. Joseph Asch, rainwear and sports clothes manufacturer, died Tuesday, night, apparently of a heart attack, while presiding at a meeting of the board of directors of Congregation Anshe Sholom in Kew Gardens, Queens.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The government, in a formal warning to the public, said today that the Hoxsey cancer treatment was worthless and in some cases might actually speed the growth of cancer.

A three-week-old girl was burned fatally yesterday in a fire that caused considerable damage to an apartment in a two-story frame house at 26 Jewel Street, in the Greenpoint district of Brooklyn.

KEEPING apace with all the news of sports is far from easy for a fellow flitting about the baseball camps. This is especially true of some seemingly inconsequential items, those that barely ripple the surface but, like icebergs, are of monumental size down below. That's how this tourist foundered when he belatedly crashed into the news that Joe Louis has turned wrestler.
ALGIERS, April 4--The French drive against nationalist rebels in Algeria continued to gain momentum today.

The Sanitation Department reported "good cooperation" yesterday from upper East Side motorists on experimental limited parking, which it hopes will simplify street cleaning.

The appointment of A.E. Bollengier as vice president of the Magna Theatre Corporation was announced yesterday by George P. Skouras, president. Mr. Bollengier succeeds Malcolm Kingsberg, who has resigned.

CHICAGO, April 4--Bosom boards were identified at Sears, Roebuck general offices as a cardboard stiffener for the inside of men's dress shirts. They were slipped inside a man's beruffled shirt to keep it very stiff when worn.

The six-story commercial building on plot 50 by 100 feet at 5153 Leonard Street has been purchased by John S. Kroese, president of the Gaffney-Kroese Electrical Supply Corporation. The concern will move to the Leonard Street building from its present quarters at 25 West Broadway.

Many prominent patrons and patronesses have been announced for the United States premiere of "Madame Butterfly" at the Baronet Theatre on April 23. TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 4 (AP)-- The United States Air Force today opened its new Taiwan (Formosa) headquarters on the outskirts of Taipei. It formerly occupied an old silk factory. The new headquarters of twenty onestory buildings has a library, chapel, post exchange, barber shop and mess hall.

The appointment of J. Willard O"Brien as editor-in-chief of The Fordham Law Review was announced yesterday by John F.X. Finn, dean of the Fordham University School of Law. He will edit the quarterly from September, 1956, to June, 1957.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, music director of the Philharmonic-Symphony, returns to the orchestra next week to conduct the final three weeks of its season.

Electric power production in the week ended on Saturday declined to 10,992,000,000 kilowatt hours from 11,134,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, April 4 (AP)-- The Phillips 66ers won the United States Olympic basketball trial play-offs tonight. But the Oilers had to sit on the sidelines for a couple of hours before they learned they were the tournament victors.

Cocoa futures closed higher yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, following six trading days of declines. Prices opened in new low ground on continued long speculator liquidation. Short covering-and hedge lifting reversed the trend.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 17 points down to 3 points up yesterday.

ALBANY, April 4 (AP)--Governor Harriman today proclaimed this week "Boys Club Week" in New York. The national organization, comprising about 450 clubs, is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary this year. Fifty-eight of the clubs are in New York.

The United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners announced last night that it had rigned a national agreement designed to give union carpenters first call on construction jobs. The union said the pact would apply even in eighteen states with "right to work" laws that prohibit any form of compulsory union membership.

Singing was just about the best way for one Girl Scout to find another Girl Scout yesterday at Camp High Rock in New Dorp, S.I. Nobody could see through the fog, and radar was not part of the twentythree-pound pack that each teen-age girl carried to the expedition.

American Viscose Corporation spent $10,700,000 for expansion. replacement and modernization of its manufacturing and research facilities last year, Frank H. Reichel, chairman, reported to stockholders yesterday.
