Informal opinions at Jamaica race track yesterday indicate that the rule making last place mandatory for a horse that fouls may be in for a change. However, few of those on the professional side of racing were sure that the change, if made, would be a good thing.
Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmierl rebuked defense counsel yesterday for permitting John J. O'Rourke to take over the presidency of the Teamsters Joint Council despite a restraining order.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 5 (AP)--The Philadelphia Warriors broke a four-year jinx tonight as they beat the Fort Wayne Pistons, 107--105, for a 3--1 lead in their best-of-seven National Basketball Association championship series. Paul Arizin scored 30 points.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)-- Clarence G. Morse, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, disclosed today that the Government might sell, "in the next few days," ten of its Mariner-class cargo vessels to Pacific Steamship Lines.

Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., investment bankers, and a small group of associates have acquired a 40 per cent interest in the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company through the purchase of all the outstanding stock (4,000 shares) of Sugar Securities Corporation.
QUANTICO, Va., April 5--It will be with a sense of awe that competitors in the Marine Corps Schools Relays trace footsteps in the new Butler Stadium track tomorrow and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The Office of Defense Mobilization today opened a study of the domestic watch and clock industry to determine whether competing imports threaten national security. The study is the first to be ordered by the O.D.M. under the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act since that statute was renewed last year by Congress.

Henry Jaffe, show business attorney, has submitted his resignation as counsel for the New York local of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. It is expected that the resignation will be accepted at a board of directors meeting today.
An analysis of recent events in Argentina will be published May 10 by Praeger under the title "Argentine Upheaval: Peron's Fall and the New Regime."
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) --Poliomyelitis cases fell 23 per cent in the "disease year" just ended, the Public Health Service announced today.
Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange must come to at least 3,000,000 shares a day to maintain "minimum liquidity," Keith Funston declared yesterday.
Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume improved in most markets.
Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that the city's teachers must drop their two-year-old boycott of extracurricular activities.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP)-- The United States Court of Appeals today affirmed an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission barring a New York company from dealing in securities on the ground it "churned" customers' accounts.

As the result of complaints from five city hospitals, the Controller's office put a stop yesterday on the delivery to hospitals of glass syringes sold to the city by a Queens concern. The complaints had dated to February, 1955.

Mrs. Belmont J. Evans' Pink Tea took the feature at Jamaica yesterday. To the majority of the 24,279 customers, no horse could be less aptly named, for the afternoon was anything except a pink tea for turf students who actually believe in figures.

While Vassily Smyslov of Russia played a draw with Paul Keres, Russia, and held first place with a score of 4--2, Dr. Miroslav Filip of Czechoslovakia made the biggest gain in the sixth round of the world championship challengers' chess tournament in Amsterdam, according to a report from the Netherlands yesterday.
LONDON, April 5--The United States informed the Soviet Union today it was ready and willing to join in the first stage of an agreed world disarmament plan "as rapidly" as such a plan could be set up.

The Allegheny County, Pa., Sanitary Authority announced yesterday plans for borrowing $25,000,000 on sewer revenue bonds on May 1. The securities will be dated June 1, 1956, and will come due serially on June 1 from 1961 to 1996.
GENICHIRO INOKUMA, who signs himself "Guen," is a Japanese painter and teacher having his first exhibition in the United States at the Willard Gallery, 23 West Fifty-sixth Street.
Cotton futures advanced 4 to 33 points (20 cents to $1.65 a bale) yesterday, with new crop months strongest.

NEW ORLEANS, April 5-- The Dodgers and Braves played peacefully at Pelican Field today, but the pitching left something to be desired. Each team produced two home runs and the Braves won, 8--6. Two of Milwaukee's three errors made two Brooklyn runs unearned.
ST. LOUIS, April 5--The New York City public school system was urged today to adopt a controversial report providing for the teaching of moral and spiritual values.

ONCE upon a time not so many years ago a good proportion of the excitement in fiction was caused by villains acting villainously. Today, although villains are not yet extinct, much literary excitement is produced by psychopaths acting psychopathically. The results may not be any more dramatic, but they usually are much more intellectually interesting.
Jonas C. Andersen, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb Co., investment bankers, died Wednesday in his home at 420 East Twenty-third Street after a long illness. His age was 62.
PARIS, April 5--Robert Lacoste, French Minister Residing in Algeria, won approval today for his plan to send 100,000 more French troops to Algeria to quell the rebellion there.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Friday, April 6--Ceylon's ruling party is losing the national elections to a coalition pledged to the nationalization of plantations and the ouster of the British from air and naval bases here.

A tract of thirty-two acres on Central Avenue, near South Street, in New Providence, N.J., has been purchased by the New York Life Insurance Company for improvement with a onestory building to house its expanding records division.
Lieut. Col. William R. Fitzgerald, a cancer victim whose vocal cords were removed four years ago, returned yesterday to the hospital here where he had learned to talk anew.
COLUMBIA, S.C., April 5-- Olin D. Johnston and Strom Thurmond were virtually assured today of re-election to the Senate.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 5--A cease-fire arranged by United Nations officials tonight appeared to have ended a flare-up in the Negev.
A venture in color photo evangelism by the Southern Baptist Convention--the largest church body in the South--was previewed yesterday.
DETROIT, April 5 (AP)--John W. Rouse bowed today to his neighbors' belief that he and his family are Negroes.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 5--Soviet Communists abroad have received copies of Nikita S. Khrushchev's recent address downgrading Stalin.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 5-- Explorers of the atom's nucleus have discovered a nuclear "jungle" peopled by strange creatures that canont be fitted into any of the known categories of the physical universe.
Sales of the W.T. Grant Company, variety retail chain, reached a new high of $351,848,626 in the year ended Jan. 31.

ABOUT 100,000 anglers will be pursuing 255,000 hatch ery-bred trout and a few wild ones tomorrow morning when the season opens in New Jersey's streams and lakes. The angler figure is an educated guess by the state's conservation department. The trout were counted.

RUDOLF FIRKUSNY gave a lift to last night's Phil harmonic concert at Carnegie Hall with an exciting performance of Brahms' D minor Concerto. He is a pianist of temperament, and he brought poetry and dramatic tension to a work that demands a commingling of tenderness and passion.
Loans to business outstanding on the books of leading New York City banks dropped $251000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (UP)--A committee member for the West Coast Relays at Fresno suggested to the Amateur Athletic Union today that it "go jump in the lake" after the A.A.U. asked to see a detailed financial report on its expenditures for competing athletes.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 5 --George Breen, the United States' new swimming marvel, tonight set his second world distance mark within a week.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 5-- The specter of Japanese competition hung heavily over the nation's cotton textile manufacturers as they opened their annual meeting here today.

The formal blessings of the Security Council will follow Dag Hammarskjold as he starts off for the Middle East today. It is true that the unanimous vote on the United States resolution which sends the Secretary General to report on Middle Eastern conditions was accepted by Russia with obvious reluctance after a futile attempt at amendment.
LIMA, Peru, April 5--Pedro Beltran, standard bearer of the democratic opposition in Peru, announced today he would not run for President.
Michael J. Quill met with a warm--in fact, heated--reception yesterday on a noontime visit to the I.R.T. car shop at Lenox Avenue and 145th Street.
Artful dodgers demonstrated yesterday that it would take more than warning signs and steel fencing to keep them out of the core of Columbus Circle.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5--Ken Venturi, a 24-year-old amateur from San Francisco, set the pace with a six-under-par 66 in the opening round of the Masters golf tournament today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 --Paramount has bought "Joey," a recent television play, as a future picture prospect for Anthony Perkins, young actor being groomed by the studio for stardom.
"Affair of Honor," starring Dennis King, will have its delayed premiere at 8 o'clock this evening at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.
WASHINGTON, April 5--The Maryland city of Hagerstown will be honored here tomorrow night for its remarkable fouryear friendship with Wesel, Germany.
RALEIGH, N.C., April 5-- The North Carolina Advisory Committee on Education recommended tonight, in effect, that segregation be continued in the public schools next year.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy promoted forty-eight members of the force yesterday and then transferred seventeen high-ranking officers.
THE first shad ventured up the Hudson River earlier this week and were snared off Edgewater, N.J. Starting a week from Monday, Harry Lyons predicts, Hudson shad will be abundant in local stores.
WASHINGTON, April 5-- Manufacturing and trade inventories rose by $700,000,000 in February. This figure caused mild concern among economists here today.
A New York educator outlined last night three factors that have created problems and anxieties among the youth of today.
ROME, April 5--The discovery in Rome of a catacomb hitherto unknown to scholars was announced today by L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The irritation the President displayed at his news conference yesterday, when asked whether he might order the Sixth Marines into military action in the Mediterranean area, must have been the result of the words in which the question was phrased.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 5--Old drawings found in an attic here are adding laurels to a deceased artist whose prime job had been to make persons laugh.
THE Chicago artist Margo Hoff is holding her first New York show of paintings at the Barone Gallery, 202 East Fifty-first Street.
GENEVA, April 5--A greatly enlarged United Nations Economic Commission for Europe opened its eleventh session here today.

The British Government has arranged consultations with Soviet Russia on the deteriorating situation in Vietnam. It is now obvious that the "free general elections by secret ballot" for the unification of Vietnam, provided by the Geneva ceasefire agreement of 1954 for July this year, will not be held.

DETROIT, April 5 (UP)--Ted Lindsay and Gordie Howe fired third-period goals tonight to pace Detroit to a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens and lift the Red Wings' sagging hopes for a third straight Stanley Cup championship.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 5 (AP)--Shelley Mann today was dethroned by a 13-year-old Californian in the 400-yard individual medley of the women's Amateur Athletic Union national indoor swimming championships.

CHICAGO, April 5--All deliveries of wheat and soybeans made new highs for the crop today on the Board of Trade. All corn futures except the May delivery also set highs, as did September and December oats and most rye futures.
MADRID, April 5--Generalissimo Francisco Franco told Moroccan leaders today that Spain was determined to respect Morocco's independence and territorial unity.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 5 --The Army football squad, which has been thwarted by the weatherman for three weeks, held its first spring practice drill today.
NAHAL OZ, Israel, Friday, April 6--The Gaza Strip was completely quiet early this morning after a day of ominous incidents that again brought Israel and Egypt to the brink of war.
Victor Riesel once said that a man's tears made him a supporter of labor.
New historic highs were made yesterday by The New York Times industrial and combined stock averages--but they lasted only briefly.
Man will become a space traveler "within a generation or so" and may do his exploring in an atomic-powered craft, according to an atomic scientist.

"HORSE racing is a disease, especially for an owner," said Bill Cane over and over. No one had more justifi cation for repeating that sentence than he because the man who was known as Mr. Trotting was hopelessly incurable.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (AP) --Vic Mitchell of San Diego, Calif., eliminated the Canadian champion, David McTaggart of Vancouver, tonight in the men's singles quarter-finals of the United States open badminton championships.

A big new sugar refinery-- eventually to be one of the world's largest--is helping Venezuela to meet her consumption needs. The mill, Hacienda el Palmar in San Hateo, is processing 4,000 tons of sugar cane a day into 360 tons of raw sugar.

BONN, Germany, April 5-- The Forgign Ministry sharply criticized Guy Mollet, French Premier, today for apparently having downgraded the reunification of Germany as an objective of international policy.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 5--Donald T. Carlisle, a frequent writer on naturalist topics and since 1945 a vice president of the New York Zoological Society, died here this evening in St. Francis Hospital after a short illness. He was 61 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 5--A marked trend toward independent voting seems to be modifying, if not destroying, many of the normal political assumptions of both the Republican and Democratic parties.
WASHINGTON, April 5-- Democratic conferees today predicted quick approval in the House of Representatives of a farm bill that President Eisenhower would sign.
AFTER a six-year stint at suit designing Alice Orovan has been wooed and won back by Gunther Jaeckel's fur salon.

The Hathaway Building, a twelve-story structure on plot 81 by 100 feet at 49 to 53 West Forty-fifth Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, has been sold by the W.A. Hathaway Company, furniture dealers.
The General Electric Company has a backlog of large steamturbine generators valued at an estimated $665,000,000.
IF we were to dress ourselves to match the interiors of our homes, many of us would be wearing coonskin hats; for Early American, or colonial furniture remains one of our most popular periods.
LONDON, April 5--A "war alliance" rather than Egypt's purchase of arms from Communist sources is the cause of tension in the Middle East, Georgi M. Malenkov declared today.

Governor Harriman believes the United States must take dynamic action to counter the Soviet Union's new economic and political moves in the underdeveloped countries of Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
MEXICO CITY, April 5--Mexicans were introduced to "Five and Ten" merchandising this morning when F.W. Woolworth Co. opened the first of a projected chain of stores in this country.
LONDON, April 5--Britain and the Soviet Union have agreed in principle to a high level meeting on maintaining the Indochina cease-fire agreement.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 4 --United States-Indonesian relations are at a critical juncture.

The One Hundredth Anniversary of the Charity Ball was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. It attracted a large gathering of members of society, many of them descendants of the men and women who had taken an active interest in furthering the success of the early Charity Balls. The fete served as a benefit for the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.
The uptrend in coal is expected to continue, with a market in the 1965-75 period "far greater than any experienced in the past," Felix E. Wormser, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, said yesterday.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is not confining its equipment purchases to new motive power. This summer, in addition to taking delivery of scores of Diesel locomotives, the road plans to put on the rails one of the cheaper-tobuild-and-operate "trains of tomorrow."

A preliminary accord has been worked out between the Japanese and the Koreans on the return of some nationals of each country held by the other. Japanese fishermen who have been held in Korea for some time are to be returned and some Koreans who have been detained in Japan will be allowed to return to Korea if they wish to do so.
RURAL flavor vanished from New York, especially from Manhattan, long ago, but The Rural New-Yorker, farm journal, has stayed on. Even after 106 years' existence it still flourishes here.
Recently introduced tranquilizing drugs were credited yesterday with having increased significantly the discharge rate of patients in New York State mental hospitals.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti April 5--Considerable political importance is being attached to a visit today by President Paul E. Magloire to Aux Cayes in the south of Haiti.

The Rev. Dr. Miles Lowell Yates, chaplain and Professor of Greek at the General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Avenue, died yesterday in French Hospital after a brief illness. Dr. Yates was 66 years old and lived at 2 Chelsea Square.
MOSCOW, April 5-Pravda's denunciation today of "rotten elements" in the Soviet Communist party was coupled with an attack on local party officials who were tolerating criticism of basic policies.

The way was cleared yesterday for construction work on the first "roll-on, roll-off" trailercarrying ship to receive Federal mortgage insurance as a specialpurpose vessel essential to national defense.
A girl who put her faith in God and The New York Times to restore her lost dog had her faith justified this week. The only role of The Times in the matter lies in reporting the successful mission.
An anonymous donor and Cardinal Spellman have contributed a total of $16,000 on behalf of the families of six firemen who were killed in an East Bronx factory fire Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, April 6--Significant progress toward the development of anatomic-powered airplane was indicated today in the award of a contract that the Air Force will make to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation on Monday.
We'll all wax fat in twentyfour years if Edward T. McCormick is a good prophet.

"THE CITADEL OF LEARNING;" by James Bryant Conant, is certainly the most stimulating and will, I hope, be one of the most influential discussions of education in the clamorous world we know. He can be blunt and suave in the same sentence and he is always persuasive.

Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, criticized yesterday the school of thought here and abroad that contends that the United States "is not equal to its tasks, and that world trends inevitably favor communism."

WASHINGTON, April 6--Representative Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today he would try to unseat Senator Prescott Bush, Republican. Mr. Bush was elected to the Senate by 30,000 votes in 1953 to complete the unexpired term of the late Senator Brien McMahon, a Democrat.
TO GOURMETS, mention of Bresse brings to mind the succulent chickens for which that French region is famed.
Five small motor-cargo ships from the reserve fleet are being reactivated for sale to the Republic of Korea, according to the Maritime Administration.
VIENNA, April 6--Confirmation has been given reports of the release of Wladislaw Gomulka, former Secretary General of the Polish Communist party, who was arrested in 1951 on Stalin's orders.

AS a boy, Neil Hosler McElroy knew the meaning of hard work. He shoveled snow, mowed lawns, worked in a laundry and a can factory. By the time he finished high school, he had saved $1,000, enough to get a good start in college.

Manhattan College's baseball team converted an attempted squeeze play into a double play to gain a 5-5 tie against Columbia University at Baker Field yesterday. The double out brought an end to the nineinning contest because of darkness.

MOAB, Utah, April 6--Mining and metallurgical engineers from all Western states crowded this boom town today to attend the first major uranium conference ever held at this southeastern Utah hub of the ore-rich Colorado River Plateau.
LONDON, April 6--Sir Anthony Eden completed today his first year as Prime Minister. The anniversary was marked by yet another suggestion that he make way for some other Conservative leader.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 6-- Senator Estes Kefauver accused Adlai E. Stevenson today of "mudslinging and character assassination."
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 6--The Baghdad Pact has become a key factor in the critical question of the Middle East's relations with the Western powers and the Soviet bloc.

The City C.I.O. Council has complained to city agencies that the low bidder on hypodermic syringes for the Hospital Department employs nonunion labor and imports substantial parts for its syringes from Japan.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. April 6--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold declared today that his mission to the Middle East had become "all the more imperative" because of the new Israeli-Egyptian clashes.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 --"The Alcoa Hour" will use color for the first time on April 29 when "Paris and Mrs. Perleman" is presented over the National Broadcasting Company television network.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 6 (AP)--Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Herb Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., gained the St. Andrew tennis tournament final today.

The final report growing out of last fall's White House conference on education gives a striking picture of the present state of the public schools and provides firm ground for a new and vigorous drive to get the President's school-aid bill through Congress during the current session.
WASHINGTON, April 6--Investigating Senators unanimously approved today a report deploring tactics employed by some oil and gas men on behalf of the natural gas bill.
The recent exchange of letters between Allen T. Klots, president of the New York City Bar Association, and Harrison Tweed, chairman of...
ALBANY, N.Y., April 6 (AP) --The Public Service Commission today approved, in principle, the second amended plan for reorganizing the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and its affiliates.

Larsen Hurls First 9 Frames and Richardson Bats In 4 Yanks as Phils Lose MOBILE, Ala., April 6--Although the method is scarcely to be commended, uprooting telephone poles may be another way of getting in shape for a baseball season.

WALTER GIESEKING is a recognized old master and a sell-out audience that overflowed the stage came to Carnegie Hall last night to pay homage. It was the German pianist's first solo concert in this country since his accident several months ago. The only visible sign was a bit of adhesive tape covering the head injury he had sustained.
MOSCOW, April 6 (AP)--A Czechoslovak Communist leader said today the Prague regime had investigated and found valid the execution of Rudolf Slansky and Vladimir Clementis.

RALEIGH, N.C., April 6-- Gov. Luther H. Hodges said today he intended to call a special session of the General Assembly to implement recommendations of the North Carolina Advisory Committee on Education.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6--Ken Venturi of San Francisco refused to relinquish the lead in the second round of the Masters golf tournament today.
Dr. Charles Christian Lieb, Hosack Professor Emeritus of Pharmacology at Columbia University, died yesterday in his home at 1 West Seventy-second Street. He would have been 76 years old on April 19.
WASHINGTON, Aprii 6--A joint Congressional conference committee ignored President Eisenhower's pleas today and wrapped up a $3,000,000,000 farm package that would revive rigid price supports.

William Lombardy, the C.C. N.Y. representative on the United States team in the international students' chess tournament at Uppsala, yesterday defeated Wolfgang Pietsch in the second round against East Germany, according to a report from Sweden.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, April 6 --The big United States air base at Keflavik stands astride the Great Circle approach to North America midway between Moscow and New York. Right now its location is "between the devil and the deep" and its future uncertain at best.
Republicans who voted in the Minnesota Democratic Presidential primary did so because they were good neighbors, according to Maryland's Republican Governor, Theodore R. McKeldin.
ST. LOUIS, April 6--Roman Catholic educators were urged today to support the policy of desegregation.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 6-- Alger Hiss, former State Department official convicted of perjury and imprisoned five years ago, is scheduled to speak on the Princeton University campus April 26.

Governor Harriman's approval of the Republican state income tax cut bill was interpreted widely yesterday as a sign that he believed his chances of winning the Democratic nomination for President were getting brighter.
Midafternoon, a 4-year-old colt owned by Mrs. E.E. Robbins, had the Jamaica race track all to himself in the feature event of a mile and a sixteenth yesterday.

The Du Mont Broadcasting corporation announced yesterday the purchase of nearly $500,000 worth of television equipment to increase the power of its two outlets and to introduce color TV on its New York station.

Five investment properties in the North Hudson area of New Jersey have been sold by the Columbia Development Corporation to the Boulevard Realties Holding Company in a transaction negotiated by J.I. Kislak, Inc., as broker.
WASHINGTON, April 6-- President Eisenhower is considering a plan to increase his request for defense appropriations by $550,000,000.

CAIRO, April 6--Egypt bitterly accused Israel today of having made a premeditated attack yesterday on civilians in the Egyptian-held Gaza strip just as the United Nations Secretary General prepared to start his peace mission to the Middle East.

HOUSTON, April 6--Johnny Antonelli, the ace of Bill Rigney's mound staff, made good on a promise today. The southpaw was the major figure in the 13-6 victory the Giants scored today over the Cleveland Indians. And mainly because of Antonelli the New Yorkers' skipper enjoyed a good dinner tonight.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 6--One cannot be a heretic without first practicing orthodoxy.
NEW DELHI, India, April 6-- India and the Soviet Union signed a shipping agreement today for an unlimited period.
The city was asked yesterday to repossess slum-cleared housing sites on which private redevelopers have delayed construction work.
When the wooden Indian was taken in out of the rain he either fell victim to the axe or survived to become the quarry of hunters of unusual game.
A five-story apartment house at 222 East Sixty-seventh Street has been sold by James L. Wilson Jr. to the Raymoy Realty Company, represented by Julius Raynes.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif. April 6 (UP)--A pair of 17-yearold high school students from the East won the honors in the national downhill ski champion ships today.

WASHINGTON, April 6--In an extraordinary demonstration of support for an alliance it has refused to join, the United States is sending Loy W. Henderson to the Baghdad Pact meeting in Teheran, Iran, April 16-20.
Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly higher yesterday.
ALBANY, April 6--Following is the text of the memorandum that accompanied Governor Harriman's approval of the $40,000,000 state income tax reduction bill:
MADRID, April 6--Spanish anti Moroccan representatives were reported today to have struck a snag in negotiations designed to prepare for the end of Spain's rule in northern Morocco.
BOWIE, Md., April 6 (AP)-- Maryland's first $100,000-added handicap horse race drew seven thoroughbreds today.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., April 6 --A spokesman for the raw cotton and allied industries today advocated lower cotton prices as part of a long-range effort to meet the competition of synthetic fibers.
The Biow Company, Inc., one of the nation's oldest and largest advertising agencies, will go out of business on June 30.
New York and New Jersey found themselves at odds yesterday over the across-the-river licensing of Willie Gilzenberg as a wrestling and boxing promoted after New York had revoked his license.
A compromise plan that would give all teachers a pay rise and in addition reward those with considerable extra training has been advocated in an effort to break the salary deadlock.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) --The Armed Services Petroleum Purchasing Agency announced a new policy today of giving Defense Department orders for oil products to refineries qualifying as small businesses.
Four hundred ministers of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church will exchange pulpits tomorrow in a country-wide "get-acquainted" project.
A decision that may vitally affect the State's lower courts was handed down yesterday in Queens County Court by acting Judge Miller B. Moran of Lewis County.
AT the end of the first act of "Affair of Honor," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore last evening, a gentleman remarked to his lady: "There are some phases of this play that remind you of a turkey."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 6--Adlai E. Stevenson started his campaign for support in the South today by declaring that he would not swerve from his belief that the region must conform to the Supreme Court decision outlawing public school racial segregation.
JERUSALEM, April 6--Two breaches of the cease-fire agreement the United Nations truce supervisors had obtained late yesterday were reported today from the Gaza strip.
ALBANY, April 6--Governor Harriman authorized today a $40,000,000 reduction in the state income taxes for 1955. The tax returns are due by April 16.
Eli Lilly Co., announced yesterday that it had arranged to purchase Corn States Laboratories, Inc., of Omaha, Neb., for cash, subject to a final audit.
LONDON, April 6--The stock market was unsettled today by the outbreak of shooting between Israel and Egypt and by yesterday's setback in Wall Street.
An investor has purchased the apartment house at 1290 Lafayette Avenue, the Bronx, from Hellas Realty, Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 6--The Committee for the White House Conference on Education recommended today that expenditures for education be doubled within the next decade.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 6 (AP)--Shelley Mann of the Walter Reed Hospital Swim Club, Washington, winner of three titles last year, scored her first 1956 victory by easily taking the 200-yard butterfly stroke event at the Amateur Athletic Union's women's national indoor swimming and diving championships today.
TUCKAHOE, N.Y., April 6. --A derelict clubhouse that was once a luxurious show place and sports center will be converted into a suburban governmental center.
The producing auspices for "Happy Hunting," the musical comedy that Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse are writing for Ethel Merman, have undergone a change.
Joseph Trerotola was chosen yesterday as acting president of the embattled Teamsters Joint Council with the approval of Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri.
Attacks on the International Labor Organization, spearheaded by the United States Chamber of Commerce, urgently call for a rally in its defense.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. April 6 --Frank Capra, one of the great movie directors and a three-time Academy Award winner, has decided to end his long absence from the motion-picture business. He has made a one-picture contract with Columbia, which had been his home studio for thirteen years until 1939.
CHICAGO, April 6--Rudolph F. Blash, founder of the Webster-Chicago Corporation, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his home at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. His age was 70.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 6 --A world record in the 220-yard butterfly race and the defeat of the defending titleholders in the first three finals of the evening marked the Amateur Athletic Union's national swimming championships tonight.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 6 --Prime Minister Chaudry Mohammed Ali disclosed today that Pakistan's dispute with India over Kashmir would be returned to the United Nations Security Council. The decision to reopen the eight-and-a-half-year-old issue at the United Nations was the climax of a special session of Parliament.
ROCHESTER, April 6--Senator Clinton P. Anderson proposed tonight the establishment of international atomic laboratories.

QUANTICO, Va., Aprll 6--Despite a driving rain that chilled the contestants to the bone and turned portions of the brand-new Butler Stadium track into a quagmire late in the program, the Marine Corps Schools Relays got away to a spectacular start today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6-- A rise in consumer credit was termed today essential for the nation's continued economic expansion.
THE Virtuosi di Roma took a temporary farewell of New York last night with a concert in the Hunter College Auditorium.

The State Tax Commissioner issued the following instructions yesterday after the new income tax cuts became law: If you have already filed your return on the basis of the full tax, sit tight. Your refund will be made automatically...
Cotton futures moved 13 points higher to 10-points lower yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The circus went on last night with some of its tinsel chipped off by union trouble.
TOKYO, April 6 (AP)--The leader of an official United States trade mission told Japan today it must raise the quality of cotton exports to gain a bigger share of the American market.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6-- James M. Skinner Jr. today reached the presidency of the Philco Corporation, a post his father had held from 1929 to 1939.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 6-- The defeat of Ceylon's pro-Western Government was accepted here today as an accomplished fact. But the man scheduled to become the next Prime Minister of this Indian Ocean island gave assurances that his Government would not be anti-Western.
Counsel for the Waterfront Commission yesterday recommended denial of a permanent license as a contracting stevedore to the Jules S. Sottnek Company, Inc.
Miss Carolyn Forrest Murray of 124 East Eighty-fourth Street and James Edward Moore of 136 East Sixty-first Street were married last evening in Christ Church, Methodist.
This is spring cleaning time and millions of American housewives are getting set for their annual battle with a ravenous foe.
THE thousands of rowboat anglers who love the Long Island flounder are just beginning to get the chance denied them recently by foul weather.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 --The Los Angeles County Medical Society has withdrawn its seal of approval from the "Medic" television program "The Glorious Red Gallagher," after the deletion of the filmed scene of a caesarean birth.
WASHINGTON, April 9--In an apathetic atmosphere the Senate opened today its showdown fight with the Administration for the right to some control over the Central Intelligence Agency.
LONDON, April 9--The firmness of Wall Street last Friday and some good dividend statements spurred demand for industrial shares here today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 9-- Two local race tracks have attacked in court the validity of a franchise granted by the Government to the San Juan Racing Association, Inc. The association is building a $5,000,000 track outside Rio Piedras.

WASHINGTON, April 9--The Eisenhower Administration sent its civil rights program to Congress today. The proposals evoked cries of "politics" from right and left-wing Democrats alike, and less than all-out Republican backing.

The case of the five former Soviet seamen who elected to redefect back to Moscow last week-end points up the importance of a disturbing report on Iron Curtain refugees recently prepared by the International Rescue Committee group headed by William J. Donovan.
GENEVA, April 9--The Soviet Minister of Foreign Trade invited Western European countries today to look to Moscow for their needs when dollar aid ran out.
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP)-- The executive committee of the Illinois Central Railroad today authorized the line to spend up to $8,000,000 for stock of the Central of Georgia Railway.
Princeton University decided yesterday not to yield to alumni protests against a scheduled speech by Alger Hiss on the campus April 26. Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of ...
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)-- President Eisenhower nominated Floyd S. Bryant of Atherton, Calif., today to be an Assistant Secretary of Defense. He will succeed Franklin G. Floete.

American Airlines, Inc., achieved record operating revenues and earnings last year, and became the first airline in the world to carry more than 7,000,000 passengers in a single year, the annual report stated yesterday.

HILLSBORO, Ohio, April 9 (AP)--The Hillsboro School Board decided tonight not to ask the Federal Supreme Court for a new hearing on its refusal to review a lower court order directing the immediate integration of more than a score of ...

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 9 (AP)--Industrialist Howard Hughes announced today that he planned to build a manufacturing plant for the design, development and manufacture of airplanes in Florida at a site to be determined later.

WASHINGTON, April 9-- Former President Herbert Hoover will be the lead-off witness Wednesday as Congress again grapples with the question of what should be done if a President is unable to carry on the function of his office.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)-- The Supreme Court released in effect today more than $2,700,000 in escrow funds to the four big dairy farmer cooperatives in the New York milksheds.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 9--It was the turn today of the late Klement Gottwald to be downgraded.

YOUR reviewer is generally abashed on hearing that someone has just finished reading a long book at one sitting or discovered a volume so spectacularly rich in tactile value that none can put it down.
ROME, April 9--Dag Hammarskjold had an audience with Pope Pius XII today before leaving for Beirut, Lebanon, on a Middle East peace mission.
Once the youngest member of the New York Stock Exchange, James Crane Kellogg 3d yesterday was nominated to become its chairman. He is now 40 years old.

MADRID, April 9--To be Foreign Minister under a dictatorship is not only a difficult but often an ungrateful job. Dictators are especially concerned with their own prestige both at home and abroad. They are "always right," even when they are wrong.
American players in the international students' chess tournament in Uppsala made a strong stand yesterday in the first round of the finals with Czechoslovakia, according to a report from Sweden.
PARIS, April 9--Serious divergencies of views on Algerian policy between Premier Guy Mollet and his Minister of State, Pierre Mendes-France, were aired at a four-hour Cabinet meeting today.

Last week at his press conference President Eisenhower, asked for his opinion of the pending farm bill, which was still in conference committee, said he preferred not to render a final judgment until "a whole bill is in front of me."
WASHINGTON, April 9--Alberto Martin Artajo, Foreign Minister of Spain, arrived today for a ten-day visit to the United States.

NEW DELHI, April 9--The Indian Government has decided to take over diamond mining, it was announced in Parliament today by K.D. Malaviya, Minister for Natural Resources and Scientific Research.

BOSTON, April 9 (AP)--Albert Pell of New York upset Heiji Shimabukuro of Honolulu, the defending flyweight champion, tonight in the opening trials of the three-day national Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships at Boston Garden.
Textron American, Inc., big textile concern, is expanding its cotton and sisal padding operations through the acquisition of the Carolina Bagging Company, Henderson, N.C. ...
Septuagenarians henceforth will be barred as directors of what is said to be the country's largest department store group.

The most modern electronic "fence" in the world--a "fence" about 3,000 miles long and many miles high--is being constructed along one of the earth's last frontiers--the North American Arctic. It will cost $400,000,000.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 9--Rear Admiral George J. Dufek and a group of United States Navy officers visited the Soviet whaling factory ship Slava today and were treated as if they were long lost brothers.

Stocks weakened yesterday after a strong start that had taken The New York Times combined and industrial averages within fractions of their historic highs, Losses were moderate. Steels, oils and aircrafts, once well ahead, closed with gains reduced or erased.

Another season of continued growth and excellent cargo prospects appears to be in store for the annual seven-month period when the Great Lakes are in direct ocean-shipping contact with European ports.

WASHINGTON, April 9--The United States' first four Career Ambassadors, the diplomatic equivalent of five-star generals, took the oath of office today.

Surrogate George Frankenthaler will entertain this morning an application for temporary letters of administration on the estate of Jesus de Galindez, Columbia University lecturer who disappeared on March 12.
The city's high school teachers intend to continue their boycott of extra-curricular activities until the salary issue is settled, they indicated yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9-- President Eisenhower arrived her shortly after noon today for a week of golf on one of the nation's most beautiful--and toughest--courses.

The driving of stock-car taxicabs in New York's streets became legal yesterday.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday, Old July rose 19 points (95 cents a bale) and other months were 7 points (35 cents a bale) off, to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up.
TUNIS, Tunisia, April 9--The Bey of Tunis, Mohammed el Amin, turned to Habib Bourguiba today for guidance in forming a new Tunisian Government.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 --Purchase of motion-picture rights to "Deliver Us from Evil" was announced today by Bryna Productions coincident with the publication of the book by Farrar, Straus Cudahy.

WASHINGTON, April 9--A veteran Marine sergeant led seventy-five recruits in a floundering march in pitch darkness through a swamp near the boot camp at Parris Island, S.C. last night. Today five of the youths were dead and one was missing.

TORONTO, April 9 (Canadian Press)--Ford Motor Company of Canada Ltd. announced today it has filed a damage suit for nearly $1,000,000 against twelve insurance companies as a result of a strike in Ford's Windsor plant in December, 1951.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Chief Justice Earl Warren urged today that the parole system be run by trained professionals, not politicians.
Council President Abe Stark offered yesterday a plan for the combined industrial and residential redevelopment of 21.5 acres on the Bowery, and lower East Side.
John Simpson is 36 years old, sandy-haired. He wears spectacles, has a pleasant grin and listens more than he talks.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 9-- The great challenge--and the great opportunity--facing United States foreign policy is communism's eager pursuit of nationalist movements all over the world.
LOUISVILLE, April 9--The Braves turned the tables on the Dodgers today, beating the champions, 8--4, at Parkway Field. The triumph enabled Milwaukee to take a 5-4 edge in the spring series.

DETROIT, April 9 (AP)--The nation's car makers are scheduling production of some 1,800,000 cars for the second quarter. They got the quarter away to a good start last week with 134,273 car assemblies.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 10 (AP)--The United States team of Erwin Klein of Los Angeles and Mrs. Leah Neuberger of New York was a surprise survivor today as the mixed doubles event of the world table tennis championship reached the semifinal round.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 9-- J. Raymond Tiffany, onetime assistant attorney general for the State of New Jersey and a former district court judge, died today in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ride. He was 67 years old.

PALERMO, Sicily, April 9 (U.P.)--Giuseppe Merlo of Italy defeated Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif., 6--4, 8--10, 6--3, 6--2, in the singles final of the Palermo International Tennis Tournament today.
A WIDEAWAKE Manhattan concern prefers sleepy-head ed office girls.

HARTFORD, April 9--Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff urged Gov. William C. Marland of West Virginia tonight to cancel a visit to Connecticut April 20 to talk with industrialists about locating branch plants in the South.
As the Secretary General of the United Nations hastens eastward on his peace mission into the face of the gathering storm, the war clouds are rolling up again around Israel's embattled borders.

Moscow's two wandering troubadours, Messrs. Khrushchev and Bulganin, have issued a complaint. "Certain forces in Britain," they have told the world, are trying to keep them away from the British people during their scheduled visit there later this month.
The election of Archibald E. King as president and chief executive officer of the Isthmian Lines, Inc., was announced here yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 9--The West German Government informed the Soviet Union today that it was prepared to release thirty-one "foreigners" who had expressed a desire to return to Russia. All are inmates of West German prisons under sentence for common crimes.

NIR GALIM, Israel, Tuesday, April 10--A five-man fedayen (suicide) band that penetrated within fifteen miles of Tel Aviv was surrounded and wiped out yesterday by Israeli border policemen in a dry creek bed just west of here.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 9-- Nicosia security authorities revealed today the contents of a letter purporting to authorize the setting of time bombs in aircraft at the international airport here.
Ted Atkinson took the popularity poll with 24,266 racegoers at Jamaica yesterday by riding four winners, three for the Wheatley Stable and Trainer Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)-- The Air Force stepped up its program for an atom-powered airplane today with two new contracts for continued research and development.
A lumber expert said yesterday that output of particle board, a product salvaged from lumber mill waste, might hit 2,000,000,000 square feet a year in five years.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) --Homer Ferguson, former judge, Senator and Ambassador, was sworn in today for a fifteen-year term as a judge on the Court of Military Appeals.
DALLAS, Tex., April 9--Synthetic drugs that for years have been effective against malaria are being modified for use against cancer.

Lower first-quarter sales than a year ago, a rise in construction expenditures and the possibility of a stock split were the highlights of discussion at yesterday's annual meetink of E.I. du Pont de Ne mours Co.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 9 --Three developments today brought Pakistan's economic future into brighter perspective.

NOUASSEUR, French Morocco, April 9--The air materiel base here went on an emergency operation basis today as its 3,500 Moroccan employes struck. The base is the supply depot for United States Air Forces in the Mediterranean area.
WHITE PLAINS, April 9-- The Rev. Alfred C. Arnold, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at Main and Church Streets here, died of a heart attack last night in his home at 144 Church Street.
The Communist party filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to recover $10,200 now held by the Government to satisfy an income tax lien of $389,265.

A series of hold-ups in Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday cost the victims approximately $5,000.
WASHINGTON, April 9--Employment rose 500,000 from midFebruary to mid-March. This put the total at about 63,100,000. It was 2,500,000 higher than a year ago and a record for March.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced last night that he was still investigating the overcoming of twenty-four persons by gas fumes at a dinner Sunday night.

Dr. Harry Slochower will be reinstated on the faculty of Brooklyn College as the result of the Supreme Court's decision of yesterday and then will be suspended on new charges of "untruthfulness and perjury."
Trading in commodity futures on the New York exchanges was dull and featureless yesterday. Price moves were irregular.

A goal of a record total of 5,000,000 visitors here in June, July and August was set yesterday for the city's 1956 summer festival, This would be 1,000,000 above last summer's mark, and at an average of $100 a visitor would mean extra spending of $100,000,000 here.

MOSCOW, April 9--Trofim D. Lysenko, who once wielded Stalin-like power over Soviet biological research, has resigned as head of the All-Union Academy of Agricultural Science. His successor is Pavel P. Lobanov, a Deputy Premier in charge of agriculture.
HOUSTON, April 9--A heavy downpour at noon today wiped out the scheduled exhibition game between the Yankees and the Houston Buffs, so Casey Stengel passed the time taking inventory of his resources.
LONDON, April 9--The Foreign Office rejected today as "quite untrue" the two principal Soviet leaders' charge that their travels in Britain had been arranged to limit their contacts with the people.
The opening of the college rowing season in the East Saturday will be of unusual interest because of the return of Navy's Olympic championship crew of 1952.
The city's firemen paid their final respects yesterday to their six comrades who were killed in a factory blaze in the East Bronx last Wednesday.

A strike of 8,000 unionized employes at Macy's began at 12:01 A.M. today. The midnight shift did not report for work and thirty-five pickets began to patrol the entrances to the world's largest department store in Herald Square.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 9 (AP)--Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo proclaimed today a policy of cooperation, but no political or military ties, with both Western and Communist countries.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, April 9 (AP)--Hilario Camino Moncado, twice candidate for President of the Philippines--in 1941 and 1946--and founder of the Filipino Federation of America, died yesterday on the Agua Caliente golf course. He was 58 years old.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9--The United States Government pledged itself today to oppose aggression in the Middle East "within constitutional means." It said it would "support and as sist" any nation attacked there.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- President Eisenhower asked today a defense budget increase of $547,100,000 to expand production of B-52 intercontinental bombers and speed other critical programs.

MANY youthful girls, fresh to the career world, live by the work of their hands as they busily type up their quota of office mail for the day. Others live by their wits. Nineteenyear-old Ursula Stenz lives by her ears.
The six-story apartment house accommodating thirty-six families at 2201 Caton Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by the Richlaw Realty Corporation to a client of Sidney Hoffman, attorney.
Little Jack Little, widely known radio and vaudeville artist died yesterday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. His age was 55.
WASHINGTON, April 9-- Prof. James T. Shotwell counseled today against United States withdrawal from the International Labor Organization.
WASHINGTON, April 9--The Supreme Court upheld today a highway use tax levied by New York State against the International Harvester Credit Corporation and the Brockway Motor Company, Schenectady.
WASHINGTON, April 9--The Supreme Court today denied New York City the right to dismiss a college professor for in voking the protection of the Fifth Amendment.
Paul Keres, Estonian grandmaster and former Russian national champion, moved to second place yesterday in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Amsterdam.
The point-of-sale display, which has been performing its task of reminding potential customers of media advertising at the store counter, is to be called on to do considerably more.
Net assets of the Lehman Corporation, a closed-end investment trust, reached new highs on March 31, its third-quarter report showed yesterday.

Investment bankers yesterday designated a yield of 3.85 per cent for the marketing of a new issue of public utility securities of investment grade. The offering consists of $40,000,000 of debentures of the Columbia Gas System due April 1, 1981.
Jack Amiel's 7-year-old Mr. Turf took the $6,000 purse race that topped the program at Jamaica yesterday.
Experts said yesterday that medical dissection of the human body for teaching purposes apparently was performed nearly a thousand years earlier than had been believed heretofore.
CAIRO, April 10--Dag Hammarskjold flew to Cairo today for high-level talks on his peace mission to the Middle East.
WEST NYACK, N.Y., April 10--The largest lake in Rockland County, N.Y., is forming rapidly in the Hackensack River Valley behind a dam completed recently by the Hackensack Water Company.
TUNIS, Tunisia, April 10-- Habib Bourguiba agreed today to head the first Government to be formed in an independent Tunisia.
The proposal for a $20,000,000 sports stadium on Manhattan's West Side received impetus yesterday when it was approved by Horace C. Stoneham, president of the New York Giants.
BUFFALO, April 10--New York State business men took another long look at the potential of the St. Lawrence Seaway today.
Three persons were questioner yesterday in the inquiry into the acid-throwing attack on Victor Riesel, labor columnist, last Thursday.
Western Europe is determined to fill its urgent fuel needs by developing a common nuclear energy pool, Albert Coppe, vice president of the European Coal and Steel Community, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10--A Senate investigation subcommittee accused the State Department and the Civil Aeronautics Board today of not having given United States airlines a fair break in international air agreements.
MILES NEKOLNY, a baritone from Chicago who has sung with the Chicago Lyric Theatre and has appeared extensively in concert in the Midwest, sang in his debut recital at Town Hall last night.

The democracies were warned last night that they are handicapped in the "cold war" by lack of a great constructive ideal with which to win world support against communism. They were urged to adopt an ideology of freedom based on the rule of law to protect the individual against the tyranny of the state.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 --The reactivation of Oriental International Films, Inc., was announced today by Kenneth J. McEldowney, president and production head.
The deaths of six Marines on a march through a Parris Island swamp Sunday night left their families stunned yesterday.

THE single, most positive trend in interior decoration today is a look of luxury. Most apparent during the last year in elegant traditional rooms, the same look is being translated into modern decor, too, judging from model room settings opening today in New York stores.

LOUISVILLE, April 10-- Somewhere in the line-up of the 1956 Giants there should be a spot for Carroll (Whitey) Lockman. That is the conviction of most observers who have been following the spring training fortunes of Bill Rigney's New Yorkers. Rigney, too, believes Whitey belongs--but where?
International Paper Company announced plans yesterday for immediate construction of a $57,000,000 newsprint and bleached kraft board mill at Pine Bluff, Ark.

CHICAGO, April 10--Net earnings of the Thor Power Tool Company last year rose to $2,027,631, or $2.57 a share, from $1,504,891, or $1.91 a share, in 1954, Neil C. Hurley Jr., president, announced today in the annual report to stockholders.
The Citizens Committee for Children of New York City declared yesterday that many priority needs in children's services will not be met as a result of extensive cuts in the city's new budget.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company achieved new quarterly highs in operating revenues and net income in the first three months this year.

The Eisenhower Administration's civil rights program, as finally announced at long last by the Attorney general, has considerable merit even though it hasn't much chance of getting very far and though it may be taxed now with some political motivation. The program is still, on the whole, a commendable one.
Farmers will not share fully in the bounding prosperity that now seems to await most Americans in 1956, according to an Associated Press survey. The indications are that auto dealers will not either.
WASHINGTON, April 10--J. Edgar Hoover said today that his information about Communist plans to offset anti-Red legislation had come "from within the Communist party itself."
Two nations, more than 16,000 men, six military services, at least $400,000,000 and courage, blood and sweat are building the Distant Early Warning line across the American Arctic.
WASHINGTON, April 10--The Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, moved tonight to break any latent party bolt in the South.
Massachusetts borrowed $18,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance service benefits for war veterans. The borrowing was on an issue of bonds maturing serially on May 1 from 1957 to 1981.

JOHN CREIGHTON MURRAY, who was heard last night at Carnegie Hall, is a violinist with an individual style. He crouches, bobs and sways a good deal as he performs. His approach is prevailingly romantic, and the music he draws from his instrument is intensely lyrical and very sweet in tone.
MOSCOW, April 10--The end of "organized recruitment" among the 18,500,000 members of the Young Communist League for assigned tasks has been suggested.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., April 10--A Marine Corps court of inquiry heard testimony today from survivors of a forced night march into a treacherous tidal stream. The march was ordered by a drill sergeant "to teach the platoon discipline."
The Supreme Court decision in the case of the ousted Brooklyn College faculty member will not substantially affect the current investigations of Communist influence in the city schools and colleges.

ROGER PARIZOT, the diffident but competent Burgun dian who is chef and co-owner of the Chateaubriand Restaurant, likes to prepare the delectable roe of shad in a sauce tangy with sorrel, rich with cream and subtle with wine.

PARIS, April 10--Once it was firmly established after the war, Tito's revolution began to apply orthodox Communist theory as sanctified by Moscow. Factories were nationalized. Private business was backed against the wall.
JERUSALEM, April 10--There was a noticeable slackening of tension in Israel today.
A drive to force owners of commercial buildings in the city to perform better "housekeeping practices" was started yesterday in the Bronx.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 10 --Directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation do not yet deem the time "appropriate" for a stock split.
The convictions of Henry Grunewald, Washington influence peddler, and two others for conspiring to fix criminal income tax prosecutions were upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, April 10-- William Goldman, a night desk man for The New York Daily Mirror for fourteen years, refused to tell the Senate Internal Security sub-committee today whether he had ever been a member of the Communist party.
TRINCOMALEE, Ceylon, April 10--There's something strange about the latest manifestation of Asian nationalism: The demand that Britain quit her naval base in this old fort town.

WASHINGTON, April 10--Reports that the Soviet Union was recruiting Moslems for a holy war against Israel have attracted interest here. United States officials attach significance to a denial of the report by a leading Syrian Communist.
CHICAGO, April 10--Heavy pressure developed in early trading today in the grain pits on the Board of Trade, but selling spent its force by mid-day, and there was a fair recovery.

HE wore a grenade like a gardenia in Korea. He had already fought in Sicily and jumped with the airborne into Nazi held Normandy. And when he completed his two-year stretch as Army Chief of Staff last June he left behind him a stick of explosive statements that still crackle in the American political and military air.
"Omnibus," the program produced by the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation, will switch next fall to the American Broadcasting Company television network.
WASHINGTON, April 10-- The United States Government is using all its influence to persuade Egypt to join Israel in a cease-fire in the Middle East.
A two-story industrial building at 140 Main Street in Lodi, N.J., has been sold by the Commercial Trading Corporation to Division Properties, Inc.
WASHINGTON, April 10--Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. pleaded the Administration's case for civil rights legislation today.
FASHION today sees hosiery as an important accessory. The old idea that one neutral shade in one denier and one gauge goes with everything has given way to a new one-- the stocking wardrobe.
Canada is going to gird itself with another radar belt--this one to smooth the flow of airplane traffic.

Cocoa futures soared the daily limit of 1 cent a pound in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The volume, 570 contracts, was the largest since Dec. 2, 1953. There were thirty-eight unsatisfied bids at the close.
NAHA, Okinawa, April 10-- The man who founded a Communist party in Okinawa, the one politically stable United States military base in the Asian area, got out of prison today to a tumultuous welcome.
NEW ORLEANS, April 10 (UP)--A New York research scientist said today he had isolated a virus that he believed caused leukemia.

When we reflect on how long the New York City government has dawdled over the grant of permission to the Port Authority to build a temporary heliport at the foot of West Thirtieth Street we hesitate to say even' now that the battle for it has finally been won. However, it does appear to be.
ALBANY, April 10--Governor Harriman vetoed today a bill to permit New York taxpayers to deduct sick pay from their income tax returns this year under certain circumstances.

THE Trojan priest in "Troilus" at the flew York City Opera last Thursday night kept his arms crossed as long as he was on stage. When the show ended he was helped out of his garb and went to Roosevelt Hospital to have his arms set. He had fractured them that afternoon in a fall from three-foot-high stilts while practicing for a super's bit in "La Boheme."
JERSEY CITY, April 10-- Senator Estes Kefauver expressed confidence here today that he would get the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 10-- A lopsided daily-double pay-off provided the highlight of tonight's harness racing program at Roosevelt Raceway. A 40-to-1 shot, Truly Clever, combined with the 12-to-1 Miracle Henry to return a double of only $257 for $2.
LONDON, April 10--The British Government warmly welcomed today President Eisenhower's statement last night on the Middle East.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 10 (UP)--The tour of Gov. William C. Marland of West Virginia in quest of industry for his state was labeled "a raiding party" today by a second New England Governor.
SNOWS Sunday and Monday somewhat altered the pros pects for the opening day of New York's trout season Saturday, and hardly for the better.
CHICAGO, Wednesday, April 11--Adlai E. Stevenson's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination received renewed impetus yesterday.

BOSTON, April 10 (UP)--Phil and Danny Moyer, the sons of a former Golden Gloves champion, punched out impressive quarter-final victories in the National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships tonight.

SINGAPORE, April 10--The tides of change are running strong in Southeast Asia. The newly sovereign states just emerged from cast-off colonial shells are in danger of being swept away in the shifting groundswells.
An imaginative aeronautical engineer suggested a way yesterday to protect passengers from radiation in an atomic airliner. Don't carry any passengers.

WASHINGTON, April 10--The Administration proposed a farm bill compromise on price supports to House Republicans today. However, farm state members were opposed.
Opposition to subsidized housing was expressed yesterday at a luncheon meeting under the sponsorship of the Federation of New York Taxpayers, Inc., at the Commodore Hotel.
LONDON, April 10--The United Nations Disarmament Conference here was reported today to be in danger of stalling should there be no early Soviet move to meet Western ideas for arms cuts.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10-- President Eisenhower made a special effort today to spur legislation to halt the heavy turnover of trained military personnel.

MONTREAL, April 10 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens completed the downfall of hockey's greatest dynasty tonight. They beat the Detroit Red Wings, 3--1, to take the final National League play-off series by four games to one and capture the Stanley Cup for the seventh time.
Thousands of Macy's employes stayed away from their counters, desks and elevators yesterday to go on strike against the world's largest department store.

A delicious aroma of roast beef and Yorkshire pudding was sniffed in Grand Central Terminal during the lunch hour yesterday. It was traced to the lower level, where a busy little bearded Englishman was to be seen cooking.
Five store and apartment buildings occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and 105th Street have been purchased by the Bared Realty Corporation of Flushing, Queens.

TOKYO, April 10 (AP)--America's two national champions, Erwin Klein of Los Angeles and Mrs, Leah Neuberger of New York, finally cracked the Japanese monopoly in the world table tennis championships today. They beat two of Japan's strongest teams to gain the mixed-doubles final.
City policmen and firemen completed plans yesterday for mass demonstrations at City Hall today in support of their demands for pay increases in the 1956-57 city budget.
Two influential school groups called yesterday for an end to the teachers' boycott of extracurricular activities.

Ifor Owain Thomas, a singer, photographer and painter, died Monday night at the Lynwood Nursing Home, 306 West 102d Street, after a long illness. He was 61 years old. His home was at 50 West 106th Street.
MADRID, Wednesday, April 11--Thousands of workers in Pamplona yesterday challenged the labor laws of the Franco regime and caused a general strike in the city.
First-quarter sales of Philip Morris, Inc., approximate $72,000,000, or about 26 per cent above $57,000,000 volume a year ago, it was reported yesterday.

A business built by help wanted ads celebrated its golden anniversary yesterday. That's the way Alfred C. Fuller, 71-yearold chairman, describes the Fuller Brush Company, which he started in Hartford, Conn., on April 10, 1906, in an $11-a-month shed.
DALLAS, Tex., April 10--Out of a welter of experimentations, shake-ups and casualty replacements, Casey Stengel is gradually assembling his Yankee parts and dropping them into their proper places.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 10 --A statement deploring racial prejudice has been issued by twenty-eight leading figures of the largest church body in the South, the Southern Baptist Convention.

WASHINGTON, April 10-- Senate investigators of corruption in New York's garment industry began exploration today of a mysterious $6,000,000 bond fund.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 11 --The proposed triangular trade arrangement under which Japan would buy United States farm surpluses for yen and the United States would use the yen to buy machinery here for the Southeast Asian countries apparently will not he realized.

WASHINGTON, April 10-- The United States and Canada will join in a practice alert for a nuclear attack in July. The exercise was announced jointly today by the Office of Defense Mobilization, the Federal Civil Defense Administration and the Department of Defense.

The attached letter, addressed to me by the Secretary of Defense, reviews the serious nature of the personnel situation in the armed forces. It also outlines the major legislative proposals which the Administration has presented to the Congress as a means of improving military career incentives.
WASHINGTON, April 10-- Southern Democratic Senators have shown no signs in Florida of openly expressing their preference for Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois over Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.
Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, who wrote "My Fair Lady," are unable to proceed with their next project, a musical version of Edna Ferber's novel, "Saratoga Trunk."
Against the Spanish team in the third round of the international students' chess tournament at Uppsala, the Americans yesterday draw one game and adjourned three, according to a report from Sweden.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 10 (UP)--Frank Sedgman, a former Australian Davis Cup tennis star, said today he might join a fellow pro, Ken McGregor, in an effort to attain reinstatement as an amateur.
Furman's Darrell Floyd and George Washington's Joe Holup carried off the chief individual statistical honors during the east basketball campaign.
Fears about the Middle East situation were largely responsible for two bursts of selling on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday that sent prices tumbling in the worst break since Oct. 10.
Hugh V. Freeman has sold an industrial plot on the west side of Fifty-eighth Street, about sixty-two feet south of Broadway, in Woodside, Queens, to John Scala of Brooklyn.

Influential Republicans appeared yesterday to be gravitating toward the selection of L. Judson Morhouse, instead of former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, as chairman of the New York delegation to the Republican National Convention.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's crop of winter wheat at 716,477,000 bushels.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 10-- The" Economic Council of the Baghdad Pact held its first session today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10--New York University scored 8 runs in the third inning and went on to defeat Yale, 12--4, at Yale Field today. N.Y.U. stayed its big inning on only three hits, a double by Bill Shelley and singles by Joe Duva and Tony Triulzi.

TERRE HALITE, Ind., April 10--Rain washed out the final exhibition baseball game between the Milwaukee Braves and Brooklyn Dodgers at Evansville today. In addition some of Manager Smokey Alston's pitch ing plans were dampened. These plans involved his two leading starters, Carl Erskine and Don Newcombe.
DALLAS, Texas, April 10-- The day may come when Americans will eat main courses of mushrooms garnished with beefsteak instead of the other way around, a scientist said today.

The creation of a new diplomatic rank in the United States service, Career Ambassador, is an encouraging sign. Our Foreign Service needs encouragement, for its morale was allowed to reach an all-time low during the McCarthyite assaults in 1953-54.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 10--A group of white men attacked Nat (King) Cole, the Negro singer, as he sang to an all-white audience in the Municipal Auditorium tonight. Mr. Cole was not injured.

Severe winter weather as well as increased wage arid operating costs restricted first quartet earnings of the Northern Pacific Railway, stockholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting in St. Paul.

THE fortieth annual exhibition of the Society of American Graphic Artists, which opened yesterday at the Architectural League Gallery, 115 East Fortieth Street, is one of the largest and perhaps quite the most diverse in the society's long series of annuals.
Steel production broke records in March and the first qumrter of the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.
This country's cotton exports this year will be the smallest in 107 years--barring the Civil War, Reconstruction and World War II periods and 1949.

Net earnings of the General Aniline and Film Corporation in the first quarter of this year were up nearly 90 per cent to $1,450,000 from $760,000 in the initial three months of last year. Sales were estimated at $31,250,000, compared with $28,885,000.

Two Waterfront Commission investigators charged that they were assaulted yesterday morning outside a Hoboken N.J., pier in the first instance of dockworker violence against investigating personnel of the bi-state . agency. A third said he had been threatened.
The figures on employment and unemployment as of mid-March have just been issued by the Departments of Commerce and Labor, and generally speaking they again make encouraging reading.
Eighteen Protestant churches, among those built in the United States during the last twentyfive years, were cited yesterday for architectural excellence.
MOSCOW, April 11--Authorities have demanaed a stepped-up civil defense program to protect the Soviet Union against atomic or bacteriolgical attack.

BELMONT, Mass., April 11-- Dean Erwin N. Griswold of the Harvard University Law School and Mrs. Griswold have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Eleanor Griswold, to Daniel Murrow of New York.

CHICAGO, April 11--The Continental Insurance Companies-- Continental Casualty and Continental Assurance--announced today plans to make United States Life Insurance Company a more independent operation.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., April 11 (AP)--A drill sergeant who ordered a forced march that resulted in the drowning of six Marine recruits has been given a psychiatric examination, his commanding general reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 11--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 4:
Frederick H. Leonhardt, chairman of the board of Fritzche Brothers, Inc., died Tuesday night at his home, 7 Willow Street, Douglaston, Queens, after several months' illness. He was 83 years old.
Greenwood Mills, Inc., of New York and California Fabric Company of Los Angeles have formed a new fabric converting concern, Greenwood-California Fabric Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- Many legitimate small businesses would be penalized if the Securities and Exchange Commission fails to revise a regulation it has prepared to curb speculative stock issues of $300,000 or less, the Small Business Administration said today.
"TRY your kitchen on before buying it," advises Prof. Lucille Williamson, home economist at Cornell University.
At the age of 80, Stella Walthall Patterson decided to leave city life and move to a cabin on a mining claim she owned in the remote timber forests in the Siskiyou Mountains of northern California.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 11-- Violence flared here today when a delegation of Negroes sought to be served at the cafeteria in the Harris County courthouse. Dee F. Derrington, who operates the cafeteria under lease from the county government, closed it after the violence.
An order banning picketing by firemen while in uniform was issued last night by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
MOSCOW, April 11--The present Soviet leadership has rehabilitated many persons falsely convicted as "enemies of the people" and is reviewing cases of many others.

Dag Hammarskjold, intervening on behalf of the United Nations in the perilous Middle Eastern conflict, has gone to see Premier Nasser of Egypt first. The reasons ought surely to be obvious to everyone following events in that part of the world.
The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, A.F.L.C.I.O., has called upon labor to take strong action against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, an affiliated union.
Electric utilities slowed their financing in the first quarter of this year.

IMOGENE COCA, the comedienne, last night tried her first dramatic role on television, portraying a theatrical star beset by emotional insecurity. She acquitted herself acceptably in a script that covered rather familiar ground.

GUATEMALA, April 9--A leading archaeologist reported today the most important archaeological finding so far in efforts to restore Tikal. This key city of the Mayan civilization has been dead for eleven centuries.
The Celanese Corporation of America plans to spend more than $100,000,000 in the next five years, Harold Blancke, president, told shareholders, at the annual meeting here yesterday.

Career Boy hit hard in the stretch to win the $29,250 Gotham Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The C.V. Whitney colt took the mile-and-a-sixteenth event by three lengths over Mrs. Lloyd P. Tate's Jean Baptiste, who had a neck the better of Mrs. Anson A. Bigelow's Nail.

DALLAS, Tex., April 11-- Fifty thousand new compounds are being created throughout the world this year by chemists in their quest for drugs, plastics, dyes, fibers, fuels, improved fuel production and other aids.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- Former President Herbert Hoover recommended today that a stricken President's Cabinet decide when and for how long a ... Vice President should take over his duties.
The Convair Division of the General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that it had developed a medium-range jet airliner that would be the fastest in the world.
"SCHOOL FOR WIVES," Rolf Liebermann's opera which had its New York premiere at the City Center last night, lasts only sixty-five minutes. Rarely has so much tedium been packed into so short a span.
The United States team, encountering Russia in the fourth round yesterday, fared poorly in the international students' chess tournament in Uppsala, according to a report from Sweden.
WASHINGTON, April 11--Investigating Senators cast some light today on a two-year masquerade under a dead man's name by Robert G. Thompson, New York State Communist chairman now in jail.

NEW HAVEN, April 11--The New Haven Railroad intends to seek a 25 per cent increase in commutation fares. This was disclosed today by George Alpert, new president of the line, at the annual meeting here.

BURLINGTON, Wis., April 11 (AP)--Clarence (Ginger) Beaumont, considered one of baseball's great outfielders, died last night at Burlington Hospital. His age was 79. He was they first man to bat in an American League-National League world series.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- The National Association of Attorneys General opened fire here today on the Supreme Court's ruling that the Smith Act superseded state sedition laws.
LONDON, April 11--Doubts about United States willingness to take effective action in a Middle Eastern crisis developed here today.
JERUSALEM, Thursday, April 12--The Israeli Government faced a new clamor today for reprisals against Egypt in the wake of suicide squad raids in the heart of Israel.

ALBANY, April 11--Governor Harriman approved legislation today to help crack down on narcotics peddlers and rehabilitate their victims.
