An effort to unite Negroes in "all-out, vigorous support" of the Supreme Court's order for ending segregation in public schools was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- The Senate bowed today to the wishes of the President and the Central Intelligence Agency. It rejected, 59 to 27, a resolution that would have created a Joint Congressional "watchdog" committee to supervise the intelligence organization.

The importance of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov in Soviet affairs and his role in the purge of the late Lavrenti P. Beria have been detailed by diplomatic sources having access to private statements of the highest Soviet leaders.

Revlon, Inc., maker of cosmetics, toiletries and proprietary products, achieved record sales and earnings in the first quarter this year.

Pleasure boating is an adaptable sport. The skipper who wants blue water over his bow can get it. He needs an offshore, solid, seagoing cruiser if he hankers for waves and rough going out in the ocean or on the sometimes raging Great Lakes.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 11 (AP)--The American Academy of Arts and Sciences, founded by President John Adams, paid tribute tonight to two famous personalities with perhaps the most unusual concert of this century--music played on a reconstruction of an instrument long forgotten on the concert stage.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- The United States information services should devote more attention to the content of this country's message to the world and less to the mechanisms of delivery, the United States Advisory Commission on Information said today.
AT one time a woman was considered an adequate public speaker if she could manage a clear, emphatic "I do." Today she must be prepared to enter the verbal limelight at the drop of a P.-T.A. gavel.

WALTHAM, Mass., April 11--Brandeis University has received a gift of $1,000,000 for a library. The donor was disclosed today as Jack A. Goldfarb, a New York industrialist.

WASHINGTON, April 11--The soundest and perhaps the only conclusion that can be drawn from the Presidential preference primary in Illinois is that, as a road map to the White House, it is unreliable.

Cocoa futures jumped the 1cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions for the second consecutive day on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. Volume continued heavy, at 467 lots. There were seventy-four unsatisfied bids at the close.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 11-- A crowd of 13,796, the largest turnout for a Yankee exhibition game this spring, saw the Bombers bow to the Cincinnati Redlegs, 7 to 5, tonight.

An industrial site on Southern Boulevard, between 173d and 174th Streets, the Bronx, has been sold by the City of New York to the Boston Properties Corporation. The property, comprising 40,000 square feet, is being used for a parking lot.

Leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations units in the state and city yesterday urged George. Meany and Dave Beck to end "strike-breaking" by truck drivers in the Macy walkout.
JOE E. BROWN easily stole the show in last night's presentation of "Shower of Stars" over Channel 2. He did his pantomime of the baseball pitcher who is harried by batters, base runners and umpires.

Jean Morel has been engaged to conduct at the Metropolitan Opera next season. Rudolf Bing announced yesterday that one of the works to be assigned to the French-born musician is Offenbach's "La Perichole," the one opera of the 1956-57 repertory that has never been given at the Metropolitan before.

IT may be that this will inspire haughty snorts from the reverent priests of the flyrod, who abhor heretical tendencies in tackle, but the plain truth is that spinning rigs will outnumber flyrods tomorrow when the New York trout season opens.
Tammany named Supreme Court Justices S. Samuel Di Falco and Joseph A. Cox yesterday as its candidates for the two Surrogate's Court vacancies to be filled at this fall's election.

Max Liebman has decided to produce a song-and-dance program devoted entirely to popular music composed by the late George Gershwin. It will be televised in color on May 12 from 9 to 10:30 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company network.
NAPLES, April 12 (AP)--Althea Gibson of New York gained the women's semi-finals and two Californians advanced to the men's quarter-finals today in the Naples tennis tournament.

The formation of the TriState College Basketball League was disclosed last night. The circuit will be made up of teams from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

American players met strong opposition in the fifth round of the international students' chess tournament at Uppsala yesterday, scoring 1, point to 2 for Rumania, with one game unfinished, according to a report from Sweden.
Customs collections from shipping and airport activities amounted to $32,772,397 in March, a drop of $68,748 from the preceding month, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) --Gen. Randolph McCall Pate said today a psychiatric examination indicated that the drill sergeant who led six Marine recruits to accidental death in a South Carolina swamp was "a perfectly sound, well motivated young man."

CINCINANATI, April 12--The Yankees flexed their muscles today and exploded four home runs. They paid off handsomely, for the Bombers, getting spotty pitching, needed all of them to bring down the Redlegs, 8 to 7, in their final meeting this spring.

CHICAGO, April 12--The threat of a Federal grand jury investigation faced northern Illinois locals of the International Union of Operating Engineers today. The threat came as the union carried on its convention in the Conrad Hilton Hotel behind closed doors.
LONDON, April 12 (AP)--Lou Perini, president of the Milwaukee Braves Baseball club, came to England today with a revolutionary plan--baseball for Britain and cricket for the United States.

Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., will serve as playing captain of the United States Wightman Cup tennis team this year. The match with the British women's team will be held at Wimbledon, England, June 15 and 16.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- The Internal Revenue Service is getting ready to cock a more critical eye at the individual income tax returns piling up at its sixty-four district offices.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 12-- S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike drove up to the Governor General's house today in his ten-year-old Plymouth and a half hour later drove away in a new air-conditioned Cadillac, which goes with the job of Prime Minister of Ceylon.

The United Corporation's first quarter of operations as an investment company was marked with continued increases in net asset value and income, William M. Hickey, president, announced yesterday. BOSTON, April 14--Larry Boardman pummeled the featherweight champion, Sandy Saddler, with rights and lefts and hooks in the early stages, then settled down to outbox Sandy tonight for a unanimous decision in a ten-round nontitle bout at the Boston Garden. Boardman weighed 135 pounds, Saddler 130.

Greece's recent decision to withdraw her ratification of the convention establishing the Intergovernmental Maritime Consultive Organization has left in doubt the immediate future of this international shipping body.

NAHAL OZ, Israel, April 13 --When the tension becomes almost unbearable in Israel, as it did this week, the best way to achieve inner calm is, (a) go home to America, or (b) go to the front and spend a couple of days at a frontier settlement on the edge of the Gaza strip.

WASHINGTON, April 14-- Pan-American unity has demonstrated that it is strong enough to withstand the disruptive efforts of propagandists for "a clever world conspiracy," Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower said today.

BOWIE, Md., April 14--The Companas Stable's Besomer rallied under a hard ride by Nick Shirk today to score a head triumph over the pace-setting Decathlon in the $34,000 Governor's Gold Cup at Bowie.

ALBANY, April 14--Governor Harriman approved today the compulsory automobile safety inspection bill. It requires yearly checks of all cars and trucks more than four years old. The program will begin next year.

THE lucid and luminous writings of Thomas Jefferson are a continuing challenge to editors who would present a representative selection in a single volume. John Dewey selected "The Living Thoughts of Thomas Jefferson." William Peden and Adrienne Koch edited a volume of "Selected Writings." Bernard Mayo assembled an autobiographical narrative in "Jefferson Himself."
MILWAUKEE, April 14 (AP)-- The Milwaukee Braves, in their first home appearance of the year, whipped the Cleveland Indians, 6--4, today before 10,394 paying fans at Milwaukee Stadium.

THE public's intense interest in a person, a pastime or an idea is one of the most familiar and im portant occurrences in American life. For weeks, for months, sometimes for years, one person or thing is a topic of conversation, a seed-bed of jokes, an object of passionate curiosity or of some other emotion that preoccupies the public mind. When this happens, we have what can only be called a national phenomenon.

DALLAS, Tex., April 16 (AP) Former President Herbert Hoover told the Inter-American Bar Association tonight that "hermit crabs" of socialism were prowling Western Hemisphere countries on orders of the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Herbert Browneil Jr., Attorney General, and the Justice Department were accused in the House of Representatives today of granting special favors to "big business" in antitrust cases.

DETROIT, April 16-- The president of the StudebakerPackard Corporation reported to stockholders today that the cormpany had been unable up to now to obtain the financing required to improve its sagging position in the auto industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16-- Senator Estes Kefauver flew back to California today. In a series of speeches, the Tennessee Democrat denounced the Eisenhower Administration as an "exclusive club" of operatives working in secrecy for the benefit of big business.
Miguel Berrios, a fiery little Puerto Rican, defeated Bobby Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, in a rousing ten-round fight at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The big national magazines are going in heavily for full-scale sales presentations. SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 16-- It is known in Sofia that the new leader will be Anton Yugov, although this has not yet been officially announced.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) --Miss Gertrude S. Carraway of New Bern, N. C., President General of the Daughters of the American Revolution, called tonight for members to help "spread the fire of freedom" against threatening "foreign ideologies."
MILAN, April 16--The drenching the Milan Fair has taken in its first four days would have discouraged a duck, But this biggest show of its kind is already a clear success.

Stocks fell into a familiar pattern yesterday, gaining in the morning and losing ground in the afternoon. The close was mixed but moderately lower on average.

The Winding Way Farm's Golf Ace took the medal in a six-furlong sprint at Jamaica yesterday. Established odds-on in a field of eight, the eccentric son of Escadru contributed a formful performance to beat Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Deep Breath by three and a half lengths.

CHICAGO, April 17--Preliminary revenue and profit figures for the Hilton Hotels Corporation and subsidiary companies indicate record high levels in the first quarter of 1956, Robert P. Williford, executive vice president, told shareholders today at the annual meeting in Chicago.
The Pittston Company's proxy contest for control of Brink's, Inc., the armored car service concern, reached a stalemate yesterday.
The skipper of the new Empress of Britain, due to depart on Friday from Liverpool on her maiden voyage, will be Capt. S.W. Keay, former master of the Empress of France.

PARIS, April 17--During the singular group confessional practiced by the Soviet leaders at their party congress Mikoyan made reference to "certain ossified forms of our diplomacy." That is no longer an apt...
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Secretary of State moved today to appease critics of the Administration's foreign aid program in both major parties.

The United States Rubber Company had a net profit of about $9,000,000 in the first quarter this year, against $9,940,000 in those three months last year, H.E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
A total of 226,097 fans braved generally chilly weather to attend the eight opening games of the 1956 baseball season yesterday.
Cotton futures trading was quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 3 points up to 14 points off.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 17--The principality of Monaco became perhaps the most densely populated country in the world today.
A charge that too many unreported accidents occur in hospitals was offered yesterday at the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council.

A crowd of 24,236 filed happily out of sprawling, ramshackle 44-year-old Ebbets Field yesterday. The world champion Dodgers had lost the opening game of the baseball season to the Phillies, but the fans were in a gay mood, nevertheless.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 --Charles Laughton is the first of four leading role players to be signed by Sam Spiegel for his production of "The Bridge Over the River Kwai."
CHICAGO, April 17 (UP)--Bob Lemon walked in the winning run in the seventh inning today to bring the Chicago White Sox a 2-1 victory over Cleveland before 16,773 fans.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 17 --An impression of a thriving Tallinn was given today by a Finnish professor who spent five days in Estonia last month.
Extensive study and public hearings on all so-called "premerger notification" bills now before Congress was urged yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

VIENNA, April 17--The resignation of Vulko Chervenkov as Premier of Bulgaria was accepted today by the National Assembly. First Deputy Premier Anton Yugov was unanimously approved to succeed him. Both events are sequels of Moscow's new antiStalinist policy.

Athletic prestige carried a lot of weight in Rutgers University's recent student elections. Seven of the fifteen student council seats and four class offices went to members of Scarlet athletic teams.

Major television program changes are contemplated by the National Broadcasting Company because of competition from rival networks. Among the programs expected to be affected soon are "Howdy Doody" and the Sunday night "Comedy Hour."

NAHA, Okinawa, April 16-- As wards of the United States, while still subjects of Japan's Emperor, the 800,000 natives of the Ryukyu Islands find themselves in an anomalous and uncomfortable political situation.

The Atlantic community, already startled by the resignation of General Gruenther and the latest developments in France and Iceland, is going through another flurry of concern because of the decision of the West German Government to inter vene in the Big Four deadlock on German unification with a direct approach to Moscow.
Operating income of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, the world's largest investment house, rose $11,989,000 last year, the firm reported yesterday in its annual report.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Office of Defense Mobilization reported today plans to make available all possible information about its operations.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Administration's civil rights proposals were unexpectedly blocked today in the House Judiciary Committee, but supporters predicted that a bill would be approved next week.

THE April-in-Paris Ball that will be staged at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Friday evening through dawn of Saturday will approach, if not surpass, in splendor lavish events staged in France in the lushest times of the Kings Louis.

Miss Lavinia Lloyd Dock, a nurse, a leading settlement worker and a militant suffragist, died last night in the Chambersburg (Pa.) Hospital. She was in her ninety-ninth year. Miss Dock's hip was broken in a fall three weeks ago in her home in Fayetteville, Pa.
Mayor Wagner and his wife, Susan, joined the 12,790 fans who quarter-filled the Polo Grounds for the Giants' opener yesterday.
LONDON, April 17--Harold Macmillan, Chancellor of the Exchequer, offered Britons strong incentives to save today. He even appealed to their well-developed gambling instinct.
Bearing an Olympic "torch of freedom," Shalom Kahalny, 22-year-old Israeli farmer, ran from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to City Hall yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Democrats conceded defeat today in their effort to get Congress to override President Eisenhower's veto of the farm bill.

The problem of Palestine must have priority over the Baghdad Pact in United States policy if peace is to be preserved, it was asserted here yesterday by Elmo H. Hutchison, former chairman of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission. He now is a director of American Friends of the Middle East.

MILWAUKEE, April 17 (AP)-- Five-hit pitching by Lew Burdette and home runs by Henry Aaron and Joe Adcock sparked the Milwaukee Braves to a 6-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs in the season opener today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 17-- Brazil is ordering two hydro graphic ships in Japanese ship yards.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 --Maxwell Anderson's drama "The Star Wagon" has been acquired for production on the forthcoming television program, "Playhouse 90," over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
Brooklyn's opening-day parade yesterday to honor the world champion Dodgers was more like a scratch single than a home run.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- John Foster Dulles expressed "very great concern" today over the possible effect on world trade of legislation in two southern states aimed at Japanese textiles.

Leon Fleischmann, civil engineer and a former president of the Ninth Federal Savings and Loan Association, died Monday night at his home, 120 West Seventieth Street, after a long illness. His age was 77.

The five-story apartment house at 1387 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, has been sold by Peoria Potentials, Inc., to an investing client of Liepson Rubman, attorneys. The property, near 170th Street, was sold for cash above mortgages of about $155,000. Schiffman Goldkopf were the brokers, and Howard Rikoon was the attorney for the seller.

SWEET peppers marinated in olive oil and vinegar, aromatic with capers, garlic and oregano. Does not that sound good? And it is, as done by Udo Taormina, which packs the savory concoction under a label that reads Progresso pepper piccalilli.

IT was a long wait but the glorious moment finally arrived yesterday at Ebbets Field. A white pennant with blue borders and blue lettering rose swiftly to the top of the mast, curled patriotically around the American flag in a quick embrace and then dropped below it into place. As if on cue, the wind caught the pennant and whipped it out straight for every proud Brooklyn eye to see.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation achieved record high first-quarter sales and net profits in the first three months this year.

The jurisdiction dispute between the television film actors union and the live-show performers union was pinpointed yesterday by an arbitration decision relating to a device employing both film and electronic techniques.
A sharp increase in net income and record sales and revenues were reported yesterday by W.R. Grace Co. in its annual report.

Many observers of the business scene regard the third quarter of this year as a crucial period during which the staying power of the boom will be sharply tested. That remains to be seen, but at least a sizable segment of the business population has no qualms.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 17-- Because of the murder of an Assistant Police Superintendent on Sunday, a week-long duskto-dawn curfew was ordered today in this capital city of Cyprus and seven villages in the suburbs.

The Alabama State Building Authority is planning to borrow $4,000,000 in the public market on May 2 on an issue of serial revenue bonds dated June 1, and due on Dec. 1 from 1959 to 1986. Money raised by the sale will be used to erect an office building.
CHICAGO, April 17--The president of the American Broadcasting Company, declared today that charges of "huckster" and "tasteless" programming leveled at broadcasters were myths.
PISA, Italy, April 17--The Leaning Tower of Pisa, one of the world's most famous landmarks, has stood in apparent defiance of the laws of gravity for longer than seven and a half centuries.

THE Ballet Theatre last night opened a three-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House in a program designed with considerable ingenuity to get all the principal artists of the company into the bill in reasonably rewarding fashion.

WASHINGTON, April 17--Almost from the moment festivities in Washington's opening baseball game got under way today it must have become patent to the 27,837 onlookers that the Yankees would steal the show.

TIFLIS, U.S.S.R., April 17-- The rector of Tiflis State University said today that authorities were taking measures to prevent a repetition of "certain excesses," including casualties, that marked last month's proStalin demonstrations here.

EASTWARD IN EDEN" ran for only fifteen performances when it was given on Broadway nine years ago. The fact that it flickered out in spite of encouraging reviews is probably what has prompted an off-Broadway group to attempt a revival of this compassionate dramatization of the life of Emily Dickinson.
Again the leaders of world communism have shown themselves masters of the dramatic gesture, performed at the psychologically most useful moment.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized ten large railroad companies to buy and jointly operate the properties of the Illinois Terminal Railroad Company. The Terminal company's headquarters are at St. Louis, Mo.
PALMDALE, Calif., April 16--What is believed to be the fastest combat plane in the world was displayed for the first time today.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman declared last night that the threat of McCarthyism to civil liberties had not ended.

LONDON, April 17--The British Government will suggest to Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev that stoppage of arms shipments to Egypt from Soviet bloc countries is a primary means of easing tension in the Middle East.

STANDING with unreluctant feet where Mayfair and Bohemia meet, Iris Murdoch has written a mythological novel about modern London. The cast of wonderful women swirls around a strange lot of vaguely purposeful men in "The Flight From the Enchanter."*

The two Russian "traveling salesmen," Premier Bulganin and Communist party leader Khrushchev, bearing gifts and wreathed in smiles, are now in London.
Net profit of the Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries rose 58 per cent in the first quarter this year, compared with the same three months last year.
"Waiting for Godot," Samuel Beckett's tragicomedy, has its Broadway premiere at the John Golden Theatre this evening at 8 o'clock under the auspices of Michael Myerberg.

WASHINGTON, April 18--The failure of the Democratic leaders of the House to summon even a simple majority to override the President's veto of the farm bill (two-thirds in each branch of Congress was required for repassage) is surface political testimony, at least, that the President and the "yardstick" on which he measured the bill and found it wanting are supported by public opinion.
KISHINEV, U.S.S.R., April 15 --Moldavian authorities are engaged in an important program for recruiting farmers for the virgin lands of Kazakhstan, 4,300 miles away.

First quarter earnings of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company amounted to $5,680,827, or 93 cents a share, on sales of $88,001,240. J.P. Levis, chairman, reported these results at the annual meeting yesterday in Toledo, Ohio.
"OUT of the rocking chair," is an expression frequent ly used by Mrs. Terry M. Mc Kinley.

ROSCOE, N.Y., April 18-- Snow fell twice here today and so did rain; the famous Beaverkill is bank full and still cloudy, though not muddy, and the day is raw. But the neversay-die anglers are still trying.

A PROFESSOR who is more apt to be absent than absent minded is David Ffolkes of Boston University. Professor Ffolks, who in 1954 was appointed to teach the history of architecture, costume design and theatrical drawing tech nique, sometimes takes six months' leave so design costumes for the movies.
PATERSON, N.J., April 18-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Haft of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Lois Haft, to Ronald A. Hausman.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- Joseph (Joey) Abrams of Great Neck, L.I., refused today to tell whether or why he allegedly had bought nearly $6,000,000 worth of Federal, state and municipal bonds while making uni forms for the armed services.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) --The Daughters of the American Revolution pledged their support to the United Nations today "in its original purpose." But they opposed its conversion into a world government.
LONDON, April 18--The Government's plan to encourage savings by selling bonds carrying a chance to win substantial prizes was praised and condemned today with almost equal gusto.

Maurice Epstein, who has been a heavy investor in midtown Manhattan realty, turned yesterday to the downtown area where, he bought two five-story commercial buildings at the northwest corner of Cortlandt and Washington Streets.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP)-- The Navy unwrapped today a model of an ejectable cockpit capsule designed to permit survival bail-outs at several thousand miles an hour.
CAIRO, April 18--Egypt was reported today to have embarked on a new policy of strengthening her relations with the Asians.
WASHINGTON, April 18--A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today an omnibus civilrights bill that includes major provisions not requested by the Administration.

CHICAGO, April 18--James C. Hagerty, press secretary to President Eisenhower, said today he saw no reason why all political parties should be granted equal radio and television time with the two major parties in an election year.

BONN, April 17--A draft of legislation that would permit a return of the commercial banking system to Germany's historie pattern is expected to be submitted to the Federal Parliament during the current session.
Attorneys for T. Vincent Quinn and his two ex-partners failed yesterday in an attempt to stifle the Federal Government's charges that they had shared illegal fees.
THE first new ballet by Antony Tudor in four years was presented by the Ballet Theatre last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The problem that confronted the new Chancellor of the Exchequer in formulating Britain's fiscal program for 1956-57 was an unusual one. Strictly speaking, it was not a budgetary problem in the popular meaning of that term.
Merchants representing many types of business throughout the country were honored last night for promoting brand names.
MOSCOW, April 18--Pravda said today that although the Cominform had been dissolved the Communist parties of the world were expected to maintain ties in an effort to achieve a common goal.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer, yesterday reported a record net income of $13,559,000, or $2.09 a common share, for the first quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, April 18--It may be, as the song has it, that "you've gotta have heart" if you mean to succeed in baseball. But the Yankees are doing well without one.

Memories of home mingle with dreams of the future at the tenth annual hobby show for older persons. The display opens today at the American Museum of Natural History, where it will continue through April 29.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- President Eisenhower accepted with reservations today the Soviet Union's announced readiness to support a settlement by the United Nations of the ArabIsraeli crisis.

DETROIT, April 18--Walter P. Reuther returned from a ten-day visit to India today. He urged a "non-partisan, nonpolitical" reassessment of the United States' Asian foreign policy.

The Primavera Enchantment Ball will be held May 10 at the Plaza under the auspices of the Renaissance of Italian Youth Foundation. Proceeds will aid the work of an orphanage, I Celestini, in Prato, Italy.
The scales were tipped further yesterday toward the ultimate reconstruction of the Aqueduct race track in Queens as the longprojected "super track."
Ewfim Geller of Russia was the lone winner yesterday in the twelfth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Amsterdam, according ...
SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 18 --John A. Heydler, former president of the National Baseball League, died in Mercy Hospital here today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 18 --The American Whig-Cliosophic Society, student debating organization of the Princeton campus, announced today that its meeting next Thursday would be open only to members of the society. Alger Hiss will be the speaker.
OTTAWA, April 18 (UP)-- Russia has bought nearly 15,000,000 bushels of Canadian wheat already under new RussoCanadian trade agreements, Trade Minister C.D. Howe told the Commons today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 18--Maximum penalties were given today to four men for their part in the attack on Nat (King) Cole, Negro singer, during his performance at Birmingham's Municipal Auditorium April 10.

Waterfront employers urged State Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel Di Falco yesterday to mete out identical punishment to two top dock union officers for disobedience of a court injunction against last September's longshore strike here.
MOSCOW, April 18--The visit to Britain by the Soviet leaders is regarded by a substantial number of Muscovites as a major move for peace.
RICHMOND, Va., April 18-- T. Coleman Andrews, former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, was elected president today of the American Fidelity and Casualty Insurance Company in an organizational change.

THE stripling Kipling, who saw San Francisco in 1889, said it was a mad city, "inhabited by perfectly insane people whose women are of a remarkable beauty." Others have had the same impression since then, although the town grows increasingly debonair.
Gov. Robert E. Meyner emerged with new political prestige yesterday after his organization's victory in New Jersey's primary election on Tuesday.
The Waterfront Commission voted yesterday a permanent license to the Nacirema Operating Company, Inc., New York stevedores.

A drop of 2,263,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 195,059,000 barrels, compared with 197,322,000 a week earlier and 181,864,000 a year ago.

PARIS, April 18--The French Government told the National Assembly today it planned to get through this year with what it called an "acceptable" budget deficit in spite of the cost of the Algerian war.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will become the first company in history to spend $2,000,000,000 on construction in twelve months.
Mayor Wagner and Senator Herbert H. Lehman have accepted invitations to speak next Wednesday at a fund-raising dinner for Adlai E. Stevenson's Presidential campaign.
William De Koning Jr., labor leader and convicted extortionist, would answer only one question put to him yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti.

The outlook for an early peace in the city school system all but disappeared yesterday. The Teachers Guild, A.F.L.C.I.O., after a noisy two and one-half hour meeting of its delegate assembly, unanimously rejected the plea of school officials to end the boycott of extracurricular activities.
PITTSBURGH, April 18--Adlai E. Stevenson denounced today the Eisenhower Administration's "three do-nothing years in the fields of education, highways and housing."
President Eisenhower and Adlai E. Stevenson were criticized equally yesterday for their advocacy of a policy of moderation on major issues.
Mayor Wagner has asked Governor Harriman to veto the bill to add twenty-one places on the Supreme Court bench. Sixteen of them would be in counties within New York City.

The Power Authority of the State of New York yesterday postponed indefinitely the sale of $7,250,000 of revenue bonds scheduled for April 26. The authority has decided to resort to temporary financing for the time being.
Mediation efforts were reported in progress early today to end the ten-day-old Macy's strike.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Unanimous agreement was reached here today on the charter for a world-wide atoms-forpeace agency.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday fell 6 to 53 points (30 cents to $2.65 a bale) in fairly heavy trading.
A new mill to feed the seemingly insatiable maw of America's newsprint-using industries may go into action next year.
JAMES A. BEARD has a finger in every pie. This New Yorker writes cookbooks (on fish, Paris cuisine, outdoor foods, etc.), lectures on gastronomy, advises big business on the table art.
SANTA SUSANA, Calif., April 17--Amid rock-dotted hills and dales, scientists and engineers are busy marshaling the eerie horsepower of the future.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) --Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today he would reject a request of the Justice Department to testify in the contempt of Congress trial of Wendell H. Furry unless Judge Bailey Aldrich withdrew from the case.
Helen Hayes has canceled her television appearance in "The Cradle Song" on May 6 because of the sudden illness of her husband, Charles MacArthur. Her role will be played by Evelyn Varden.

WASHINGTON, April 18--A budget surplus of $2,000,000,000 this fiscal year was forecast today by the staff of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. President Eisen hower in January had estimated the budget barely would be in balance, with a $230,000,000 surplus.

Although some of the oils and papers showed strength, the stock market as a whole ended virtually unchanged yesterday, rising gently in the morning and then wiping out its gains before the close.
James D. Norris, president of the International Boxing Club, yesterday outlined a heavyweight elimination program to determine either a challenger for a successor to Rocky Marciano, the champion.
SALINAS, Calif., April 18-- Senator Estes Kefauver told Californians today that he had... "no alibis, no regrets, no excuses" for his defeat in yesterday's New Jersey primary.

Push-button yachting is here for sure. There is no longer any doubt. The fun and thrill have even been taken out of blowing a foghorn on a pleasure craft. An inventor has come along with a "power can" to blow fog and signal horns automatically.

RABAT, Morocco, April 18-- While negotiations are getting under way for the transfer of authority in Morocco to Moroccans' hands, the difficulty of maintaining order during the transition period is emphasized by daily events.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 18-- A possible relationship between salt and one form of hypertension has been found in a survey of 1,346 employes of the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

Frederick Schwartz, cab driver, is a man of principle. He has 35 cents to prove it. It took eight months and eighteen days to accomplish it, but Mr. Schwartz collected this sum, representing the full amount of an unpaid fare, in an action instituted in Manhattan Small Claims Court.

Royal Lark of the Maine Chance Farm won the $23,350 Prioress at Jamaica yesterday. Walter Blum guided the daughter of Royal Blood to a nose triumph over C.V. Whitney's Aiming High in the ninth running of the six-furlong stakes for 3-yearold fillies.
IF the City Center can perform the whole series of springtime musical dramas as beautifully as it staged "The King and I" last evening, the town has something to enjoy and look forward to.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 18--Joseph W. Barlow of Flemington, former chairman of the New York University Spanish Department, died yesterday at Hunterdon Medical Center. His age was 71.

QUIET but intense, the gouache paintings by Pat Adams at the Zabriskie Gallery, 835 Madison Avenue, restore to painting a certain delicate, poetic touch that seems to have fallen into desuetued since the late nineteenth century.
DARIEN, Conn., April 18-- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Sylvester have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Dalton Sylvester, to George David Gwilt.
The Finch College Nursery School at 540 East Seventysixth Street will benefit from a dance to be held tomorrow in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.
Paul G. Hoffman appealed last night for a more liberal and realistic tariff and trade policy to help the United States compete with the new Soviet economic offensive.

Since it had committed itself to the farm bill monstrosity that was to meet with a Presidential rejection, the House of Representatives had no choice yesterday but to go through the motions of trying to override the White House veto.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 18-- The United States has become a full member of the Economic Committee of the Baghdad Pact.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- The House of Representatives rejected today a Democratic motion to override President Eisenhower's veto of the farm bill. The vote was 211 to 202.
Vice President Richard M. Nixon credited the Eisenhower Administration last night with halting an American drift toward nationalization of resources and socialism.

LONDON, April 18--Talks on international issues between the British and Soviet leaders began tonight, six hours after Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party chief, had arrived in London.
The Douglas Aircraft Compang, Inc., realized net earnings of $5,113,000, or $1.38 a share, on net sales of $201,026,000 in the quarter ended Feb. 29.
Mayor Wagner will reappoint Irving Ben Cooper as Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions.

CHICAGO, April 18--Nervous price swings were witnessed in the grain markets today, but in wheat a stronger turn developed. In corn there was some pressure at times. Soybean futures moved irregularly in a moderate range, with offerings increasing on the hard spots.
A 38-year-old man was free yesterday because three justices of the Special Sessions Court could not answer three questions about burned rubbish.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- To the nation's newspaper editors, an Eisenhower-Nixon ticket apparently looks like a sure bet for re-election this year.

CLEVELAND, April 18-- Isaac Evans, president of the Master Mechanics Company, chemical manufacturers, died today at the age of 72. He earned international goodwill for donating livestock to countries whose herds were depleted during World War II.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18--Eugene R. Black, who says he is a conservative banker "committed to the future," boldly forecast today a long-term expansion of the world's economy and trade.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 18--Grace Kelly of Philadelphia and Hollywood and Prince Rainier III of Monaco were married today.
HOUSTON, April 18 (AP)-- Hamilton Richardson rallied to eliminate Grant Golden and enter the quarter-finals of the twenty-second annual River Oaks tennis tournament today.

JERSEY CITY, April 18-- More than 3,000 school youngsters gamboled and frolicked on the green in Roosevelt Stadium today in an exuberant preview of the Brooklyn Dodgers' opening against the Phillies tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- The perjury trial of Aldo L. Icardi turned today to a consideration of Congress' power to investigate.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN has written a Serenade that is attractive in places and ought to be better in sum. Just as this work, scored for violin solo and string orchestra with percussion, has begun to persuade us that it is going to be all music, it fritters away its opportunity.
THE Jersey City Dodgers, a road-company version of the Brooklyn Dodgers, will open a seven-game season at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City this afternoon.

The Shipbuilders Council of America held its twenty-seventh annual meeting in the Whitehall Club yesterday in an atmosphere of cautious optimism over the ship construction outlook for the immediate future.
PITTSBURGH, April 18 (AP)-- Irwin D. Wolf, president of Kaufmann Department Stores, died today at his home. He had been ill for several months. His age was 61.

Potato prices continued easier yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the second day in a row after advancing for six consecutive previous trading sessions. The volume, 2,077 car lots (45.00 pounds to a car) was the fourth largest of the year.

LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) --The British pound sterling rose today in terms of dollar value to $2.81 1/16, its highest rate since August, 1954, in dealings between London and New York. The rate in August, 1954, was $2.81 1/8.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 18--In her civil marriage today to Prince Rainier III of Monaco, Grace Kelly took the first step toward sharing her husband's many titles as well as his throne.

Yale University's defending Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League champions scored their thirteenth straight Eastern League victory over a three-season span by defeating Columbia, 10--3, at Baker Field yesterday.
PARIS, April 18--The French National Assembly after a long Easter recess, unseated two Poujadist Deputies today. The evictions were on technical grounds.
THE cutting edges of cutlery, if properly sharpened, will perform efficiently and last a lifetime, says the American Cutlery Manufacturers Association.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- The Democratic majority on the Government Operations Committee of the House of Representatives made public today a report sharply criticizing Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, and his top aides.
JERUSALEM, April 18--Six high school students from New York expressed mixed feelings of admiration and moral outrage six-day tour of Israel.
A family ownership of nearly 300 years has been terminated in the sale of the Sherrill homestead on Main Street in East Hampton, L.I.

Postage stamps, photographic equipment and foreign cars worth $20,500,000 will go on display at the Coliseum immediately after the opening ceremonies on April 28.

Eleven motorcycle policemen involved in the courtesy card racket were found guilty yesterday after departmental trials. They were fined from fifteen to thirty days' pay by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today $3,350,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Portland Gas and Coke Company at a price to yield 4.25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 19--A Catholic missionary who was imprisoned for four years by the Chinese Communists testified today that the writings of some Americans had been used to help "brainwash" prisoners.

With trading the dullest since Feb, 16, the stock market followed the pattern that has marked every day this week. It made slight gains at the start and then closed generally lower.

THE second "Giselle" of the Ballet Theatre's season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night had Rosella Hightower in the title role. It was her first appearance here in the venerable classic since the visit of the DeCuevas Ballet six years ago, which added to the interest of the occasion.

TRENTON, April 24--Gov. Robert B. Meyner and top officials of his administration minimized today a report that strongly implied wrongdoing on the part of a State Senator and former officials of the State Highway Authority.
OAKLAND, Calif., April 24 (AP) --An investigating attorney said today he would not be "czar" of California boxing for $50,000 a year "because I don't have that strong a stomach."
Jacob S. Manheimer, an attorney and Jewish leader, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home, 322 Central Park West. He was 57 years old. His law office was at 295 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- House Republicans decided unanimously today to fight for an Administration soil bank bill that could put as much as $500,000,000 in farmers' pockets before the November election.
The five-story store and apartment building at 2172 Eighth Avenue has been sold by Leonard J. Winston, real estate operator, to an investing client of Lawrence King, attorney.

Automotive Associates Inc, buying office, in 175 5th Ave; Hollinghurst Co Inc, fertilizers, in 60 E 42d St; R. A. Hirschler Co Inc, exportsimports, in 19 W 44th St; MazelSiegel Inc, general merchandise, in 26 E 33d St--Helmsley-Spear Inc, broker.

Two men received jail sentences yesterday in Federal court for income tax violations. Hans Paul, 65-year-old former head waiter in the WaldorfAstoria banquet division, was sentenced to four months' imprisonment and fined $7,500 for evading $4,992 in 1951 income tax.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association opened its seventieth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday with discussions that stressed the rising costs of publication.
AGAIN, "Goodbye Again." First produced in 1932, it was revived in 1943, and put on for the third and last time at the Helen Hayes Theatre last evening.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer yesterday announced its intention of branching out into the play-producing field on a wide scale. Sidney Phillips, a local Metro executive and former stage producer, has been chosen to head the new project.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Adlai E. Stevenson accused the Eisenhower Administration today of "Government without representation."
THE oldest delicacy shop in town, which closed tempora rily last January, has reopened in spanking new headquarters at 52 East Fifty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Foreign aid officials asked Congress today to double aid appropriations for the Middle East. Most of the increase would be for military aid to members of the Baghdad Pact.
Attorneys for T. Vincent Quinn and his two former law partners asked Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday to order them acquitted of charges that they had shared illegal fees.
An official of Lufthansa announced yesterday that the company had ordered four Boeing 707 intercontinental jet airliners.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 24-- Henry Stephenson, for more than half a century an actor on stage and screen, died in St. Luke's Hospital here today. He was 85 years old on April 16.
"Neither a borrower nor a lender be," was the cagey advice of Polonius in Shakespeare's Hamlet. But commercial banks often have to be both.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 --The bones of a fifty-foot sea monster, the largest marine reptile known to man, are being prepared for public display at Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology.

Export of United States surplus agricultural produce at prices below cost poses a serious problem for Denmark, her Consul General in New York, Eyvind Bartels, declared yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon of the Export Managers Club of New York at the Statler Hotel.
ODESSA, U.S.S.R., April 24-- Odessans said today that Stalin's one-man rule had caused the Soviet Union to err in international relations.

Paul Keres and Vassily Smyslov, who had been tied for first place with their fellow Russian, Ewfim Geller, agreed to a draw after nineteen moves of a Ruy Lopez in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Amsterdam yesterday.

The Port of New York Authority proposed yesterday six heliports in or near the heart of the metropolitan area.
World merchant shipbuilding has reached a post-war high mark, with 7,000,000 gross ton under construction in yard around the globe.
TIP to the quick-getaway cult: zoom over to the house of Aronowicz, where a group of "sports car furs" as sleek as Jaguars are being offered at Tin Lizzie prices.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Southern Democrats ran the House of Representatives through a parliamentary hoop today in a successful effort to delay action on a civil rights measure.
Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division was credited last night with having brought the Supreme Court calender up to date for the first time in almost half a century.

RABAT, French Morocco, April 24--Ahmed Balafrej, secretary general of the Istiqlal party, the dominant nationalist group, is expected to become the first Foreign Minister of newly independent Morocco.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) --The University of Alabama asked the Supreme Court today to order a rehearing of the Autherine J. Lucy segregation case.

Preventable accidents are crippling mititary efficiency, Maj. Gen. Ralph C. Cooper, Chief of Staff of the First Army, said yesterday. He estimated the accident cost to the First Army last year at $2,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- The "hundred housewives conference" today turned thumbs down on picture windows.

Still another new cigarette is to make its appearance. It will be called the Salem and it will be a king-size filter-tip described as "menthol fresh" by its manufacturer, the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
Trevor Huddleston, an Anglican priest who has spent the last twelve years in South Africa, has written an account of his experiences there in "Naught for Your Comfort."

The fifteen New York State Supreme Court justices in the Second District, Kings and Richmond Counties, yesterday accused Federal Judge Harold R. Medina of "a lack of judicial temperament" in his criticisms of the state court system.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Secretary of State Dulles will take to Paris next week new United States proposals for transforming the North Atlantic alliance into a broader association of free nations.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24-- Pennsylvanians voted today in one of the dullest Presidential primary elections on record.
The Ford Motor Company's first annual stockholders meeting may be held in a circus tent.
The breach between the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman widened yesterday.

JOHN MASON BROWN, the Confederate Aristotle, turns in his extraordinarily lively new book from esthetics to politics. It is called "Through These Men," and it presents a searching commentary on the personal histories of conspicuously prominent personalities on the passing scene of American politics, or, if you will, statesmanship.

CASEY STENGEL couldn't resist. Twentytwo years ago the mischief bubbled within him as much as it does today--maybe even more so. For one thing, Casey couldn't be serious about the team he was then managing because the Brooklyn Dodgers of that era were a laughable lot. But as the 1934 season reached the end, the downtrodden Brooks beat the Giants two in a row knocking the New Yorkers out of the pennant.

CINCINNATI, April 24 (AP)-- President Warren C. Giles of the National League today was "convinced" a beer can and bottle barrage during a New York Giants-Phillies game at Philadelphia Sunday was not directed personally at Whitey Lockman, a Giant outfielder.
MADRID, April 24--The need for freedom and reform sought by Spanish youth was brought out today at the trial here of four young intellectuals.

Operating revenues of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for twelve months ended March 31 reached a new high of $503,067,104. This marked the first time the utility has topped the half-billion mark in any twelve months.
A stevedoring company official testified yesterday that he was forced to employ Frank Acosta two weeks after the Yonkers waterfront figure had been suspended as a pier hiring agent.

Events tonight: Orchestra da Camera, Remus Tzincoca conducting, Rudolf Firkusny, pianist, Town Hall; Mozart Anniversary Festival, Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conducting, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, both at 8:30.
Brokers in Palm Springs, Cal., are now as close to the trading floor of the Stock Exchange as their counterparts right here in New York.
Savings and loan associations were urged yesterday to restrain their own borrowing to "stem the inflationary tide."
The public confidence in President Eisenhower is matched by a trust in his ability and sincerity throughout the world, Senator Leverett Saltonstall said yesterday.
DESIGNERS of the future took a long look at the past yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum.
KANSAS CITY, April 24 (UP) Steve Gromek held the Kansas City Athletics to six hits today while Detroit pounded three pitchers for ten hits, including three homers, in a 7-4 victory.

CHICAGO, April 24--Except for rye futures, which advanced sharply following a big upturn at Winnipeg, there was considerable pressure on grains and on old crop soybean futures in early trading today on the Board of Trade. But there was some commission support on the declines, and soybeans and wheat closed on a sharp upturn.
The May potato option fell as much as the -cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Two more United States corporations joined an exclusive club last year. They qualified for membership by reporting total assets in excess of $1,000,000,000.
TURIN, Italy, April 23--Nine out of every ten motor vehicles produced in Italy are manufactured by Fiat.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Thirty American scientists were elected here today to the National Academy of Sciences. The academy is the highest ranking scientific body in the United States. It limits its membership to 600.
It couldn't have happened at a better time than in an Olympic year. There hasn't been a college rowing season in a long spell in which the competition was so wide open as it is now.

Heavy buying and a large attendance were reported yesterday at the fall showing of boys' wear lines at the New Yorker Hotel. The five-day show, which ends tomorrow, is sponsored by the Boys' Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association and the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association.

Two of the leading candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination called yesterday for a revision of American policies in the light of Russia's projected completion of an intercontinental missile with a hydrogenbomb warhead.

The New Haven Railroad cautiously patted itself on the back yesterday. It said its on-time performance for inbound commuter trains for the first three months of 1956 had shown "marked improvement" over the same period last year.

PARIS, April 24--A transformed North Atlantic Alliance, adapted to an economic as well as to a military "cold war," was seen by European officials here today as the logical, even probable, result of the speech by Secretary of State Dulles in New York yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24--Burt Lancaster will co-star with Tony Curtis in "Sweet Smell of Success." It will be the first picture to be produced by Mr. Curtis' independent company, Curtleigh Productions, in association with Hecht-Lancaster Productions.

ST. LOUIS, April 24 (AP)-- Ken Boyer drove in four runs tonight with a homer and single as Vinegar Bend Mizell and Ellis Kinder pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-3 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 24--The Administration rejected today the major recommendations by a Government commission for large expenditures to develop seven areas inhabited by 9,000,000 Negroes.

CAMP SMITH, N.Y., April 24 --Police officers from New York City "captured" some armed "desperadoes" who had barricaded themselves in old buildings here today. But there was no shooting. The deadly work was simulated in a field training refresher course.

The retention of the Jamaica race track as an operating track for "at least several years and perhaps indefinitely" is indicated by "several factors," a track spokesman told the Public Service Commission yesterday.

Nikita Khrushchev and Nikolai Bulganin have stepped into a strange new world and it has disconcerted them. To read what Mr. Khrushchev, Communist party chief, has been saying in Britain the last few days is to be covered with bewilderment and confusion.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Lawyers were reviewing today the legal background of the Supreme Court's action in a South Carolina bus case. They came up with answers that were not apparent when the ruling was announced yesterday.
Sales and earnings of the Continental Can Company before and after taxes broke all previous records in the first quarter this year.
One of the season's freshest and liveliest evenings of contemporary chamber music was presented last night in Carl Fischer Concert Hall by New Music Concerts.
The reported shelving of veterans' benefit bills by a House committee was denounced last night as "unwise, unnecessary and illogical."

A large subscription has been reported for the pre-opening performance of the new musical "The Most Happy Fella" on the night of May 2 at the Imperial Theatre for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society of New York.

Stockholders of the Phillips Petroleum Company held their annual meeting in Bartlesville, Okla., yesterday, but they got the "big" news of the day after the meeting, when directors voted to split to the shares twofor-one.
QUESTION--Mr. Secretary, there has been a lot of interest and speculation on your remarks in New York yesterday about expanding the operation or purpose of NATO.

ABUNDANCE, the graceful wench in Pulitzer Memorial Fountain, and tough old William Tecumseh Sherman, who more or less face each other in Central Park Plaza, are in the hands right now of Park Department beauty experts.
The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday confirmed receipt of an offer from the British American Oil Company to acquire its wholly-owned subsidiary, the Canadian Gulf Oil Company.
KANSAS CITY, April 24 (AP) --If you are an American League baseball fan, look closely before you advise the umpire to get a pair of glasses.

Of all the litter-strewn areas of New York the worst are open lots. Almost 7,000 of what in a country village would be called "dumps"--if they were allowed to exist in it at all--are now the target of the latest salient in the coordinated battle against the city's dirt.
LORD MAYOR of the City of London is by tradition and the nature of the office no job for a man with an inferiority complex.
Golf can be a topic for discussion even during the early hours of the morning on the Long Island Rail Road. Conductor George Baskiel finds it so.
PARIS, April 24--Premier Guy Mollet told visiting Soviet newspapermen today that France would remain faithful to her allies and would seek peaceful solutions in accord with them.

MOSCOW, April 24--A Soviet publication charged Stalin today with responsibility for enormous wartime losses of Soviet manpower and materiel. He was accused of having failed to heed warnings from his own intelligence service and of having neglected industrial mobilization.

Owner George D. Widener, Jockey Paul Bailey and Trainer W.F. Mulholland combined for a second straight victory in a Jamaica feature yesterday. This time the medium was Rare Treat, a 4-year-old filly who won the $10,000 Rego Park Handicap.
Teletypesetter service by short wave radio was begun yesterday by The United Press.
The Yankees turned the tables yesterday on Chuck Stobbs, the pitcher who had accounted for the only blemish on the record of the American League leaders this season.
A plan was proposed yesterday for nursing homes in the city to pool resources to employ experts they cannot now afford on an individual basis.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) --The United States Chamber of Commerce told Congress today that local community effort-- not Federal subsidies--should solve the unemployment and economic problems of depressed areas.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 24 (AP)--The medal winner, Doug Sanders of Miami, scored a 5and-4 opening-round victory over Keely Grice of Charlotte, N.C., in the North and South amateur golf tournament today on the No. 2 course of the Pinehurst Country Club.

It is regrettable that the state remains without the needed legislation that would have streamlined the archaic traffic code to bring it into conformity with modern rules of the road that have been adopted elsewhere throughout the country.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 25 (AP)--Bermuda yachtsmen took over the first three places in the competition for the Princess Elizabeth Cup today but only three points separated seven dinghies after three races.
LINCOLN, R.I., April 25-- There is nothing pretentious about Lincoln Downs. It is only a little three-quarter of a mile track on the outskirts of Providence.

Adlai E. Stevenson accused the Eisenhower Administration last night of shirking its moral responsibilities in the field of civil rights. The Administration, he charged, has con tributed nothing toward an atmosphere in which the Supreme Court's school integration decision "could be carried out in tranquillity and order."

A radio and television talent union has notified employers of its members that it will take action when employment is denied to a performer "because of misleading statements by AWARE, Inc., or any other similar organization."

A four-story business building at 1146-58 East New York Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Bishop, McCormick Bishop, Inc., to Par Motor Parts, Inc.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 18 points (90 cents a bale) up to 11 points (55 cents a bale) lower than on Tuesday.
Despite a world-wide shortage of newsprint, newspapers reportedly have been able to print the advertising scheduled and are said to be confident that they can continue to do so.

Stocks were generally dull yesterday, although a few active issues dotted the list with sharp gains and losses. At the close the rails were higher, owing to the increased Pennsylvania dividend, but industrials sagged to give a somewhat lower appearance to the list.
HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., April 25--For the last two days, nearly 400 company presidents have been discussing here how to become even more successful.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The United States expelled today two members of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations for their part in sending five Soviet seamen home.

BALTIMORE, April 25--Despite a porous defense, which was guilty of four errors, the Yankees turned back the Orioles, 4--2, tonight for their fifth straight victory.

Earnings of the American Gas and Electric Company are expected to rise "almost 10 per cent" this year to top $40,000,000 for the first time. Philip Sporn, president, told 250 stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 25--A Senate inquiry issued a subpoena tonight for Murray Chotiner, campaign manager in 1952 for Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
ANOTHER milestone in the direction of automation-inthe-home has been reached with the 1956 gas ranges. The new models introduced this month are almost all automatically controlled.
Roughly four out of five of the companies that have found uranium in Utah won't make a dime from it, the state says.

BUENOS AIRES, April 25-- Argentina's Junta Consultiva, a body of advisers, presented a new problem for the Provisional Government today. It advised the Government to expropriate all foreign electrical utility companies.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 25 (AP)--Ham Richardson, a United States Davis Cup player from Westfield, N.J., played brilliantly in a pair of marathon tennis matches today and gained the quarter-final round of the annual Bournemouth tournament.
The fourth annual Kips Bay dinner dance in the ballroom of the Plaza this evening will be attended by prominent persons, many of whom will entertain in connection with the event.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- President Eisenhower defended today the aims of the United States in continuing its tests with the hydrogen bomb. He emphasized that the goal was to develop a more campact bomb for military uses and not a bigger one for "mass destruction."

Both sides rested their cases yesterday in the Waterfront Commission hearings of charges that Frank Acosta had accepted kickbacks from longshoremen he engaged when he was hiring agent at a Yonkers sugar pier.
LONDON, April 25--United States officials who saw a faint prospect Monday for tentative agreement with the Soviet Union on disarmament were not so hopeful today.

While helicopter travel in the New York area is still in its infancy, there seems to be ample reason for planning a substantial future. The absence of a commercial heliport in Manhattan has been a stunning han- . . .
MINNEAPOLIS, April 25-- A major step toward the gradual elimination of the last racial barrier in the Methodist Church was taken here tonight.
JERUSALEM, Thursday, April 26--A bitter dispute between right and left wing extremists paralyzed the World Zionist Congress last night.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- President Eisenhower affirmed without qualification today the authority of the Federal Reserve Board to handle money and credit as an agency independent of the Executive Branch of the Government.

Fifteen years of national prosperity have brought the Negro in the North more economic proggress than in any period since the Emancipation Proclamation. But the Negro worker started from such a submerged position that he remains the low man on the job opportunity ladder.

Secretary of State Dulles suggested in his press conference on Tuesday that the Soviet grip on its Eastern European satellites is loosening. Mr. Dulles indicated his belief that recent changes in Soviet policy "have put a certain premium now upon Titoism."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25--Twelve sponsoring nations made public today their detailed draft for the establishment of an international agency to promote the peaceful use of atomic energy.

The Government yesterday lost its move to bring to trial William Z. Foster, 76-year-old head of the Communist party in the United States. Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan ruled that a trial might result in Foster's death.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 (UP) --John T. Fulton, a former national Amateur Athletic Union 800-meter champion, has charged that Daniel J. Ferris, the secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., paid his expenses for a private trip to Canada in violation of A.A.U. expense allowance rules.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23-- "There is no room for Communists in Brazil," according to Vice President Joao Goulart. But communism must be fought by improving the standard of living of Brazilians rather than by violent repression, he said in an interview last week.
FLORENCE, Italy, April 25 (UP)--Art Larsen, a former United States tennis champion who is favored to win the men's singles in Florence's international tournament, won his first two matches today.

Richard W. Slocum, president of the American Newspaper, Publishers Association, charged yesterday that Federal, state and local government officials were interfering with freedom of the press. He said they did so by withholding information that the public was entitled to have.

Commodity futures were generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cottonseed oil, rubber, zinc, hides, copper, lead, cocoa and soybean oil declined; potatoes rose, and price movements for sugar and wool mere mixed.
Paul Muni will take a twomonth vacation from his starring role as the defense attorney in "Inherit the Wind" beginning July 1.
Stanley M. Isaacs, minority leader in the City Council, cast a wary eye yesterday at the project to convert a half-acre of Central Park into a parking area for the Tavern-on-the-Green Restaurant.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Government indicated today it would not offer financial aid or guarantees to help build a petroleum pipeline from the Gulf Coast to the Ohio-Pittshurgh area.

The Southern Pacific Company, the nation's longest (mileage) railroad, is taking to the air. The company announced yesterday that through its highway subsidiary, the Pacific Motor Trucking Company, it has entered into an agreement with three airlines to provide an inteerated truck-air freight service.
In the chilling setting of 47degree temperature, the Dodgers last night made their first appearance in history under the lee of Coogan's Bluff as world champions.
PHILADELPHIA, April 25-- National, state and local politicians juggled Pennsylvania's Presidential primary election returns today with the dexterity of budget balancers.
Judge Harold R. Medina may have "demonstrated a lack of judicial temperament" in his recent criticism of the courts, as justices in two New York City Supreme Court districts have now charged.

EVERETT SLOANE, one of the stars of "Patterns" and Rod Serling, its author, were reunited last night in the playwright's latest work, "Noon on Doomsday," on the "Theatre Guild-United States Steel Hour" over Channel 2. What honors there were went this time to Mr. Sloane.

"LA CLEMENZA DI TITO" stands low in the Mozart canon. The opera was written several months before the composer's death, when his body was weary and sick and his mind weighed down by the pressure of other obligations.
CAIRO, April 25--The leader of the Algerian moderates said today he had joined forces with the National Liberation Front in an all-out war for freedom from French rule.
MADRID, April 25--Four persons received jail sentences today of six months to a year and were fined $125 to $250 on charges of having issued illegal and clandestine propaganda.
Hofstra scored two unearned runs in the ninth inning to gain a ten-inning 4-4 tie with Manhattan in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game at Van Cortlandt Park, Bronx, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Administration has came up with a provisional answer to its foreign-aid dilemma.

Two fight promoters testified yesterday in Federal Court that they had been required to sign agreements granting to the International Boxing Club a percentage of the receipts in bouts involving a former world heavy weight champion. Ezzard Charles.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 25--A government White Paper issued today told how the effort of Heinrich Himmler, Hitler's Gestapo chief, to save his own skin resulted in the delivery of thousands of war prisoners to Sweden.

LONDON, April 25 (Reuters) --Vivien Leigh returned to the London stage tonight, after more than two years' absence, in Noel Coward's latest play "South Sea Bubble." The comedy is set in a mythical British islandcolony in the Pacific.
The United Press reported yesterday that additional facilities to speed the movement of news and pictures had been a primary development in its operations abroad last year.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The "one hundred housewives" here to design the future American home today spoke up for sidewalks--on both sides of the street and not next to the curb.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) --A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Trans World Airlines be permitted to extend its international route from India to Manila.
John Storrs, American sculptor and pupil of Rodin, died Sunday in Mer, Loire-et-Cher, France.

New York City subway trains are to begin transporting mail on an experimental basis before the end of the summer. The joint announcement was made yesterday by Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority, and Robert H. Schaffer, postmaster for Manhattan and the Bronx.

Prophets Bell was an easy winner of the $16,725 Rosedale at Jamaica yesterday. With Eddie Arcaro riding to his third triumph of the afternoon, the Reginald Webster filly scored by more than four lengths over Alan W. Vaughan's Anita V. Memo, part of John H. Clark's triple entry, was third.

THE annual rage to determine and record who caught the most and the biggest is upon us. The fishing Tournaments, Contests, Competitions, Derbies and perhaps Hambletonians have begun, are beginning or soon will begin.
Frank Costello has lost one of his big gambles--an offer of voluntary exile to avoid prison.
T. Vincent Quinn was absolved yesterday of charges that he had sold influence in income tax cases while sitting in Congress.

BEAUTY is a gift given to the few, but the search for it by the many makes for a business. Today a multi-million-dollar corporation that was built upon the desire for a good complexion marks its 150th anniversary.

SATURDAY, 11:30 A.M.: Four stories will be told at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place. At 1:15 P.M. a live animal program will be given, followed by a science, cultural history and planetarium demonstration at 2:30, 3 and 3:30 P.M. Free.

A draw in eighteen moves in the sixteenth round yesterday enabled Paul Keres to regain sole possession of first place in the world chess championship challengers' tournament, according to a report from the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The Senate passed by voice vote tonight a bill designed to curb future expansion of bankink companies. The bill now heads for conference with the House to reconcile minor differences. Final enactment of holding company legislation now seems assured.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25--The Hollywood A.F.L. Film Council announced today cancellation of plans to organize a "nation-wide consumer's boycott" against the movie "Daniel Boone."
Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, Consul General of France in this city from 1931 to 1940, died yesterday in Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital. His age was 79. He had suffered a heart attack on Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Democrats acted today to get a revised election-year farm bill, including direct subsidies to farmers.
LONDON, April 25--The talks between British and Soviet leaders ended this evening without any spectacular immediate results.

A Balzac of the station wagon set, Mr, De Vries continues here the casual human comedy he began in "The Tunnel of Love." Although his new novel is ostensibly concerned with year-round natives of Exurbia, the most pow erful weapon in his characters' armory remains the country club.
Mayor Wagner repeated yesterday that the teacher salary increases this year would be limited to $21,000,000.
WASHINGTON, APRIL 25-- The State Department opposed today a senate resolution aimed at stamping out forced labor in the world.

MOSCOW, April 25--The salaries of the highest paid members of the Soviet professional and administrative class have been drastically cut by the Government. In some cases the reduction amounts to 50 per cent.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 25--This city's boycott by the Negro population of the local bus line remained constant today. The City commission continued to he adamant in demanding compliance with custom. And another round of maneuvers by spokesmen for the various disputants was scheduled for tomorrow.

The State of Ohio borrowed $50,000,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds to finance the construction of major thoroughfares of the state highway system.
