The Westinghouse Electric Corporation suffered a net loss of $18,575,000 in its strike-bound first quarter, but directors voted the regular quarterly dividends yesterday on the common and preferred stock. In the first three months of last year net earnings were $12,782,000 or 75 cents a share.

AS the second premiere of its season at the Metropol itan Opera House, the Ballet Theatre last night presented. Agues de Mille's "Rib of Eve," to music of Morton Gould, with d cor by Oliver Smith and costumes by Irene Sharaff.

A capacity audience of high school pupils from the five boroughs yesterday heard the New York Philharmonic-Symphony under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos. The concert was held at Julia Richman High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue.
A Greenwich Village property passed to new control in a deal reported yesterday by Loomis J. Grossman and Hugh K. McGovern, realty operators.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 25 --After examining the question of United States aid to Ceylon Prime Minister S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike said today he was satisfied that there were no strings attached. He has been in office for two weeks since his left-wing coalition won an overwhelming victory in the elections earlier this month.

The City Stores Company, which includes Franklin Simon and Oppenheim, Collins specialty stones in its fifty-three retail-unit operation, last year exceeded a quarter of a billion dollars in sales for the first time in its history.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- President Eisenhower said today he still had no "final and definitive" answer from Vice President Richard M. Nixon on whether he desired renomination.
WASHINGTON, April 25--The really indicative Presidential preference primaries are yet to come so far as the Democratic contest is concerned.
MAHWAH, N.J., April 25 --A car welder's painting of his own grimy task won a special award today in a competition sponsored by the Art Council of New Jersey and the Ford Motor Company.
WESTBURY. L.I., April 25 (UP)--Blackstone Widower breezed to a two-length victory over Master Fingo in 2:05 2/5 tonight in the $4,000 Levittown Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. My Scotch Belle was third.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 25 --Frederick B. Rentschler, board chairman of the United Aircraft Corporation since 1935, died today at his winter home here. He was 68 years old. Mr. Rentschler had been ill for some time. His family was with him at his death.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, added his voice today to Administration pleas for liberalization of the immigration laws.
Governor Harriman, Mayor Wagner and Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield will speak at a forty-five-minute ceremony opening the Coliseum on Saturday morning.

A pleasure craft skipper has obligations. Since accidents can happen, he must be prepared for them. That's where the United States Power Squadrons come in. They drive home to all hands the importance of safety in small boat handling and navigation.

All political camps claimed victory yesterday in the results from the Pennsylvania and Massachusetts primaries. However, one result could not be contradicted: President Eisenhower showed again that he was a vote-getter.
Dr. Philip Ingram Nash of 3100 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, long a leader in civic and medical circles in Coney Island, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Coney Island Hospital. His age was 80.

WASHINGTON April 25-- Consumer credit could increase by $20,000,000,000 and still be within the 1940 ratio of private debt to the annual gross national product, Wallis G. Hockey, credit manager of Charles A. Stevens Co., Chicago, said today.
Following is the text of the address given last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Adlai E. Stevenson, as recorded by The New York Times:
LONDON, April 25--The British boxing world is reeling today as a result of the rise to prominence of a 22-year-old minister's son from one of the farthest and tinest corners of the Empire.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP)--Hogs and prime steers matched their 1956 highs and lambs sold at their best prices since September, 1955, on the livestock market today.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 (AP)--Ernest T. Weir, chairman of National Steel Corporation, said today he could not agree with the United States Steel Corporation that an in crease was not needed in the basic price of steel.
Safe-driving awards for twenty-one daily newspapers wet a announced yesterday at the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Waldorf--Astoria Hotel.
BOSTON, April 25--Massachusetts Democrats may back Representative John W. McCormack on the first ballot for the Presidential nomination at Chicago in August.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 25-- Fordham's baseball team posted its fifth victory in six games by defeating Navy, 7--3, today.

Eastern States Health Education Conference, New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street. 9:30 A.M. Afternoon session, 1:30 P.M. Dinner meeting, 7 o'clock. Speaker: Dr. Gerald Caplan. Continues tomorrow morning.

Remus Tzincoca brought to an end in Town Hall last night the series of three concerts in which he has conducted the Orchestra da Camera. His soloist was Rudolf Firkusny, in Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Secretary of State Dulles declared tonight that the day must come when the Soviet Union would be willing to subject the new power of nuclear weapons to the control of the world community of nations.

WASHINGTON, April 25--The first glimpses of life at work as it fashions living tissues out of simpler constituents were described today at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.
ODESSA, U.S.S.R., April 25 --The Mayor of Odessa said today the Soviet Union's new policy of collective leadership already was manifest in his own administration as well as on the national scene.

At this distance the situation in Algeria seems to be getting worse for the French. One sincerely hopes that appearances are deceptive, for it would be tragic if France lost this struggle by going down to the same sort of defeat she met in Indochina.

SEYMOUR FOGEL, a wellknown muralist from Aus tin, Tex., is showing recent oils and temperas at the DuveenGraham Galleries, 1014 Madison Avenue. Mr. Fogel paints constructions of a geometer's figures, arcs and lines in the faceted manner of the postCubists. His color is often lyrical, as in the warm-toned "Votive Lights," and is laid on in thin, even layers.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- City consumer prices rose an average of .1 per cent between mid-February and mid-March. It was the first advance since last November.
Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri heard a description of teamster-union operations here yesterday that sounded, he said, as if rules were "made for the occasion as a matter of convenience."
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The House Judiciary Committee overrode Southern objections today and approved the Administration's civil rights proposals.

The General American Transportation Corporation is offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe to $23,810,700 of subordinated debentures convertible into common stock until May 1, 1971. The debentures will mature on May 1, 1981.
LONDON, April 25--Progress I made by Soviet scientists toward controlling thermonuclear explosions was described here today by Prof. Igor V. Kurchatov, leading Russian authority on atomic energy.

IF a fellow's memory is long enough, bells will jingle pleasantly along Memory Lane with surprising regularity. The appear ance of the brilliant Oxford University relay team at the Penn Relays, starting tomorrow, sets into motion a tintinnabulation of its own.

A tour of four Westchester County homes--one each of Renaissance, Colonial, functionalmodern and nautical styles--will benefit the Radcliffe-in-Westchester Scholarship Fund. This fourth annual event will take place on the afternoon of May 19.

In the world of wonders created on earth, there are few so remarkable as the modern phenomenon of speech-making. I don't suppose there is a meal at which ten or more people gather that is not blessed, or otherwise, by an address of some sort.

THE wayward spring is delaying vegetable growth, with the result that the market is undersupplied for this time of year. Fresh shad, repelled by the cold, has yet to run in the Hudson in any quantities. Reflecting recent price increases at wholesale, lamb and pork prices are moving up the retail scale.

ALTHOUGH the American Institute of Decorators is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary this month, interior decorating is still a new profession. It is new in the sense that its function, purpose and methods are still misunderstood by many women.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26--Billy Wilder, the directorproducer, has a full year of work lined up. He signed today with Arthur Hornblow Jr. and Edward Small to direct their film version of "Witness for the Prosecution," based on the Agatha Christie play.

KANSAS CITY, April 26 (AP) --Chico Carrasquel made life miserable for Kansas City pitchers today. He drove in seven runs as the Cleveland Indians crushed the Athletics 14--2, behind Early Wynn's four-hit pitching.
TRENTON, April 26--The public and the press were charged today with a substantial measure of responsibility for the present high rate of juvenile delinquency.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Near-unanimous approval of a record $51,860,000,000 roadbuilding program was predicted ...
A psychiatrist said yesterday that rapidly changing social patterns were making the American family freer, more creative, more confusing and essentially insecure.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26--The Soviet delegation at the United Nations denied today that its chief, Arkady A. Sobolev, or his aides had forced five Russian sailors to give up asylum in the United States and return home.

CHICAGO, April 26--Golden Reel awards for twenty-two outstanding 16mm. productions of 1955 were made here tonight by Dr. Paul A. Wagner, president of the Film Council of America. The ceremonies marked the end of the third annual film assembly.
CAIRO, April 26--Official sources said today that Egypt had accepted all of the principles and most of the specific items of Dag Hammarskjold's plan for ending the Arab-Israeli border tensions.

FERNDALE, N.Y., April 28-- Rabbi Aaron H. Blumenthal, new head of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, appealed today for close cooperation between Jewish and Christian leaders of this country. He urged such a joint effort to augment Judaeo-Christian concepts in American life.
Arrangements were made yesterday to accommodate 10,000 persons at the official opening ceremonies of the Coliseum tomorrow morning.

ZINO FRANCESCATTI was the soloist last night with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony in Carnegie Hall. Because illness forced the violinist to cancel his February engagement with the Philadelphia Orchestra, this was his first orchestral appearance here this season.
John M. Schiff, civic leader, financier and president of the Boy Scouts of America, was honored last night at a dinner in the Pierre Hotel.
The National Broadcasting Company will finance a touring water show for Esther Williams, film actress, in return for exclusive television rights to the production.
The United Parents Associations yesterday called for the appointment of mediators to help solve the teacher pay controversy.
A threat of court action by taxpayers yesterday brought to a temporary halt work on a new half-acre parking lot at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park.

STAUNTON, Va., April 26--The ceremonies held here today at the birthplace of Woodrow Wilson, in commemoration of one of the rare world figures who, like Caesar and Churchill, wrote history as well as made it, coincided with an announcement that would particularly have gratified Wilson as a historian.

SALEM, Ill., April 26--Baseball fans in the Midwest and scouts for at least five major league clubs all are agog over a local teen-ager who is being hailed as the town's greatest athlete since Abe Lincoln displayed his skill here as a wrestler.

The consolidation of the Broadway Association and the West of Central Park Association into a single civic group was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26 --Harry Gold, convicted spy, told a story today of eleven years of espionage and the betrayal of vital chemical, photographic and atomic bomb secrets to the Russians.

Futures prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and burlap rose; cocoa, zinc, tin, lead and hides declined, and price movements for coffee, sugar, rubber, wool and copper were mixed.

Football has been much in the college picture this week, with spring practice in full swing. The news releases from the campus give as much as attention to the gridiron players as to the baseball, track and tennis heroes.
Officials of The United Press announced yesterday that the agency planned its most comprehensive election coverage this year.

THE Mozart Anniversary Festival sponsored by Co lumbia University continued last night with a concert of intimate music at the McMillin Academic Theatre. Chamber music, songs and the great Sonata in F for Piano. Four Hands were on the program.
The Federal Reserve System reduced its daily average holdings of Treasury bills by $117,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

A reader's inquiry about boat charters led to a quest for answers at a New York brokerage office yesterday. The company visited was Sparkman Stephens, Inc., at 11 East Fortyfourth Street, and the man consulted was Drake H. Sparkman, its president.
VIENNA, April 26--Archbishop Gyula Czapik of Eger, acting chairman of the Hungarian Bench of Bishops, died yesterday in a Budapest hospital at the age of 68.

NEARLY half a century after the Newark Museum's founder, John Cotton Dana, honored abstract art, the museum has resumed what has been a frequently broken line of interest in presenting "Abstract Art from 1910 to Today."
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon formally notified President Eisenhower today that he would accept renomination.
STAUNTON, Va., April 26-- Woodrow Wilson's birthplace commemorated today the birthday centennial of the twentyeighth President of the United States.

"The Lovers" will be brought into the Martin Beck on May 10 rather than the preceding night. The switch in dates was made to avoid a conflict with the opening of the "Kiss Me, Kate" revival at the City Center.

MOSCOW, April 26--Five Soviet sailors, considered in the United States to have been the victims of a "political kidnapping," said today that American officials had tried "all means" to force them to stay in New York against their will.
RICHMOND, Va., April 26 (AP) --The president of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway today said his company was headed toward record-breaking earnings of $7.59 a share this year.
The new Reserve Forces Act is severely handicapping the National Guard, the commanding general of the New York National Guard said last night.
The New York State Commissioner of Commerce wooed Canadian industrialists yesterday.
ANTHONY TUDOR'S "Dim Lustre" was revived last night by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House after far too long an absence from the repertoire.
A plea in behalf of "the uncommon man" was sounded last night by Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.
PITTSBURGH, April 26 (UP) --Senator Estes Kefauver as serted today he was "very much more ahead" in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination than at this time four years ago.

Willie Boland was the big man at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The 105-pound jockey from Corpus Christi, Texas, rode four winners in succession, a feat that earned him the acclaim of most of the 15,866 in attendance.

LONDON, April 26--Treasury stocks and oil shares comprised the firmest sections of the stock markets here today. Industrial shares were depressed by the engineering workers' intention to press for a substantial wage increase. Chief movements in this market were generally in response to dividend statements.

The return to the Soviet Union of five Soviet sailors who had originally taken refuge in this country has created a diplomatic and political tempest. Our Government has declared two Soviet diplomats attached to the Soviet United Nations delegation in New York to be persona non grata for their role in the matter.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 25 --Belgian industry is beginning to be painfully pinched by the reduction in United States defense orders here.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is expected to witness the hydrogen bomb tests in the Pacific next month. After that he may visit South Asia and the Middle East.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 26--Robert D. Holbrook, chairman of Compton Advertising, Inc., was elected chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies as the group opened its annual meeting here today. Mr. Holbrook succeeds Henry G. Little, president and chairman of Campbell-Ewald Company, Detroit.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., April 26--Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Lang Metzger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Calhoun Metzger, to William Warren Demlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren H. Demlin of Douglaston, Queens. The wedding will take place in September.
A delegation of eight Russian Protestant and Orthodox churchmen will arrive in New York on June 2 for a ten-day visit.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 26 (UP)--President Sukarno will leave May 14 with a party of thirty for his eighteen-day visit to the United States, the Presidential Palace announced today.
Stocks shot up yesterday in the best gains since early March, as volume expanded to 2,630,000 shares from 2,270,000 on Wednesday.
The Metropolitan Opera Association incurred a deficit of $337,377 for its 1954-55 season.

MONTREAL, April 26 (Canadian Press)--Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminium, Ltd., today announced a $250,000,000 program for the proposed construction of a new hydroelectric project on the Peribonca River in northern Quebec.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 26--Completion of the proposed connection between the New York Thruway at Nyack and the New Jersey Turnpike is at least four years away, the Governors of the two states conceded here today.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 26--Alger Hiss said tonight that he was confident of the falseness of a Soviet prediction that the twentieth century was the century of communism.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn affirmed yesterday the right of the Rev. William Howard Melish to serve as a supply priest at the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.

John J. O'Rourke offered yesterday to hold a new election for president of the 125,000-member Teamsters Joint Council here. But Martin T. Lacey, the man the teamsters' international office said he had defeated by five votes on Feb. 14, rejected the offer.
The nation's newest and largest titanium reduction plant produced its first commercial batch or "heat" of metal yesterday.

The conviction of Joseph P. Ryan, 72-year-old president emeritus of the International Longshoremen's Association, under the Taft-Hartley act, was affirmed unanimously yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

Ten organizations yesterday protested "the failure of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to act on a request for a fullscale investigation of the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez, Columbia University professor."

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 26 (AP)--Gene Littler resumed today where he left off a year ago. He shot a two-under-par 70 in the face of blustery winds to lead twenty-one rivals through the first round of the $37,500 Tournament of Champions golf event.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, April 26--Soviet Premier Nikola A. Bulganin tried Scotch whisky straight today, and it nearly choked him. He tried it again with water and got it down.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 26 (AP)--Bermuda's John Hartley Watlington, the defending champion, today won the Princess Elizabeth Cup series for International fourteen-foot dinghies when he finished third in the last race for a total of 96 points.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Apri1 26 --Edward Arnold, actor whose career spanned fifty-one years on the stage, in films, on radio and on television, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in Encino. His age was 66.

MIDAS never played baseball, but it is increasingly apparent that the Dodgers have the Midas touch. Everything they handle turns to gold. In midseason last year they were in deep pitching distress. Walter (Midas) Atston reached out a hand to Roger Craig and Don Bessent. He couldn't have done better in Tiffany's. Pure gold.

BALTIMORE, April 26--The Orioles, who do not figure to score so many runs in a game as they did in their five-run sixth inning today, beat the Yankees, 7-5.
Space for a large retail outlets in suburban Philadelphia has been leased by E.J. Korvette, Inc., which operates nine stores in the New York City area.
MOSCOW, April 26--Attacks on Communist policy by party members in the Soviet Union are continuing despite recent demands for tighter discipline.
LONDON, April 26--The Soviet Government offered today to "consider and discusss" amending its disarmament proposals to include nuclear weapons.
LONDON, April 26--The Parliamentary Labor Party rejected tonight a suggestion that an apology be made to the Soviet leaders for harsh statements directed at them at a dinner on Monday night.
The Port of New York soon may hit a bonanza with the help of ten northeastern railroads.
First-quarter net earnings of the Socony Mobil Oil Company rose to a record $62,000,000 from $52,000,000 in the first three months of last year.

LONDON, April 26--The Soviet Union has agreed to exercise restraint in the sale or arms to Egypt and other countries. It has also promised to support United Nations efforts to arrange a final settlement between Israel and the Arab states.
RANGOON, Burma, April 26-- An excited member of the crowd beat out a syncopated rhythm on a long black drum. Another played on a reed pipe a melody appropriate for snake charming.
STUTTGART, Germany, April 26--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said tonight that the United States Government expected West Germany to adopt a law for eighteen-month military conscription.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Faced with mounting opposition, House Democrats backtracked today on their plans to push a revised farm bill with direct subsidies to farmers.

CHICAGO, April 26 (UP)--Ohio State was placed on probation by the Western Conference for at least one year today and was barred from the Rose Bowl football game for the same period for violation of conference rules on aid to athletes.

JUNEAU, Alaska, April 26 (AP)--Adlai E. Stevenson continued to hold an 8-to-5 margin over Senator Estes Kefauver today in the territory's first Presidential primary. President Eisenhower's margin over Mr. Stevenson widened to nearly 1,100.
Soviet-British trade has risen sharply since restrictions on Western exports to the Soviet bloc were eased in August, 1954, United States Government officials said yesterday.
TWO of the greatest masterpieces of religious music were presented in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church last night by the Oratorio Society under the direction of William Strickland.
WASHINGTON, April 26--The Federal Trade Commission, by a 3-2 margin, decided today it had jurisdiction over the advertising of health and accident insurance in Interstate Commerce.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., in the fiscal year ended January 31, had the greatest sales volume in its 114-year-history, according to the annual report of Bruce A. Gimbel, president, released today.

"The History of a Literary Radical and Other Papers," by Randolph Bourne, has been scheduled for June publication by S.A. Russell. Bourne, who died in 1917 at the age of 31, was one of the controversial figures in American thought and criticism in the literary field.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26-- Rabbi Leon S. Lang, spiritual leader of Congregation Beth El since 1942, died yesterday at his home in West Philadelphia. His age was 57.
Excess reserves of the nation's commercial banks declined during the week ended on Wednesday. Such a reduction in reserves tends to reduce the supply of lendable funds in the banking system.

A Jersey City stock broker was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding thousands of clients in a $15,000,000 uranium stock swindle.

BALTIMORE, April 26--Gresham Hough Poe, former investment banker, a grand-nephew of Edgar Allan Poe and member of a family that made athletic history at Princeton University, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.

A "substantial" increase in railway operating expenses and a drop in net income from oil and gas operations, held earnings of the Union Pacific Railroad to $15,825,759 in the first quarter of this year. In the first three months of 1955 net income was $16,341,180.

Samuel Rubinton, a prominent Brooklyn lawyer, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a four-week illness. Mr. Rubinton was 65 years old. He was a member of the law firm of Rubinton Coleman, 32 Court Street and resided at 160 Columbia Heights.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 763,437 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company has signed a preliminary contract for the completion of the Concord Village apartment development on Jay Street in downtown Brooklyn.
HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., April 26--A leading exponent of creative thinking today advised industry to improve its suggestion box system.

Sixteen of the eighteen rounds of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Amsterdam were completed yesterday when six adjourned games were finished, according to a report from the Netherlands.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company celebrated its 150th anniversary yesterday with the announcement of grants totaling $500,000 to 186 colleges and universities.
The Board of Estimate unanimously adopted yesterday a 1956-57 budget of $1,917,229,968. It was only $5,550 larger than the executive budget of $1,917,224,418 submitted by Mayor Wagner on April 2.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 26--A Negro mass meeting unanimously endorsed tonight the continuance of a boycott against this city's transit system.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 26 (UP)--Three American players, Ham Richardson, Budge Patty and Darlene Hard, won semifinal berths today in the British hard court tennis tournament.

A set of miniature hand looms enables a textile manufacturing concern to weave samples of new fabric patterns in its New York offices in a day or two. The customary method of turning out samples on production looms at the company's mill would require from four to six weeks.

Mr. and Mrs. Zareh Sourian of 30 East Seventieth Street have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gay Sourian, to Stephen Chinlund. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Chinlund of 45 Gramercy Park and Vineyard Haven, Mass.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation attained record steel production, billings and shipments in the first three months this year. Net income was the highest for any first quarter, although it failed to reach the record profit level of the final 1955 quarter.

ODESSA, U.S.S.R., April 26 --Most of the 700 Soviet repatriates who came here April 17 from Buenos Aires have been whisked to towns of their choice. They were the first large number of repatriates from the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Government smoothed the way today for a greater volume of exports to the Soviet Union and to her European satellites. It marked the first major easing of trade restrictions since the beginning of the "cold war."

RABAT, Morocco, April 26-- Sultan Mohammed V ended today forty-four years of French control of Moroccan foreign affairs by naming Ahmed Balafrej, secretary general of the Istiqlal (Independence) party, Foreign Minister of Morocco.
WASHINGTON, April 26----Department store sales, in the week ended last Saturday, were 1 per cent above those in the corresponding week of last year.

The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it was adding eighty patrolmen to its police force. The move is part of a drive that began last fall against crime in the subways. In the opinion of Charles L. Patterson, chairman, and E. Vincent Curtayne, an agency member, the campaign has reduced crime and provided greater protection for riders.

TROUT anglers are going to get out there and try this week-end. That is their nature; there is no way to stop them even if anybody besides their wives wanted to stop them. But they might as well know what they will be up against:
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) --Merchant marine spokesmen today opposed a bill to remove the requirement that at least half of surplus farm commodity shipments be carried in United States vessels.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26 (AP)--Kentucky Derby confusion mounted today as Toby B., a noneligible, showed his mud-churning heels to a half-dozen Derby hopefuls, including Career Boy, in the $33,900 Blue Grass Stakes. Toby B. won by three-quarters of a length.

ONE swallow may not make a summer, but two books can make a trend. And this morning, with the publication of "Double Exposure," written by an ebullient Belgian named Theo Fleischman, a novel in which reincarnation plays a part, we can report a modest trend in metempsychosis.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Senate Democrats opened an attack on the Eisenhower Administration's atomic power policies today with the hope of developing a major issue for the campaign.

The Board of Estimate yesterday approved with virtually no change the Mayor's expense budget for 1956-57. This action, together with Mr. Wagner's repeated and emphatic assertion that the sum allotted to teacher pay increases cannot be enlarged, means that the hope of salary improvement beyond the $21,000,000 specified is deferred to 1957.
JERUSALEM, April 26--The World Zionist Congress tonight closed a two-day debate on Israel's security crisis after having heard new attacks on United States and Soviet policies.
BERLIN, Germany, April 26-- Dr. Otto Suhr, Mayor of West Berlin, was prevented from visiting an outlying part of his city today by the East German police.

CHICAGO, April 26--Soybean futures soared today to new highs for the May and July deliveries on the Roard of Trade. The advance was sparked by further price gains in soybean oil and meal. Profit-taking by longs was heavy at times, but there was little outside selling pressure.
Fifty-eight silvery new trailer vans were swing aboard a tanker by a heavy crane in Port Newark yesterday in the first commercial application of a new concept in shipping.
PARIS, April 26 (AP)--Jean Ybarnegaray, former minister in the late Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain's wartime Vichy regime, died here last night after an operation. He was 73 years old.
Domestic politics, service rivalries and a "Pearl Harbor complex" in the United States are helping the Soviet Government make a point.

On the wholesome theory that "the best informed community is the best governed community," Chairman Felt of the City Planning Commission has begun the issuance of a Newsletter to be published from time to time by his department "to present current information concerning the planning, growth and development of the ...
City Civil Defense Director Robert E. Condon has dismissed the chairman of the Brooklyn Civil Defense.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Plans for a world-wide check of radiation levels in the wake of next month's hydrogen bomb tests were announced by the Government today.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- The Army has drastically limited the use of "guilt by association" as a test in security cases involving military personnel.

SCORE another beautiful dance world for Doris Humphrey. Her "Dawn in New York" had its premiere last night at the Juilliard Concert Hall, as part of the Juilliard School's fiftieth anniversary festival, on a program by the young Juilliard Dance Theatre.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Senator Paul H. Douglas declared today that the State Department's position on the issue of forced labor might embarrass the United States before the world.

All the advance reports have indicated that Premier Nu, in Burma, will have received a landslide endorsement when the votes in yesterday's popular election are finally counted. His party is overwhelmingly strong and his policies have enjoyed the confidence of a majority of the Burmans.
Daylight Saving Time begins at 2 A.M. tomorrow.
CHICAGO, April 27--Adlai E. Stevenson arrived here by plane this afternoon from Miami, Fla., where he concluded an eastern campaign tour for the 1956 Democratic Presidential nomination.
A motion by counsel for Martin T. Lacey to cite John J. O'Rourke for contempt of Federal Court was withdrawn yesterday.
Work will begin in Arthur Kill next week on a 10,950,000 railroad bridge with one of the longest vertical lift, spans in the world.
The Government completed its antitrust case yesterdays against the International Boxing Club and its affiliates.

Some of the best-fed microorganisms in the world will get their sugar-beet molasses faster and cleaner in the future, thanks to a newly modernized molasses terminal just completed by Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., on the East River.
ODESSA, U.S.S.R., April 27 --From atop the windswept staircase leading to Odessa harbor, the port seemed to be a busy place today.

Four aluminum seals in full relief adorn the facade of the Coliseum. They represent the arms of the United States, New York State, New York City and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, the agency that built the project.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- The State Department took a jaundiced view today of the professed Soviet willingness to abide by a United Nations embargo on arms for the Middle East.
EAST WILLISTON, L.I., April 27--Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley captured the opening medal-play tournament of the women's Cross County Golf Association today for the second straight year.

FROM Yakutsk in eastern Siberia, not far below the Arctic Circle, to India is some 4,000 miles. It is 4,000 miles of vast forests, treeless open country, great rivers, arid wastes of the Gobi Desert and towering peaks of the Himalayas.

JERUSALEM, April 27-- North African delegates told the World Zionist Congress today that nearly 300,000 Jews in Morocco and Tunisia were living under the threat of extermination by Moslem extremists. They demanded unlimited acceptance by Israel of North African refugees.

The Fiat Company, leading Italian automobile manufacturer, had gross sales last year of 310 billion lire (about $500,000,000), according to a report issued here yesterday by the company's representatives. The sales were 13 per cent higher than in 1954.

A Federal audit of the Union City, N.J., Housing Authority's accounts and records, following the indictment of its executive director last month for embezzlement, yesterday uncovered shortages amounting to $79,345.

THE Princess of Monaco got one, and so did Mrs. E.C. Daniel Jr. Eighty-five per cent of all the girls who get married do receive diamond engagement rings, according to a survey by diamond authorities.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- President Eisenhower today asked his Committee on Education Beyond the High School to deal as broadly as possible with questions in that field.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) --The Government set out today to recover S2,000,000 granted a group of cheese-makers about two years ago in allegedly "unauthorized and improper" payments.
The successful sale of two big issues has given the market for new capital a better tone, but the calendar of offerings continues heavy.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 27--The billions of dollars in new equity money that industry needs for expansion can be supplied by middle and upper-income families in this country without disrupting present spending habits, the American Association of Advertising Agencies was told today.

The I.L.A.'s withdrawal from its misalliance with the Brotherhood of Teamsters may well have saved the teamsters from expulsion from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and from the handicaps that would have surely followed.

THOMAS SCHERMAN conducted the Little Orchestra last night in the last of four concerts given at Columbia University's Mozart Anniversary Festival. The program was presented in the McMillin Theatre with Erica Morini as violin soloist.
In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday afternoon, Miss Barbara Anne Buck was married to George Kendall Moss.

George H. Duxbury, retired insurance executive, died of a stroke yesterday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. He was 62 years old and resided in Saddle River, N.J.

MONTREAL, April 27--Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs, urged Canadians today not to fear United States domination of Canada, economically or in matters of defense. He stressed the importance of United States investment in Canada.
HOLLYWOOD BEACH, Fla., April 27--Abolition of the "double-standard" in political contributions was advocated today by Victor Reuther.

JERSEY JOE WALCOTT, the heavyweight champion of the world, misjudged the whereabouts of the ring ropes on that September night in 1952. He took a backward step. The top strand recoiled under the impact and flung him forward.

STOCKHOLM, April 27--The possibility of an uncontrolled price-wage spiral such as brought on general strikes recently in Denmark and Finland was the real reason for Sweden's recent rollback in the volume of bank credit.
CHARLESTON, S. C., April 27 (AP)--Gen. Mark W. Clark said today he opposed integration of white and Negro troops when the policy was adopted by the Government in 1950.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 27--Judge Maengkom, who presided over the controversial fourteen-month trial of Leon Jungschlaeger, disclosed today that he had written a verdict on the case and would announce it "later" if necessary.

Back in the friendly confines of Ebbets Field, the Dodgers located their missing home-run punch last night. Jackie Robinson, Roy Campanella and Gil Hodges clouted the ball into the stands as the Brooks routed the Pirates, 7-2, before 7,056 chilled onlookers.
Loyalty Day, set up by patriotic groups in opposition to the Communists' celebration of May Day, will be celebrated today with parades in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
LONDON, April 27--The Soviet leaders' visit to Britain ended today in Russian promises of future goodwill and proffers of increased trade. These evoked a warm response from Prime Minister Eden.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 27 (UP)--The City of Montgomery held firm to its policy of segregated transportation today as a Negro boycott of city buses neared the end of its twentyfirst week.
CALLAO, Peru, April 25-- Port and national officials are planning a ceremony to open Callao's modern port terminal, grain elevator and allied facilities.
ALBANY, April 27--A Brooklyn man who three times had been sentenced to die for the murder of his parents was set free today by the Court of Appeals.
A jurist who is really at home on the bench--either in court or park--personally inspected the scene of the Tavern-on-theGreen dispute in Central Park yesterday.
SPOKANE, Wash., April 27-- A transcontinental commuter with Presidential ambitions began pumping hands across the State of Washington today.
A two-and-a-half-year investigation into racketeering in the garment industry has moved into high gear with the subpoenaing of the books and records of 140 concerns.
The International Longshoremen'S Association withdrew yesterday from its controversial "working alliance" with three major segments of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L.-C.I.O.

CAIRO, April 27--There was almost a joyful ring to headlines in the controlled Cairo press today announcing the failure of Soviet-British talks to reach any concrete agreement on the Middle East.

IVREA, Italy, April 25--In the United States Olivetti is just the name of a typewriter. In this ancient and smiling town, where the Olivettis are manufactured, it stands for a social and political philosophy.
WASHINGTON, April 27--The House of Representatives approved today a record $51,860,000,000 road-building program and tax increases on highway users to help pay for it.
If S. Hurok has his way the Moscow Art Theatre will present its production of Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina" on Broadway next season.
Only $9,500,000 in outside capital was needed to build the $35,000,000 Coliseum at Columbus Circle.
BOSTON, April 27--A Radcliffe College graduate rose from the audience at Symphony Hall today and bowed in response to an ovation for her accomplishments as a composer.

A six-story apartment house is planned for a plot 171 by 150 feet at the southeast corner of Parsons Boulevard and Fortyfirst Avenue in Flushing, Queens. The property, containing tyro dwellings, has been purchased by Samuel Lustbader...

FORT BUCKNER, Okinawa, April 16--Life is changing for the better for about 125,000 Orientals in the twenty or so typhoon-swept islands of the remote Yaeyama and Sakishima sub-groups in the Ryukyu archipelago. The change is being directed by two United States Army majors.

IN the vaulted basement of St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church at West End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street the Repertory Players are offering Friedrich von Schiller's "Mary Stuart" with far more fervor than distinction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 --The Hollywood division of the National Broadcasting Company is taking steps toward concentrating its television film activities in one location. The network has rented, on a yearly basis, four large sound stages at the California Studios, a motionpicture rental studio occupied largely with TV film work.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 27 (AP)--Ham Richardson of Westfield, N.J., and Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris today swept into the final of the British hard court tennis tournament.

Stocks yesterday made the best gains since March 9 and closed at the best levels in two weeks. The New York Times rail average in the course of the day touched 116.03, the highest mark since July 28, 1930.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 27--The regime of Matyas Rakosi announced today Hungary's second Five-Year Plan.

PARIS, Sept. 27--Premier Guy Mollet demanded a vote of confidence from the National Assembly today in defense of proposals to raise taxes by the equivalent of $400,000,000 for increased old-age pensions.

The citizens of this city have a right to expect that members of the Council have some basic understanding of the correct procedures to be followed in lawmaking. Time and time again Councilmen betray a woeful lack of the essentials.
Edmond H. Leavey was named yesterday president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, succeeding William H. Harrison, who died last week.

Dr. Willard F. Libby of the Atomic Energy Commission said last night that "we must have" atomic power for peaceful uses. The needs of the rest of the world for nuclear power, he added, are "even more desperate than ours."
The American Gas and Electric Company has ordered from General Electric Company what will be the two largest steamelectric generators ever built.
ALGIERS, Algeria, April 27-- Robert Lacoste, Minister Residing in Algeria, said in Bone today that the French Government had no intention of negotiating with the nationalist rebels.
ALBANY, April 27--The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 329 of 776 applicants had passed the examination for admission to the bar March 1-2.

WASHINGTON, April 27-- Soviet Ambassador Georgi N. Zaroubin tried today to persuade four Russian sailors to return to their homeland. He was told that they wanted to stay in the United States "forever."

Though some slight element of doubt has prevailed in recent weeks, it comes as no real surprise that Mr. Nixon is willing to accept the Republican nomination for the Vice Presidency if the convention offers it to him. If he has delayed in making known this...
The Coliseum at Columbus Circle, a $35,000,000 investment in the gregariousness of man, opens this morning.
CHICAGO, April 27--American psychoanalysts met here today to honor Sigmund Freud as the hundredth anniversary of his birth approached. The date is May 6.
BOSTON, April 27--The halfspeed curves with which the Yankees' Don Larsen kept the opposition off balance today sent the Boston Red Sox to their fifth straight defeat, 5-2.
A billion dollars will be spent annually in New York City for construction of public and quasipublic improvements in the next few years, Mayor Wagner estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UP) --David Greenglass said today that his sister and brother-inlaw, Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, had deliberately become martyrs for the "completely erroneous" cause of world communism.
THE striped bass blitz has not yet struck Long Island waters but a few skirmishers have moved in along the beaches, apparently the advance guard of the invasion.
Seventeen Paulist seminarians, largest class in the ninety-eightyear history of the Paulist Fathers, will be ordained to the priesthood in ceremonies Thursday.

Comparative quiet reigns at the moment over the Middle East as a result of new pledges obtained by Secretary General Hammarskjold from both Israel and the Arab states that they will observe an unconditional cease-fire on all fronts.
CHICAGO, April 27--American Jews uncommitted to Zionism were urged today to seek Government inquiry into relationships between certain voluntary American agencies and the state of Israel.
The first of two Masonic services of thanksgiving was held last night as part of the 175th anniversary of the Grand Lodge of New York State.

Cottonseed oil prices soared yesterday in the sharpest advance in over a year on the New York Produce Exchange, Futures climbed to the highest level since June, 1951, on the largest volume since Sept. 21, 1952.
BROCKTON, Mass., April 27 (AP)--"I want the whole world to know this was Rocky's decision only."

LONDON, April 27--The Archbishop of Canterbury was rebuked tonight by three Ministers of the Government for his recent criticism that the British Government was guilty of "inaction" over the drafting of a new constitution for Cyprus.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- The Federal Reserve Board has released the results of the first survey in a decade of bank loans to business.

Civic and religious leaders and 2,000 school children marched through West Harlem's main thoroughfares yesterday to arouse interest in the annual spring clean-up drive sponsored by the Harlem Youth Council.
RANGOON, Burma, Saturday, April 28--The Socialist-oriented party of Premier Nu moved into an early lead this morning in Burma's second national election since gaining independence eight years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 27--The two principal Democratic foreign policy leaders of Congress raised fresh obstacles today to the Administration's program for greatly expanded foreign aid.

The Chesapeake Bay Ferry Commission, a public agency that is taking over the properties of the Virginia Ferry Corporation, has negotiated the sale of $20,000,000 of revenue bonds to finance the acquisition and to lay the groundwork for expansion of service.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Prices received by farmers for their products rose 1 per cent during the month ended in midApril, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27-- A stirring anchor mile by Ron Delany, Villanova sophomore, in the college distance medley relay championship, brought the opening phase of the sixty-second Penn Relay Carnival to a close today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27--Most observers here believe that Dag Hammarskjold has won an assurance that there will be no war in the Middle Fast for several months at least. Before his arrival on his peace mission, a war before June had been considered an evenmoney bet in the same circles.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's filmed situation comedy series, "Joe and Mabel," will finally get an airing starting June 19. It replaces the "Guy Lombardo Diamond Jubilee," which will leave the television network June 12.

THE exhibition of traditional and present-day reli gious art in the Parish House of the Church of the Ascension, 12 West Eleventh Street, has been rather casually assembled but includes some interesting examples.

Mrs. Grace Crawley Oakley, retired financial secretary of the Skin and Cancer Unit, University hospital, New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, died yesterday at the hospital after a cerebral hemorrhage. She was 79 years old.
Albert J. Mesler's Power took the feature race at Jamaica yesterday, after the stewards rejected a foul claim against him.

NOT all letters this department receives from readers ask for help with cooking problems. Often the mail includes interesting contributions from women who have worked out their own special recipes or culinary quick tricks. Some of these suggestions are discussed here today.

The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., has sold an issue of $2,400,000 of water main and sewer construction bonds due serially from 1957 to 1988 to Phelps, Fenn Co. and associates. The bonds have been priced on reoffering to yield 2.4 to 3.4 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Another breach developed today in the united labor movement as an earlier crisis evaporated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27--The filing of incorporation papers for George Sidney Productions, Inc., as a California company brought confirmation today from the director that he would leave Metro GoldwynMayer upon the expiration of his contract next January.

Part of the former Kramer King Works of the Associated Piece Dye Company properties at 27 East Thirty-third Street in Paterson, N.J., has been leased by the Arlington Plastics Prints Company of Newark. The property, which fronts on Tenth Avenue at the traffic circle, was leased through J.I. Kislak, Inc., as broker, from the F. A. Realty Company.

Nearly seven weeks have passed since Jesus de Galindez, the Spanish Basque teacher at Columbia University, disappeared as if by magic. It is no exaggeration to say that his case has aroused hemispheric alarm and indignation as nothing of its kind has ever done before.

The Borg-Warner Corporation, in a reorganization of top management, elected Robert S. Ingersoll, 42 years old, as president and chief operating officer. His father, Roy C. Ingersoll, 71 years old, who had been president six years, relinquished that title but remains as board chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay told a Senate investigating subcommittee today that this country must assume that the Russians were "building a very fine air force."
An early-morning ground fog swirled in from the Atlantic Ocean yesterday, laying a patchwork quilt over the metropolitan area and parts of New Jersey.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday. Old July was 35 points ($1.75 a bale) higher. Other months were unchanged to 7 points (35 cents a bale) higher.

Throughout their training campaign this spring the Giants made it clear they were banking heavily on three youngsters--Al Worthington, Daryl Spencer and Foster Castleman--in their rehabilitation program for 1956.

WASHINGTON, April 27--A space helmet in which a child can "blast off" from the earth and return minus his tonsils was patented this week. In the more prosaic terms that grown--ups use, it is anesthesia-administering apparatus.
Sales, net income and paper production of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in the first three months of this year set records for the period.
MOSCOW, April 27--Marshals Georgi K. Zhukov and Semyon K. Timoshenko have called for the strengthening of discipline in the Soviet armed forces.

Salesmen of the Ford of the furniture industry scurried from South to West last week.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) --An Administration request for $37,900,000 to build three experimental merchant ships, including an atomic tanker, was turned down today by the House Appropriations Committee.
ALBANY, April 27--The Court of Appeals agreed today to hear an appeal in a $50,000 libel action involving the "Hanley letter" episode of the 1950 campaign for Governor in this state.
Rocky Marciano, iron-fisted son of a New England shoe factory worker, retired yesterday as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion at the age of 31 to devote more time to his family.
NEW HAVEN, April 27--Yale remained on top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Cornell, 3--2, today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 27 (UP)--Gene Littler took a fourstroke lead in golf's Tournament of Champions today. He stood off a challenge by Shelley Mayfield by shooting a 71 for a 141 total at the end of thirty-six holes.

WASHINGTON, April 27--A leading nuclear physicist said today that for the first time in the atomic age the United States was lagging behind the Soviet Union in the declassification of scientific information.

CHICAGO, April 27--Stockholders of Montgomery Ward Co. today presented John A. Barr, chairman and president, with a peaceful, uncontentious annual meeting as an accolade to round out his first year as chief executive officer of the mail order and retail concern.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 27 (AP)--Bermuda yachtsmen won the Ireland Cup today, beating, the United States, 34 to 26, in the fifth race in the series for Luder-16's. Bermuda took the series, 4-1, and captured its third trophy during international race week.

CHICAGO, April 27--Soybean futures again took the spotlight today on the Board of Trade. Big gains were registered in the May and July deliveries, and there was activity and strength in the deferred futures. Rapidly changing prices were the rule in the soybean pit.
Striking bus drivers on lines serving Rockland County, N.Y., and northern Bergen County, N.J., were warned yesterday to end their walkout within fortyeight hours.

FORT KNOX, Ky., April 27-- Wilber M. Brucker, the Secretary of the Army, declared today that the Army was making "substantial progress" in developing the intermediate-range ballistics missile of 1,500 miles range. He also disclosed it had been named Jupiter.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 27-- The Quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Church opened debate here today on a plan to build a $1,000,000 School of International Service in Washington.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 27 (UP)--Irate Ohio State football fans chorused today that other schools were just as guilty as the Buckeyes in helping their athletes.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 27 (AP)--Two sophomore sprinters, Dave Sime of Duke and Bobby Morrow of Abilene Christian, today warmed up with 0:09.4 clockings for a heralded 100yard showdown in the fortyseventh Drake Relays tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 27-- The Office of Defense Mobilization today abandoned tax concessions as an inducement to railroads to increase their fleets of freieht cars.
STUTTGART, Germany, April 27--The Christian Democratic Union's annual conference reacted politely today to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's ardent defense of his foreign and domestic policies.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 28 --A group of Princeton residents involved in the development of public opinion survey work has announced the formation of a concern to build a research center here.

TOKYO, April 28--Eleven thousand Japanese fishermen sailed north from Hokkaido today into an unknown future. A few Japanese diplomats and Soviet officials in Moscow will be deciding that future during the next few days.
KATMANDU, Nepal, April 29 --The Hindu kingdom of Nepal is preparing for 10:43 A.M. on Wednesday, the supreme moment in its national life.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 28--Australians are looking forward to Coral Sea Week, in which they will commemorate the Battle of the Coral Sea, May 4-8, 1942. The battle saved Australia from Japanese invasion in World War II.

Recent statements by President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles, in which they indicated that United States action regarding the Middle East should be taken through the United Nations, implied the same thing. But the London communique made it official.

HAL MARCH, who was married recently, will star in "The Bachelor," a musical comedy writ ten for television. The musical will be presented in color by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday, July 15, from 7:30 to 9 P.M.

DEALER-MANAGEMENT relations in the automo tive industry, which have been a, storm center for many months, moved toward a better understanding with the recent announcement by Henry Ford II, president of the Ford Motor Company, of the appointment of a Ford Motor Company Dealer Policy Board.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 28 (UP)--Budge Patty, a 32-year-old Army veteran from Los Angeles, rallied after a poor first set today to defeat Ham Richardson of Westfield, N.J., 1--6, 6--3, 6--3, 6--3. It was the first time an American ever had won the men's singles title at the British hard-court tennis championships.
Paul Keres of Estonia met his first defeat yesterday in the seventeenth and semi-final round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Amsterdam.

ARDMORE, Pa., April 28-- Miss Ann Dugmore Evans was married to Sturtevant Overin 3d here this afternoon in St. Paul's Lutheran Church.

MADRID, April 28--One of the key defense witnesses at the trial of four young intellectuals earlier this week has been replaced in an important Government post.

WASHINGTON, April 28-- The Soviet Union has "led into our strongest suit" in challenging this country in commercial and industrial competition, Joseph M. Dodge believes.

After fifty years at sea he gave his last order, "finished with engines," left the bridge, and swallowed the anchor. He had reached the top: Commodore of the Cunard Line.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 29-- George Lambrecht, the retired trainer of athletic teams at The Hill School, made his first appearance on campus yesterday in some time. The fabulous Lamrecht, now 79, seemed fully recovered from his recent operation. He was surprisingly spry.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 30-- The Quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Church unanimously approved today the establishment of a $1,000,000 School of International Service at American University in Washington, D.C.
